QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAPUA NEW GUINEA: SBS TELEVISION CREW

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to press reports that a Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) television crew entered Papua New Guinea illegally to make a television program covering events on Bougainville. Are the reports correct? If so, what action is being taken in relation to these breaches by an Australian Government instrumentality of Papua New Guinea immigration, customs and quarantine laws?

—The position of the Australian Government is that Bougainville is, of course, part of Papua New Guinea. Accordingly, journalists going to any part of Papua New Guinea must, like any other visitors, follow PNG Government entry procedures. In the light of Prime Minister Namaliu's comments about an illegal visit by an SBS team to Bougainville, I understand that Mr Beaz- ley has sought a report from the head of the SBS, Mr Brian Johns. Until we get the results of that report, it is difficult to comment further, except to say this: the Australian Government does not, of course, seek to direct the Australian media. It does, nonetheless, expect all Australians overseas to abide by the laws and regulations of the countries they visit. There is no reason whatsoever to exempt journalists, simply as journalists, from the scope of that general prescription.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to an article on page 1 of yesterday's Brisbane Sunday Sun titled `Aussie Pilots for War'. Can the Minister confirm the claim made in that article that Royal Australian Air Force F18 pilots from Tindal and Williamtown, and possibly F111 pilots from Amberley, could soon be flying combat missions in the Gulf with United States forces?

—I could not possibly confirm that report; it is based on absolutely no factual information at all. In fact, I deny that story categorically. I understand the journalist concerned did ring people in the Department of Defence with this particular story, was given the correct facts, chose not to print them but instead to print a lot of distortions and inventions. The only potential Australian pilots in that region are the ones I mentioned before-those on exchange. I think currently there is one Chinook pilot and two crew on a C130. As I have indicated I think at a previous press conference, at least one F118 pilot is on exchange and could be deployed there if his unit goes there. But the story basically is a fabrication and should be totally denied.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to comments reported last Friday, 15 February, by the new Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Tony Cole:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . consumption tax is an efficient tax system-very hard for people to avoid and also a system that can reduce the impact of taxes on inputs to business and on exports. So I have seen advantages in a consumption tax . . .
Does the Minister agree that these advantages would accompany a consumption tax and, if so, why does the Government not now support the coalition's call for the introduction of such a tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer made a full statement about this matter last year in the House of Representatives. First of all, there are many clear advantages and many clear disadvantages of a consumption tax. It is a matter of judgment and balance as to whether we introduce one in particular circumstances and at a particular time. Mr Cole, the new Secretary to the Treasury, in the course of a series of Industry Commission reports, has referred to this issue as well as to other issues of taxation reform. In one sense, in his new role as Secretary to the Treasury there is nothing particularly new in what he is saying. However, I should make the point that Mr Cole, the Secretary to the Treasury, does not agree with the Opposition's position on this issue. For example, on Friday Mr Cole stated:

ANSWER.PARA: I have never regarded it as the thing that would lift Australia's savings rate to the rate that it ought to be or that it would solve our current account problem.
On the other hand, on Friday Dr Hewson supported the introduction of a consumption tax. He used the following words:
In order to try and change the incentives to save and thereby the magnitude of total savings.

There is a clear difference of emphasis, degree and philosophy between Mr Cole and the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, on that particular issue of what a consumption tax might do to the savings ratio in Australia. Of course, as Senator Short pointed out in his question, Mr Cole did say that a consumption tax was efficient in that it was hard to avoid. That is certainly true, but there are other means of ensuring efficiencies in the taxation system. This Government has taken a variety of steps not only to broaden the tax base but also to ensure efficiencies in taxation collection. The Opposition, for example, still advocates a rorting of the capital gains tax, which is something that this Government would not countenance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—It is not rubbish. It is quite clear in the statements made by the Opposition leaders-if Senator Chapman happened to read them-both at the last election and since.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer. I draw his attention to the fact that the new Secretary to the Treasury does, in fact, say that the consumption tax would have a positive impact on savings, contrary to the Minister's statement. I ask: would the Minister not agree that introducing a consumption tax would be a more efficient method of assisting our export industries, and, hence, our ongoing balance of payments crisis, in a fair and equitable way than the various proposals which have been floated in the media as being considered for the 12 March industry statement, such as piecemeal changes to the ramshackle wholesale sales tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am as bored as all hell by the various ideas that have been floated in the media-highly speculative ideas about a whole range of issues. I do not know where all these suggestions come from, but I must say that I have not contributed to that debate in the media about these issues.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say that yes, having regard to the fact that the majority of countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development-perhaps nearly all of the countries in the OECD-now have a consumption tax of some kind or another, generally a value added tax, the existence of those taxes alleviates some burdens on their export sectors, which are not alleviated here under the present taxation regime. So, the answer to that part of the honourable senator's question is yes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH COMMITTEE OF FOREIGN MINISTERS ON SOUTHERN AFRICA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister advise the Senate as to the outcome of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers' meeting on Southern Africa which he attended in London over the weekend? How long before sanctions will start to be lifted? What is the situation as far as the sports boycott is concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were three important outcomes from the meeting I attended in London over the weekend. In the first place there was acceptance of the principle of phased relaxation of sanctions in response to further concrete developments as they occur-in effect, acceptance of the notion that sanctions pressure should be maintained until irreversible intentions become irreversible achievements-but that as such achievements do occur sanctions policy should be modified accordingly.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, there was agreement that the time to make the first move in this respect will be after an initial threshold has been overcome-a threshold involving three specific elements, all of which are expected to fall into place within the next three to four months: that is to say, in the first place the release of political prisoners and the indemnification of exiles, which is agreed now to be resolved by 30 April. A resolution is also involved of outstanding issues relating to security legislation. That is expected to be sorted out this parliamentary session, by the end of June at the very latest. The third element in this initial threshold is what happens after the promised repeal occurs-also expected this parliamentary session-of the remaining major legislative pillars of apartheid, namely, the Group Areas, Lands and Population Registrations Acts.

The third element in the weekend's proceedings that I think was important was the separate and distinct agreement reached in relation to sport; namely, that there should be no barriers placed on the resumption of international sporting contacts in respect of those sports which have achieved unified non-racial administration and which have been recognised in that respect by the relevant representative non-racial sporting organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The communique says that you will not look at it until the Harare conference.
—I know exactly what the communique says because I wrote those particular words in question, and the language of the communique in question says:

ANSWER.PARA: Taking account of these developments the Committee agreed to present to the Harare Heads of Government Meeting further specific proposals by which the Commonwealth can continue to encourage non-racial sport.
The truth of the matter, as I think I know rather better than Senator Hill, is that the statement has been clearly and unequivocally laid down, and I quote:

The Committee agreed that it was appropriate for those sporting codes which achieve unity to be recognised by the international community. The Committee also agreed that the Commonwealth should continue to be guided in this respect by the views of representative non-racial sporting organisations.

They are the two elements of the agreement in principle. Naturally, the actual implementation of that will take some time, as the unification process takes time within each of these sports in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is deferred to November.
—Senator Baume knows not what he says, on this or any other matter. As to what that means in practice--
—What does it mean?

—What it means, so far as sport is concerned, is simply this: there are ample grounds for optimism and that, that agreement in principle-as I have described-having been reached, obstacles to sporting contacts will be able to be progressively removed over the course of the next year. So far as individual sports are concerned this means: for soccer, this unquestion- ably will happen within that time frame because a unified administration is a recognised reality almost now; so far as cricket is concerned, unity is expected to be achieved by about June; so far as the Olympic sports are concerned, unity is expected round about the end of the year; for rugby, there is still, however, a question mark because negotiations have been stalled for some time but efforts are being made to regain momentum and it just is not possible to predict a timetable at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: The important thing about all of this is that sport is being treated now with the complete agreement of the Commonwealth Ministers from all the countries concerned as a separate and distinct issue with criteria for resolution of its own. That is something that has been foreshadowed for some time, but this is the first time that that agreement has been reached in principle.

So far as sanctions generally are concerned, the general understanding was reached, although this was only partially explicit in terms of the communique, that it would be appropriate for the relaxation of sanctions to be considered in roughly the following order as various milestones are reached: first of all, people-oriented sanctions-that is, consular, cultural, air links and tourism types of issues; trade and investment sanctions; financial sanctions, including International Monetary Fund loans; and, finally, the arms embargo.

The first important milestone will be the achievement of the legislative changes that I have referred to and the resolution of the obstacles issues that I have referred to relating to prisoners and exiles. It is reasonable to anticipate on the basis of the discussions that took place over the weekend that when this happens at least the so-called people-oriented sanctions will be capable of modification. Subsequent milestones are rather less clearly defined at this stage. They are only the subject of indicative reference in the communique, but Commonwealth Ministers will be in a better position to resolve these and other questions of detail when we next meet, as is currently proposed, in late May.

Overall, the meeting, while it was not for a variety of reasons an easy one in which to achieve consensus, very much succeeded in meeting Australian objectives. These objectives were essentially to get Commonwealth sanctions policy reshaped in a measured, balanced and realistic fashion so as to ensure in turn a continuing influential role for the Commonwealth not only in its own member countries but also in the evolution of policy in the United States of America, Europe and Japan-all of which are crucially important players if external pressure is to be effectively maintained on South Africa until the destruction of apartheid is finally assured. Given the haranguing I have been subjected to, it might be appropriate for me to seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of the communique of the weekend.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
COMMONWEALTH COMMITTEE OF FOREIGN MINISTERS ON SOUTHERN AFRICA
Special Session: London, 16 February 1991
Members of the Committee

The Rt. Hon. Joe Clark (Canada)-Chairman; Senator The Hon. Gareth Evans (Australia); Dr Cedric Grant (Guyana); The Hon. V.C. Shukla (India); The Hon. Dato' Abu Hassan bin Haji Omar (Malaysia); The Hon. Major-General Ike 0.S. Nwachukwu (Nigeria); The Hon. Ahmed Hassan Diria (Tanzania); The Hon. Lieutenant-General B.N. Mibenge (Zambia); The Hon. Dr. Nathan Shamuyarira (Zimbabwe).
CONCLUDING STATEMENT
Recent Developments in South Africa
1. The Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa met in a special session in London on 16 February to review recent developments in South Africa.

2. The immediate background to the meeting was President de Klerk's statement of 1 February 1991 to the South African Parliament in which he endorsed the concept of a multi-party conference to advance constitutional negotiations and announced the Government's intention to introduce legislation to repeal
- the Land Acts of 1913 and 1936;
- the Group Areas Act of 1956;
- the Development of Black Communities Act of 1984; and
- the Population Registration Act of 1950.

3. The Committee also took particular note of the `Manifesto for the New South Africa', also published on 1 February 1991, in which the South African Government committed itself to `the creation of a free and democratic political system' in which
- all the people of South Africa `shall participate fully at all levels of Government, on the basis of universal adult franchise';
- government shall `at all times be based upon the consent of the governed';
- `all people shall be equal before the law and shall enjoy equal rights regardless of race, colour, sex or creed'; and
- `all discrimination between groups of people or between individuals shall be eliminated and discriminatory legislation shall be repealed'.

4. The Committee welcomed these latest pronouncements and commitments. They agreed that these developments were a substantial progress on the situation since their last meeting in Abuja, Nigeria, in May 1990 and that when implemented in full, and taken together with the measures introduced by the Government in February 1990, would constitute a major advance towards the ending of apartheid.
Commonwealth Response

5. In considering an appropriate response to these developments, the Committee recalled the objective of Commonwealth policy towards South Africa over the years, viz eradication of apartheid and the establishment of majority rule on the basis of free and fair exercise of universal adult suffrage by all the people in a united and nonfragmented South Africa. The Commonwealth had also consistently maintained that the forms of political settlement in South Africa were for the people of that country-all the people-to determine. In this connection the Committee noted that the Groote Schuur Meeting of May 1990 and the Pretoria Meeting the following August between the Government and the African National Congress (ANC) had led to a number of important agreements, relating to the removal of preliminary obstacles to negotiations, which agreements have now been confirmed by the announcement on 15 February of the adoption of the recommendations of the South African Government/ANC Working Group relating to the release of prisoners, the return of exiles and the suspension of the armed struggle.

6. Notwithstanding these welcome developments, Ministers noted that there had as yet been very little change on the ground and that there had been more promises than concrete action by the South African Government. The Committee expressed particular concern over continuing constraints on political freedom. In the Groote Schuur and Pretoria Minutes, the Government undertook to review security legislation, repeal its repressive provisions and present amendments in the present session of Parliament. Despite assurances that this pledge will be fulfilled, the Government continues to make massive arrests and clings to the most repressive provisions of all, detention without trial and restrictions on public meetings. The Committee stressed that due process of law and the freedoms of assembly and expression are universal human rights, and called on the Government to give effect to them without delay.
Support for Negotiations

7. The Committee gave close and extensive consideration to how the Commonwealth could best assist the reform process in all the current circumstances. At Abuja the Committee had affirmed that the Commonwealth stood ready to assist in facilitating the negotiating process and had in this context welcomed initiatives to provide assistance such as constitutional expertise and funding for research, conferences and seminars on issues and options for a postapartheid South Africa. The Committee reaffirmed this commitment, and the continuing readiness of the Commonwealth to assist the process of negotiations in any other way that might be deemed appropriate by the parties concerned.
Sanctions

8. The purpose of sanctions is to end apartheid: Commonwealth leaders have repeatedly made it clear that their purpose is not punitive but to bring the South African Government to the negotiating table and to keep it there until fundamental and irreversible change had been secured. Sanctions have been crucial in bringing about the changes which have occurred to date, and will go on being crucial if the destruction of apartheid is to be ultimately assured. Ministers' firm view, accordingly, was that it was crucial to maintain sanctions pressure through all stages of that process, up to and including the adoption of a new constitution. They also emphasised the importance of the Commonwealth remaining united and purposeful in its application of sanctions, and continuing to play a catalytic role in shaping world opinions in respect of the unfolding events in South Africa.

9. In this context, Ministers agreed that, while it was not yet time to lift sanctions, the most effective way of securing these objectives in the crucial months ahead would be for sanctions pressure to be maintained by a programmed management approach, relating any change in the application of sanctions not to mere statements of intention but to the adoption of real and practical steps in the destruction of apartheid.
10. They agreed that the elements in this programme should be as follows:

(a) All existing measures should be maintained in their present form until the obstacles to negotiation are overcome in accordance with the Pretoria Minute of 6 August 1990, and the three legislative pillars of apartheid identified in President de Klerk's speech of 1 February 1991 have been repealed as there promised, i.e. until:
- remaining political prisoners have been released;
- the way has been cleared for exiles to return home;
- repressive security legislation has been reviewed and repealed; and
- the Group Areas Act, Lands Acts, and Population Registration Act have been repealed.
When these conditions have been fulfilled, this Committee will meet again after 30 April 1991, in New Delhi to consider the appropriate response.

(b) The most important forms of pressure on the South African Government-trade and investment sanctions and, above all else, the financial sanctions, including lending by international financial institutions like the IMF-should not be modified until some further major step has been taken down the path of constitutional reform. This could take the form of the establishment of an interim government; the establishment of a constituent assembly or some other agreed constitution-making process marking the commencement of final negotiations; or any other form agreed by the multi-party conference.

(c) The arms embargo-applied by the United Nations and supported by a variety of specific Commonwealth measures-should not be lifted until such time as the new constitution is firmly in place: it is not until the new post-apartheid South Africa is firmly established with full democratic control and accountability, that the supply of arms should be countenanced by the international community.
Sporting Contacts with South Africa

11. The Committee warmly welcomed the steps taken by a number of sports organisations within South Africa. Encouraging progress has been made in several codes towards unifying sport under non-racial administration. The Committee agreed that Commonwealth support and encouragement for the unity talks must be of the highest priority, and noted the importance of assisting disadvantaged South African sports organisations, to which member governments were already providing assistance.

12. The Committee agreed that it was appropriate for those sporting codes which achieve unity to be recognised by the international community. The Committee also agreed that the Commonwealth should continue to be guided in this respect by the views of representative non-racial sporting organisations.

13. The Committee agreed that it was important that the international community-governments no less than international sports federations- respond collectively and appropriately to developments in South African sport, and in particular to the wishes of the non-racial sports movement whose work to date has been greatly aided by the sports boycott. Taking account of these developments the Committee agreed to present to the Harare Heads of Government Meeting further specific proposals by which the Commonwealth can continue to encourage non-racial sport.
Human Resource Development for a Post-Apartheid South Africa

14. The Committee welcomed the Interim Report of the Expert Group and looked forward to the Commonwealth playing as significant a role in the human resource development of a post-apartheid South Africa as it had done in the elimination of apartheid. While the full elaboration of such a programme would have to await the Committee's final report and further political evolution within South Africa, there was an urgent need to take action now if there was to be a smooth transition to the promised nonracial democracy. In this context, and with a view to preparing black South Africans to take senior jobs in government, the Committee endorsed the Expert Group's emphasis on an immediate Commonwealth programme of training and work placements in the following areas:
- central administration including judicial, economic, legal, police and security services;
- local government structures including all essential services;
- technical services including management of educational institutions, transport and communication.

15. While much of the training and work placements would need to be offered outside South Africa, the Committee agreed that, subject to the criteria laid down by the Expert Group, a beginning should also be made to support training and placements within South Africa in the interests of speed and cost-effectiveness. The training and rehabilitation of returning exiles merited particular attention.

16. In endorsing the Expert Group's Report, members of the Committee pledged assistance from their governments in the implementation of its recommendations and were confident that all Commonwealth governments would wish to join in this important endeavour. They requested the SecretaryGeneral to initiate the necessary action to get the programme going as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Government accept United Nations (UN) estimates that the Gulf war will produce between 300,000 and two million refugees; World Bank estimates that the war has already cost developing countries $30 billion; United States estimates that the cost of its own war operations will be at least $645m per day; Saudi estimates that the Gulf oil slick carries a clean-up cost of between $1 billion and $5 billion; and other estimates that the cost of rebuilding Kuwait will exceed $60 billion, a high proportion of which will be attributable to war damage? Can the Minister provide the Senate with estimates of the costs arising from the destruction of Iraq's industrial and civilian infrastructure; the hundreds of thousands of Iraqi and Kuwaiti casualties, many of them young conscripts; the oil fires; and radioactive and chemical pollution in the region from bombed Iraqi facilities?
—Where is the question?

—That was a question. Given that there is a great but unfulfilled need for humanitarian aid in many parts of the world and that the total annual flow of aid to developing countries is only $50 billion, I ask the Minister whether the Government has made any formal assessments of whether the costs of fighting the Middle East war could be justified and how they would be met before deciding to support it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question about accepting various UN numerical estimates of costs and numbers, all I can say is that I have seen all those figures but neither I nor anyone else in the Government has any way at this stage of assessing their accuracy. I make the point that the anticipated 300,000 refugees, although that was a planning figure that has been adopted by a number of agencies, has not yet proven to be anything like realised. The current estimates of refugees are of the order of 15,000 to 20,000 people only, and that is, of course, after four weeks of steadily escalating hostilities. So nothing of that order of magnitude may be realised at all. I certainly hope that that will be the case.

ANSWER.PARA: On the subject of figures, I mention that conspicuous absentees from Senator Powell's list of figures were the $50 billion that Iraq has spent on military armament purchases alone over the last 10 years and the nearly $200 billion that Iraq has spent on total defence expenditure over that period. Unless one takes into account the reality of that expenditure on that side of the ledger and the threat that that posed to everyone in the region and, indeed, the wider world then one has a very narrow and distorted view of what this issue is all about.
As to Senator Powell's second question asking whether I can provide the Senate with estimates of costs arising from the destruction-no, I cannot and I do not think anyone can at this stage.

As to the third question as to whether we made any formal assessment of whether the cost of fighting the Middle East war was justified before deciding to support it-no, we did not make any such formal assessment because we do not make decisions about war and peace, with all that that implies, on the basis of dollar and cents considerations; we make it on the basis of considerations of morality, considerations of justice and considerations of an intelligent appreciation of the consequences of not acting, all of which considerations seem to be utterly beyond the intellectual resources of the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the Opposition's prescriptions that workers return to a 40-hour week to save jobs? Can the Minister say whether, in the current situation where some employers, unions and employees have agreed to work a shorter working week to protect jobs, the Opposition's ad hoc prescriptions could obstruct the development of effective, sustainable and just labour market reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was indeed a pretty sad performance on the weekend by Mr Howard, which marked him out as a genuine yesterday's man on these matters. However, Mr Howard can claim some knowledge in talking about hours and remuneration. It cannot be said that he does not know much about the subject because he was the Treasurer in 1979-81 when hours were reduced from 40 to 38, in some cases to 37 1/2 and, in some rare cases, to 35 1/2, at a time when wages were going up, when the economy had that double digit unemployment and double digit inflation, when we had negative economic growth, when we had a higher level of industrial disputation and, generally, when things were in chaos for the reason that the Opposition had no wages policy.

ANSWER.PARA: In this context it is true to say that, since 1983, when matters of the reduction in working hours have been canvassed, we have been successful in having the Industrial Relations Commission accept that unions have to produce some trade-off which justifies a reduction in hours so that there is no overwhelming cost impost because of that. That is an aspect of the wages policy we have been able to administer through the accord. That has helped the economy considerably.

The trouble with what Mr Howard said on the weekend is that no-one believes him. No-one believes that if the work force works longer hours then there will be more work around. The truth is that, currently in some industries, workers and employers, particularly in factories, are negotiating shorter hours to protect employment. It is possible to see that, if all workers worked longer hours, that would be a recipe for redundancy and that, in the end, fewer people would be working.

The allegation that it might have an impact on unit labour costs can well and truly be countered by arguing that it would also have an impact on reducing the take- home pay of ordinary workers. Certainly, it would set back quite considerably the huge gains made in this economy by award restructuring and by getting workers in Australia under the award restructuring structural efficiency principle of the national wage case to work smarter, as they are now doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Did the Minister authorise the Department of Social Security (DSS) to contribute $45,000 towards the cost of this glossy 15-page feature in Cleo magazine, extolling the virtues of trade union membership? Can he also confirm that, apart from the promotional material being in Cleo magazine, it is also to be sent to some 500,000 female trade unionists around Australia? Has the Minister obtained advice as to the legality of the $45,000 being paid out of moneys appropriated by the Parliament for the jobs, education and training (JET) scheme, which is specifically designed to assist unemployed sole parents? Finally, will the Minister confirm that the total public sector contribution to this magnificent production of $135,000 amounts to half the total cost of the promotion? How does he justify this scandalous use of taxpayers' funds to subsidise the Government's union mates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did receive some correspondence some time back from the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions suggesting this production in Cleo as a means of advertising the Department of Social Security's wares. I referred that to my Department which thought then, and still believes now, that it was an excellent use of the Department's money. I might say that, as usual, Senator Alston is totally wrong. Not one penny came out of the JET money-not a penny. It all came from the publicity allocation of the Department-the lot. I might say that this Department spends--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the Opposition! If I were Senator Bishop, I would not advertise either. But the reality is that we have to. When one is marketing services to millions of recipients, one has to spend money doing it. One does not just hide one's light under a bushel. Accordingly, with programs which will help with the education and training of sole parents in particular, one has to look for as many ways as one can to get the message to them. Any suggestion, I might say, that a magazine like Cleo would not be exactly right for that kind of audience suggests a degree of out-of-touchness on the Opposition side which is mind-boggling.
—When did Kelty tell you to do this?

—I have never spoken to Mr Kelty about this issue. I have been very nice to Senator Walters lately-she should remember that. I repeat: as far as I am concerned, it was a very sensible investment; it gets out to an enormous audience of young women in Australia, and that is to whom it was being directed. In so far as the extra 500,000 go, the extra 500,00 was one of the conditions laid down by the Department for accepting the idea in the first place, to make sure that even more people got the message.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I presume that the Minister has not seen that Cleo magazine. He must have let his subscription lapse. I borrowed this copy, and I will lend it to him afterwards.
—I am not surprised you are reading it!
—Do you prefer the Womens Weekly?
—I will assume for present purposes that the Minister has read it.
—Order! I ask Senator Alston to ask his supplementary question.

—Will he, therefore, confirm that that is the only DSS promotional material-a one-page advertisement selling the wares of the JET program? Could the Minister indicate what the departmental research has indicated about the number of unemployed sole parents who read Cleo magazine?

—I can only repeat: the Department is absolutely of the view that this was a very good investment indeed; that the coverage it gets for its target audience is phenomenal. There is nothing wrong with Cleo magazine. I cannot claim to be a reader of it but, then again, it is not directed to me. I am glad that Senator Alston is. I am glad that he pores through its pages every day. If he does so, he would have found out, I would hope, that it is a magazine directed to the very audience that JET is after. So not only have we done it once-if we can get a chance to do it again at those prices and rates, we will do it again.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Now that it is more than a month since the attack on Iraq began, in view of the hopeful signs that President Hussein might be willing to withdraw from Kuwait, and in recognition of the possibility that a month of killing and suffering has been enough, will Australia please suggest to its partners that there be a pause in the attack-a halt for a few days, or perhaps a week-as a sign of good faith and reasonableness on the part of the coalition? This could hardy be seen as a sign of weakness. Would this not provide a chance for exploring for peace and the demanded withdrawal, by following up the Soviet and Iranian dialogue, perhaps by the United Nations Secretary-General? Will the Government please consider such an initiative? I believe that it would be very welcome.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I am unable to accede to Senator Coates's suggestion. I say at the outset that I certainly share what I understand to be his hope that the action taken so far, with all its enormously regrettable but nonetheless inevitable consequences in terms of human suffering, would have been enough to persuade the Iraqi authorities that they should comply with the clearly stated will of the international community and get out of Kuwait. But I do not agree that Saddam Hussein has yet given any sign of genuine willingness to withdraw from Kuwait. There has been some speculation that the Iraqi statement of 15 February might have been intended to be such a sign, but it is hard to pursue such a line of speculation very seriously when one looks at the extraordinarily heavily-conditioned and equivocal nature of the statement.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from all the linkages and conditions that it contained, which I shall mention in a moment, there was no undertaking to accept or comply with United Nations Security Council resolution 660, only to `deal with' that resolution. While there was a reference to withdrawal, there was no specific mention of Kuwait in that context at all. There is a difficulty about even accepting what seemed to be the most central and unequivocal part of the statement. It is much more difficult to take the statement seriously when one looks at the list of conditions which were associated with it. Those conditions include: first of all, abolition or abrogation of all other United Nations Security Council resolutions on the crisis, suggesting in that respect that Iraq should bear no responsibility whatever for the devastation and other costs associated with its aggression against Kuwait. Secondly, there is a condition of complete withdrawal of all coalition troops within one month of the cease-fire, unaccompanied by any reference to any timetable for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. There was very explicit linkage with an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories, or Palestine as it is referred to in the statement.

There is a demand for a guarantee of Iraq's historical rights on land and sea, which suggests some implicit acknowledgment of Iraq's claims over Kuwait. It is clearly very problematical in that respect. There is a requirement of a reconstruction of Iraq, without Iraq incurring any expense whatsoever of its own in that reconstruction; and there is a requirement about the cancellation of the foreign debts of Iraq and other regional countries, creating a situation where Iraq is demanding to be rewarded for its invasion, a patently unacceptable outcome. In short, if Iraq wants to send a signal to the international community, it will have to be very much clearer, very much less equivocal than this, and absolutely unconditional in its acceptance of United Nations Security Council resolution 660 and the subsequent resolutions.

It flows from what I have said that Australia will not be suggesting to other coalition members that there should be any pause in the military efforts to achieve Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. There simply is no basis for suspending the military action authorised by resolution 678 and, as the Prime Minister said over the weekend, to take the pressure off Iraq at this time in response to such a manifestly unacceptable proposition would give Saddam Hussein a chance to regroup and rebuild. The Australian Government hopes that the current diplomatic activities, including in particular those in Moscow, might yet lead to a positive sign of Iraq's preparedness to withdraw immediately and unconditionally from Kuwait. Certainly we remain confident that if and when such advice is received from Iraq, the coalition will respond appropriately.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS REPORT ON STATE OF CHILDREN

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate of the significance of The State of the World's Children 1991 report produced by the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and launched in Australia by his colleague Dr Blewett last Thursday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Childs for his question. I know that Senator Childs, as President of the parliamentary committee for UNICEF, is a very keen supporter of the United Nations Children's Fund and the work it is doing for the welfare of millions of mothers and children throughout the developing world. My colleague Dr Blewett did last week, as Senator Childs said, launch in Australia UNICEF's report The State of the World's Children 1991. As Dr Blewett observed, this report is internationally recognised as the most authoritative annual statement on the situation of children throughout the world. It does document the challenge faced by the international community in protecting the world's needy children and describes UNICEF's successes and achievements.

ANSWER.PARA: The task is immense. This year 14 million children will die from easily preventable causes-diseases, such as measles and whooping cough, which we in the developed countries have almost completely forgotten. The report focuses attention on the continuing and ongoing tragedy of sick and poor children, a problem for which there is simply no quick solution. With immediate and more sensational world crises constantly pressing upon us, it is crucial that the plight of children not be forgotten. The task of reducing the tragedy of 40,000 child deaths every day-that is what it amounts to-does fall to us: all individuals, non-government organisations and governments. That is one of the successful thrusts of the UNICEF report.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of the UNICEF programs. We presently direct over $11m per annum to UNICEF and its field programs and more than that in support of women and children through other parts of the aid program. As tangible support for UNICEF efforts in child health, I had the pleasure in New York last year of passing to UNICEF the rights to a new and very innovative solar powered weighing scale invented by an Australian-a gift worth something over $1m. That hand-over followed Australia's participation in the World Summit for Children. Australia endorsed the declaration that emerged from that about the survival, protection and development of children.

Finally, the report that was released last week in Australia includes details of this international declaration and the plan of action to achieve a reduction in child mortality and an improvement in children's welfare. Obviously, Australia will do its part in every way it can in helping to achieve these objectives.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is an important decision, though I understand that the Tobacco Institute has indicated that it will appeal the decision and, therefore, I do not want to go into every detail of it. TALK.START.PARA: —On the last day of sitting Senator Short asked me about delays in the answer to a question directed to me as Minister representing the Treasurer. Largely, that question related to the Financial Corporations Act and certain procedures taken under that Act. I undertook to provide an answer by today. It is in answer to a question on notice. In the circumstances I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
1. Part III of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 gives the Reserve Bank the power to collect statistics from corporations subject to the Act.

(a) The information collected under the Financial Corporations (Statistics) Regulations dated 18 May 1984 varies for the different categories of corporations. For building societies it includes aggregated statistics on lending and borrowing, selected liabilities, assets, interest rates and selected maturity dissection of borrowings.
(b) The Act requires that statistics prepared by corporations under Part III be verified by a statutory declaration made by a senior officer of the corporations.

(c) The Act relates to financial corporations which engage in the borrowing and lending of money in a major way and whose assets exceed $1 million. Certain classes of corporations are exempt from the legislation, including public authorities, authorised banks, terminating building societies, friendly or benefit societies, medical benefits organisations, life and general insurance companies and trustee companies.

2 &3. My Department is not informed about the liquidity or viability of financial corporations as a matter of course. There is, however, a close working relationship between the Treasury and the Reserve Bank and the Bank keeps it informed of developments relevant to the stability of the financial system. Moreover, the Secretary to the Treasury, as a member of the Reserve Bank Board, receives such information as is provided to other Board members arising from the Bank's surveillance of the financial system.

4. I am informed that the Reserve Board receives regular reports on developments affecting the bank and non-bank sectors of the finance industry, and that the information relates to the operations of industry sectors, groups of organisations in a single group and individual entities.
5. (a) Yes;
(b) (c) Yes;
(d) Yes, but from a corporation entitled Countrywide Building Society.
(e) Yes, but from a corporation entitled Commercial Credit Cooperative Limited.
(f) Yes, but predominantly building societies in the Group (there are other financial intermediaries).

6. I am informed that the Reserve Bank had some discussions about the operations of the Farrow Group with the responsible State authorities. (See responses to parts 9 and 10). These discussions arose from concerns evident in sections of the market.

7. The Governor of the Reserve Bank regularly discusses economic and financial developments with the Treasurer. These discussions may include problems in particular parts of the financial system if the Governor believes that to be appropriate.
8. The Governor and I discuss the state of the economy on a regular basis and we talk face to face or by telephone whenever particular matters warrant it.

9. The Bank has told me that it had been generally aware for some time that the Farrow Group of building societies was exposed to a higherthan-normal operating risk because of its high rate of growth, its exposures to the commercial property sector, and its interest rate policy. Such information as was available to the Reserve Bank, however, was not an adequate basis on which to make considered judgements about the societies' viability.

10, 11, 12. I did not know of the financial difficulties of the Farrow Group of building societies prior to the release of a statement by the Victorian Treasurer on 13 February 1990 concerning Pyramid Building Society.

The only advice received by my office prior to 13 February 1990 was a minute dated 12 February which referred to an article on Pyramid that had appeared in the Sunday Herald on 11 February which stated that there had been small net withdrawals from the Society.
That advice could not be considered knowledge of Pyramid's difficulties. In the event the minute was not drawn to my attention as it was not considered such a serious issue at the time.
13. The Reserve Bank has informed me that it had discussions with Victorian Government officials on a number of occasions:

* On 12 and 13 February 1990-talks initiated by Victorian Office of Management and Budget in relation to its concerns about the risk of a run on Pyramid Building Society and its inquiry about the RBA's policy on liquidity support for building societies.
* On 15 and 20 February 1990-talks with Victorian Registrar of Co-operative Financial Institutions, initiated by RBA, to inquire about Farrow's efforts to arrange additional lines of support.
* On 21 February 1990-talks initiated by Victorian Office of Management and Budget to mention Farrow's liquidity difficulties and problems of securing support from banks.

14. I understand the Farrow Group had discussions with various financial institutions about possible lines of credit. The Reserve Bank has told me it was not party to any such discussions but it made known to banks and to the Victorian Government its longstanding and on-going policy of willingness to provide necessary liquidity support to banks which choose to lend to well-managed and viable non-bank financial institutions.
15. Not applicable; as indicated in the response to part 14, the Reserve Bank did not give its support to the provision of a line of credit to the Farrow Group.

16. The Reserve Bank informs me it did not meet with the Victorian Government in late March or early April 1990. There, however, were numerous discussions between various representatives of the Bank and the Victorian Government during the period from February to June 1990. These were primarily to keep the Bank informed of events as they developed; the Bank did not offer the advice mentioned in the question. I did not participate in any of the Reserve Bank's discussions.
17. Not applicable (refer to the response to part 16).

18. The Reserve Bank has informed me it did not receive a copy of an audit report by Day, Neilson, Jenkins and Johns; it did receive a copy of Price Waterhouse's summary of its review of the Farrow Corporation Limited group.
19. The question is based on an incorrect premise. The Reserve Bank did not see the first document referred to. It neither accepted nor rejected the latter.

20. The Reserve Bank does not have the power to intervene in the operations or management of non-bank financial institutions. Its longstanding policy is not to provide financial support to financial institutions it does not supervise.

21. I am informed that Farrow Corporation did not make application to become a bank. However, in January 1990, Farrow Corporation indicated to the Reserve Bank an intention to seek a banking licence in the medium term (3-5 years) if certain State legislative restrictions on its activities were not removed. The Bank offered no advice on its equity level, accounts or management arrangements. On 11 May 1990, an officer of Farrow Corporation arranged for Mr Farrow to meet with the Chief of Financial System Division of the Bank on 24 May, purportedly to discuss the possibility of a banking authority. The appointment was cancelled by Mr Farrow on 23 May.

22. I have regular discussions about economic and financial developments with both the Reserve Bank Governor and the Secretary to the Treasury. There have however been no particular discussions concerning the state of Victorian building societies.
23. I receive many requests for meetings during the course of a year, but there is no record of any such contact with the Farrow Corporation in 1990.

In the Weekend Australian last Saturday, 16 February, there is an article by Mr Greg Sheridan about my Senate speech on 12 February, in which I urged the normalisation of Australia-China relations.
