DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES AND CHARGES COLLECTION BILL 1990PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES AND CHARGES COLLECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1990NATIONAL CATTLE DISEASE ERADICATION TRUST ACCOUNT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 December, on motion by Senator Cook:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill 1990, and the complementary Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1990 and the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account Bill 1990, is to enable the Government to provide a framework for a more efficient way in which to collect the levies that are imposed on the commodities produced by the agricultural industry. The majority of these levies are made through the rural industry research funds. They work on the basis of a dollar for dollar payment by the government and industry, up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. In total, it means that the primary industry sector provides a very substantial amount for research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons why agriculture is one of the few world competitive or efficient industries in this country is that it provides a significant contribution on its own behalf to ensure that it is productive, efficient and the other things that are necessary to be successful in the international market.

The legislation will provide a single Act which will deal with all the levy and export charge collections. This will enable uniformity of collection methods and will permit a consistent approach to procedural matters previously embodied in more than 30 Acts. The Bills will give greater flexibility so that a whole range of different collection agencies and methods of collection can be used and a greater flexibility and efficiency are obtained.

Most of the levies and charges are payable by the producer or grower of produce. In order to reduce the cost of collection, the legislation provides for a better securing of payment of levy or charges, and moneys may be collected through intermediaries such as agents or exporters on behalf of producers. In addition, the Commonwealth may now enter into collection arrangements with the States, Territories and other collection organisations, subject to full consultation with industry groups. These arrangements will assist in meeting the goal to keep costs to a minimum by reducing the number of collection points.

One of the most significant of these will be the export inspection levy. Approximately $172m is to be levied this financial year. The Government made a decision in the Federal Budget to increase the cost recovery of those charges from 60 per cent to 100 per cent. The charges apply mainly to meat, but also to grain, horticulture and the dairy industry.

I should point out that in terms of cost recovery the Government could not have picked a worse time for trying to implement charges on the rural sector. The governments of most of our competitor countries pay the total amount of the inspection charge, either for public health or for export assistance reasons. The levy comes at a time of dramatically reduced, and reducing income for farmers in the cutthroat world of export competition. One only has to get out into the rural and regional parts of Australia to see how badly Australia's primary industries are faring under the present Labor Government's induced recession.

It is hard for me not to add a touch of Northern Territory flavour in this debate. By 1992 the objectives under the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign (BTEC) will be achieved, opening export markets in South East Asia which the Northern Territory cattle industry is unable to supply in terms of the demands to markets in Asia. In 1992, with primary producers restocking cattle stations the Northern Territory is set aggressively to take on markets in the Asian region. The research and development through BTEC has meant that the Northern Territory cattle industry will certainly have increased potential in future years.

Briefly, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Consequential Provisions) Bill, which is linked to the Bill I have already addressed, amends the current Acts which impose levies and charges because these will not be empowered through the new Bill. The purpose of the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account Bill is simply to provide for the continued existence of the national cattle disease eradiation trust account as a result of the former Livestock Slaughter Levy Collection Act being repealed through the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Consequential Provisions) Bill which was presented earlier. The trust account facilitates the financial operations of the national program for cattle disease eradication.

I have noted many comments in the media and generally in recent days, and in particular by the Opposition spokesman on primary industry, Mr Lloyd, that the recent Australian Agricultural Outlook Conference in Canberra gave a very dismal and dreary forecast for the rural sector of Australia. There are certainly predictions floating around that the rural area is going through a disastrous period and that in particular wool and wheat are being affected the most. It is expected that there will be a tragic drop in farm incomes this financial year. In fact, at the Outlook Conference it was interesting to note the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics December review forecast that the reduction this year would probably amount to a figure of 68 per cent.

It does not matter what basis we use for looking at these figures. Anybody in this place who has any connection with the rural constituency would know that all broad-acre farmers will probably be facing situations where the average income for each family labour unit will be about $5,500 this year. Yet many of these people have millions of dollars invested in the assets of their land and their years and years of activity. It is certainly a dismal and dreadful time to reflect on.

The abysmal record of the Labor Government in reducing input costs is one that needs to be very seriously addressed. Our labour market, the waterfront, transport systems, coastal shipping and taxes are too costly for exporters and for those who are competing against imports.

I have also noted the comments of the National Farmers Federation and, in particular, a series of studies that was prepared for the NFF in December 1990. A very detailed study was carried out by consultants on behalf of the NFF, looking at the flaws in government industry assistance at the present time and looking at the Industry Commission's methodology in determining levels of industry assistance, which has been and is seriously flawed. The Director of Policy of the NFF, Mr Garry Goucher, in releasing the internal NFF report, said that recognising the flaws within the Industry Commission's methodology would have a major impact on future programs of micro-economic reform. He stated:

In essence, the Commission has failed to recognise that agricultural industries are being penalised by inefficiencies in other sectors in the economy, particularly in the transport, irrigation, financial services and electricity industries.

The rate of assistance, or the aggregate effect of Government intervention, in industries such as sugar, rice, dairy and dried fruits, is much lower than is indicated by the Commission's current methodology.
Inefficiencies in key support services have resulted in major cost burdens on our efficient export industries, yet, the Commission has ignored their impact.
NFF is calling on the Industry Commission to change the methodology it uses when calculating effective rates of industry assistance so that all industries are treated equally.

In reviewing the legislation before us today, I note that the Opposition supports the legislation; however, I stress that it is time that the Labour Government woke up to its responsibilities and supported the industries that have contributed to Australia's international trade to keep this country on its feet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Australian Democrats will not be opposing the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill 1990, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1990 and the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account Bill 1990, mainly because we understand they have support from both the industry and the Opposition, we think that in some way that support could be described as somewhat misguided. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech made mention of the fact that the Commonwealth now recovers all costs of collection. This package of Bills adds to the process by which the costs of collection, as well as the levies which are collected, are increasingly being borne, as Senator Tambling has mentioned, by the producers.

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of user pays is one which sounds simple, but it is very hard to come to grips with in these industries. We have the question: who are the users of these services provided as a result of these levies and charges? Are the users the producers? Are they the consumers? Are they the traders in the commodities which are produced in primary industries? Then there is the question of who actually does pay. On the surface it is the producers who seem to pay.

Of course, we should ask where the money comes from. The only place it can eventually come from is the consumers. Then we have the question of who benefits. Our first reaction is to say that the consumers benefit, but, obviously, the producers benefit from research, health inspections and improved products. Also, the community as a whole benefits from assurances that we are then able to give about public health matters, the eradication of diseases and the research which leads to better industry practices and better products.

It is apparent that the whole community benefits from what is done with these levies and charges. Therefore, in the Australian Democrats opinion, it is a truism of the whole country that the Government should be contributing, and contributing more than is presently contributed. It is not a burden which is borne by a single sector of the community.

This Government seems keen to allow burdens to accrue to our primary producers. There is a consistent policy being applied throughout the rural sector-the policy of removal of government assistance and support and the imposition of government charges, fees and taxes in such a way that exemptions or variations are difficult to obtain. This policy is often mistakenly described as deregulation, a level playing field, free trade or some such other euphemism. We reject that notion. Our competitors in primary industries throughout the world are assisted by their governments. They have comparative advantages, or disadvantages, and they are levelled by taxation, policies or subsidies by our competitors. They are competitors who have devised methods of looking after their rural producers, so our nation will be disadvantaged terribly unless we match them.

It is stupidity, even arrogant stupidity, to suggest that we should lead the way in shedding our support systems. If the rest of the world follows, that might be sort of all right. But, even if some of the rest of the world does not follow us, then we are sunk and that is where we are going right now. In this regard I agree with an observation made by the honourable member for Maranoa, Mr Scott, who said in another place that right now is the wrong time to be doing this. He said:
I believe we should be encouraging rather than discouraging by levies and taxes.

He meant encouraging primary industry. Of course, when levies and charges are applied there is a responsibility to use those charges for the benefit of the industry from which they are collected. I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that one particular use to which such funds could be put is the control of the `disease' of foreign owned feedlots. Surely the fact that 2,683 cattle recently died from heat stress at the Whyalla feedlot, operated near Texas in Queensland by Nippon Ham Ltd, is important enough to move us to agree with the Queensland Government in its request for some national guidelines to be formulated, and quickly, for the operation of such feedlots. That is the sort of issue which needs national action for the benefit of our primary industries.

I only hope that such national action is helped and not hindered by the passage of these Bills which I must grudgingly admit are a worthwhile attempt to rationalise and make more efficient the collection of those charges and fees which are collected. Nevertheless, we will not be voting against this legislation; we will be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words on the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill 1990, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1990 and the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account Bill 1990 on the resumption of the second reading debate. There are a few points that I will make. First, it is rather indecent that we are debating in the Senate today a Bill on levies and charges on primary industry when, at the same time, the end of the floor price scheme is being announced in the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: Primary industry is in a great deal of stress and crisis at the moment. The wool industry has collapsed and with it will go many hundreds, if not thousands, of growers when this change is brought into place in the wool industry. Of course, we have also got to think that the grain growing industry is not in any better shape than the wool industry. Rural service industries are closing down and banks are pressing payments of outstanding debts, yet this Government is making no apologies for what it has done to all Australians but most especially to rural Australia.

This Bill claims to make more efficient the collection of various charges and it brings together 30 Acts to bring about this efficiency. It includes the export inspection charges. The meat and inspection system in this country is an absolute rort. As Mr Lloyd, the shadow Minister for primary industries said in the other place, `It has a lot to answer for'. There has been featherbedding, with inspectors living in towns in which there are no abattoirs but having to be paid in any case for doing no work. I know that representation has been made about that to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to try to fix up what seems to be an absolute anomaly. I understand that there are some 70 meat inspectors in New South Wales who do not actually do any work basically, except turn up occasionally at an abattoir to say that they are still on the payroll.

At other abattoirs there is pressure for a 68 per cent increase in wages and increased staff levels when there is no ample evidence that there ought to be any further inspectors. In fact, in most cases I believe there should be a lot fewer inspectors. They are claiming that even though they are not especially highly trained, they want something like $64,000 or $65,000 per year for the job of meat inspecting. It is very important to inspect our meat, of course, but we want productivity. We want the meat inspection part of our industry to be highly efficient, to be productive and to make sure that it does not put imposts onto our export industries that we do not need. We have also the Government vets in abattoirs who want $93,000 for a five-day week, but if one really looks at the job they have to do, one finds that it is not all that difficult.

We have also the grain inspectors who want $86 an hour. That is not a bad wage-maybe it is an ambit claim-but here again it is obviously another cost on the rural industry. How can any industry, much less rural industry, afford to pay costs and charges like that? The Federal Government has said that rural industry should meet its own costs, and it is prepared to do that. But what industry can afford rates like the rates that I have just mentioned?

What is the Government doing about it? It talks about workplace reform but does nothing. In the meantime, rural industries are going down the gurgler all over the place. Farmers are resilient though. I am a farmer myself-and I just noticed that Senator Panizza has come into the chamber and he is a farmer-and he and I know that, no matter how resilient the farming community is in the future, it is nearly at the end of its tether at present. When good young people on the land are being pushed to the brink of economic insolvency, when other people in the industry-for example, the inspectors whom I have just talked about-are claiming that they want more wages and when the people who are working their guts out on the farms see these other people getting higher salaries, it is a big worry for the future of rural industry.

What is killing rural industries, and will eventually kill them completely, is the continual mismanagement of the Australian economy. There has been mismanagement in terms of high interest rates. Last week we heard about inflation rates. Look what inflation has done. Look at how it compares with the rates of our competitors around the world. There has been a quarterly increase of some 2.7 per cent, which is absolutely astronomical. We have a dollar rate which is too high to enable our Australian farmers to compete around the world. We have had eight years now of the Hawke Labor Government and it is time that a little bit of notice was taken of the problems out in the rural communities.

We have towns, villages and, indeed, country cities that are under a great deal of stress at the moment because of what is happening in rural communities. High interest rates have permeated right through the system. High input costs to the farms are now there to stay. Those costs have been basically bolstered by high interest rates. In fact, high interest rates have stayed with us too long. They may have been used to dampen the economy but they have been imposed for too long and have now permeated all country areas. I am afraid they are going to sound the death knell for a lot of people.

Labour costs are up because of the high cost of capital and as a result of high interest rates and economic mismanagement. That ends up meaning one less employee or one less shop in country towns. If one walks around some of the country towns now one does not even see `For Sale' signs up because nobody wants to buy the shops which are closing down as a result of being screwed to the wall by this high interest rate regime that has been with us for the last few years. When we get to the stage of one less village or one less town, maybe a little bit of notice will be taken. In fact, it is time that the Government woke up.

We support this legislation. It is a change that I presume and hope will bring about the economies that it says it will. I say to the government of the day here in the federal capital that if rural Australia goes to the wall, all Australia goes to the wall. The standard of living of all Australians will be adversely and severely affected if this Government does not wake up very soon to things like labour market reform. We need to have productivity and competence. People need to do a fair day's work for a fair day's pay. All Australians will need to put their shoulders to the wheel to make sure that we get out of the economic mess that we have been led into in the last eight years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill 1990, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1990 and the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account Bill 1990 I would like to bring out a number of points which are of concern. I will do so even though the Opposition supports the legislation. I certainly support most of the principles behind the Bills. But at this time one must, as previous speakers have done, comment on the difficult situation that many people in rural industries now find themselves in. I refer here not only to the producers but also to country businesses and supporting industries that extend to the cities. In particular I want to raise the change of direction of the Government's position in terms of the sharing of responsibilities for paying levies.

SPEECH.PARA: One can support the user pays principle and it is important that all those who benefit from certain actions-I particularly refer to meat inspection levies-should share the cost. Currently, the responsibility for all costs ultimately falls back onto the producer. These costs should be passed down the price chain. It is important to note that producers are price takers, not price makers. There are two groups particularly in the community who will benefit from changes which are being made at the expense of primary producers-firstly, consumers and, secondly, the exporters.

Another important point that needs to be made in terms of our export industries and charges, the meeting of Department of Primary Industries and Energy standards and the requirements of our international customers, is that there is also a national benefit. As such, I believe it is fair that there should be a national contribution. In terms of the user pays concept, we have now reached the stage where the user is subsidising others in the community to pay for something that is of national benefit.

I want to draw attention to a couple of clauses in the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill which cause me some concern. Clause 18 deals with the overpayments which are not the mistake of the producer from whom they are collected. While there is provision for repayment of the monies that have been overpaid, there is no provision in terms of the costs incurred by that producer, nor is there any provision as far as lost interest is concerned. I believe that is an anomaly in the Bill that needs addressing.
I turn to clause 12(1) which I find a total contradiction; indeed, I believe it goes beyond fair and reasonable play. Under the heading `Industry consultation', clause 12(1) states:

12. (1) Before entering into an agreement under subsection 10 (1) . . . the Secretary is to consult with any industry body that is representative of producers of collection products, or intermediaries in relation to producers of collection products, who have an interest in relation to the proposed agreement.
Subclause (2) states:
(2) A failure to comply with subsection (1) does not invalidate the agreement.

If that is the situation which exists, one must ask the question: why have it there in the first place? It seems to me that if the direction is in subsection (2), there should be a requirement that that consultation does take place. If this Bill is to work how we want it to work from an industry point of view, it is important that consultation is made a requirement of the legislation.

I now move to the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account Bill. I wish to highlight two points in particular. In the past, the collection has primarily been made to counter the problems encountered in respect of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign (BTEC). This Bill proposes to use the moneys collected also on other diseases. From what I can ascertain, there has been no consultation with industry in terms of the expansion proposed by this Bill. One asks why at this time it is proposed to expand the types of diseases for which the levy is being collected. As I understand it, the BTEC levy was put in place for a specific purpose. We believed that when those diseases had been eradicated, the levy would not continue to be collected. I believe that there are some serious questions that need to be asked about the methodology in terms of that.

This leads me to my next point on this matter. I think that there will be some $23m in the fund by December 1992. This figure will increase beyond that, naturally, with the collection of additional levies. I ask: what is the safety net for that fund remaining where it is? I raise this as I am concerned with what has occurred in New South Wales, which I hope will not become a forerunner for other industry-collected levies. In this particular case, it was the pig industry. At the end of that research activity, the surplus of the fund was taken into Consolidated Revenue. It seems to me that there needs to be some safeguards for the collection of these levies. When they reach a certain time and their task is finished, they cannot be picked up and taken into Consolidated Revenue. I would like a commitment from the Government that it is not its intention to do that because, as I have said, that precedent has already been established in New South Wales.

In moving away from the specifics of this Bill, I would like to highlight some of the points that have been raised. Some of the previous speakers have made this point relative to the industry and inspection charges, et cetera. I do this not in the context of the blow-out or the excessive costs that I believe exist in many of these inspection charges and the way they are handled, but in the context of what is currently occurring in the meat industry in Australia and the disputation that has continued, particularly in Victoria and to a lesser extent in other States, with the absolute defiance of `the umpire'-to quote Senator Cook's favourite words-the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). I will refer to that in a moment.

Let us look at some of the costs involved. The charge for a meat inspector for a five-day week is $64,686 per year, and the charge for a veterinarian is $92,428. I believe that it is time we looked very seriously at privatising some of these operations and putting them on a contract basis. I am sure that we could introduce much cheaper costs, which would assist us in becoming international competitors and we would become more efficient.

In the United States the cost of processing beef is 10c per kilogram, yet in Australia it is 45c per kilogram. These costs are affecting our industries, particularly our export industries. We find ourselves with costs and charges that are three, four, or five times higher than those of our international competitors.

Regarding the movement towards the user pays concept, which I have talked about before, there needs to be much greater accountability in terms of the efficiency and performance of the people who are given these particular tasks. I will give an example of a meat inspector in an abattoir in Victoria recently: the role of one of the people there-we are paying him through grower levies which were applied-consisted of being at the freezer works, or the storage facilities, in the morning to open the doors. He then filled in his whole day waiting for the evening so that he could shut and lock them again. In between he effectively did nothing at all. This type of inefficiency exists in the industry. At least some of the levies that are talked about in these Bills go towards paying for these types of operations. There must be a better and much more efficient way.

I will just run through a few points on the meat industry. On a number of occasions in this place before I have outlined some of the wastage that has occurred because of the industrial disputation in the meat industry. I do not intend to go over these figures again, but I will draw the attention of the Senate to a number of things which have occurred in recent times. I refer to a statement of 3 December by the Full Bench of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which reads as follows:

The industrial action in the meat industry has been in breach of ACTU/AMIEU assurances given to the Commission in the meat industry inquiries proceedings and has been in breach of the AMIEU no-extra claims commitment.

Approximately one week later, the Deputy President, Joe Riordan, gave a direction to the AMIEU that it should desist from further industrial action while this matter was before the Industrial Relations Commission and while the Harrison inquiry was proceeding. I have the document here. We find the signature of Bill Kelty with the explanatory notes alongside it-in fact supporting and urging others to support the AMIEU and to defy the direction of the Deputy Commissioner, Mr Riordan. In the situation that exists in the meat industry now the ACTU is held up high by people on the other side of the chamber as being the great reasoner, the upholder of a sane, sensible industrial relations system in this country which believes in fair play. This situation actually defies the current position. I get rather emotional about this because this industry has the capacity to make a wonderful and very important contribution to the welfare of this country and will enable us to export and overcome some of our problems.

I would like to see the Government start to get serious about its continual references to upholding the umpire's decision. That is fine, but when only one side obeys the umpire, it is time that the whole system was looked at. Quite clearly, the system that exists with the meat industry at present has failed.
The Bills before us today will impose costs, for the benefit of the industry, back on producers. Much of that money is going down the drain through sheer industrial lawlessness.

In conclusion, I have commented on what I see as some of the anomalies in these Bills, which are being debated cognately. I would like to hear the Government's view on the points I have made, particularly in relation to consultation with the industry. Unless these anomalies are corrected, these Bills will have to come before us again as they will not be worth the paper they are written on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to address briefly the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill 1990 and add my support to the points made by my colleagues Senator Brownhill and Senator Crane. I understand that this Bill brings together 30 Acts by which inspection and research levies were previously collected. This will mean that we will not need to deal with 30 amendment Bills coming into the Senate over the next year or so in different ways and means. I believe it was a good idea to bring all these pieces of legislation together and, as pointed out by the two previous speakers, our side of politics will certainly support it.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1988 the Department of Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) commenced charging for collecting inspection fees. I am not exactly sure what the Department is charging for the collection of these fees, but I hope that it is no more than the 2.5 per cent charged to unions by the Department of Finance for collecting their membership fees from weekly pay packets.

The biggest collection under this Bill is about $172m, which comes from the meat inspection fee. Madam Acting Deputy President, you may recall that the upsurge in more efficient inspection of export meat was caused by the fiasco that occurred in Australia about three or four years ago, which was caused by the excessive use of certain pesticides, now banned, which were detected in meat sent to the United States of America.

The Government has by steps increased what it collects for inspection charges. At one time it was a 50 per cent charge, but it has gradually been increased and now lies at 100 per cent. But I ask: 100 per cent of what? It does not seem to be 100 per cent of the actual work being done. It seems to be 100 per cent of what is done, of the training of those meat inspectors, of the vehicles they drive-and probably drive for other purposes, including private purposes a lot of the time-and of all the infrastructure and site resources which go into putting those people into employment with the DPIE. We are being charged 100 per cent and that fee is ever rising.

The two previous speakers pointed out a few figures. For example, a meat inspector is on a salary of $64,846. I do not want to decry the job of a meat inspector, but I do not think that figure is quite commensurate with the standard of education needed to be a meat inspector. A meat inspector can qualify with 12 months part time TAFE study, and I understand that has not changed in the past few years. The salary paid to meat inspectors is certainly higher than the salaries paid to anyone on this side of the chamber in a year. Ministers get more than that figure, but it certainly puts meat inspectors on a higher salary than the members on this side of the chamber and meat inspectors work only five days a week from, I believe, 7.30 a.m. to 3.30 p.m. Therefore, I think they are slightly overpaid.

Veterinarians, who are far more highly educated and who are working in a far more competitive environment, are paid an average of $92,428 for a five-day week working those same hours. Although veterinarians working in normal practices around Australia are highly educated, I am afraid that is not a figure for running their own businesses and meeting their own upkeep and business costs; it is a figure I know that the average veterinarian does not get. I have a few friends who are in that profession; I know of one particular veterinarian who used to be a lecturer at the School of Veterinary Science at Murdoch University in Western Australia and I can assure honourable senators that she is on half that figure and probably works twice as long. Of course, she has the added burden and work of teaching young students and seeing them successfully through university. So I consider that, for the hours meat inspectors work in abattoirs and wherever else they do their inspections, they could be slightly overpaid. Their salary, for example, puts them virtually into the category of the pay of a Minister. I do not see Senator Tate disagreeing with my assumption, so we will presume that a Minister's pay is around that level. I believe the industry is overloaded with costs with which it should not have to contend.

As a result of the sorts of figures which we, the industries, are bound to pay-I say `we' because I am in all those sorts of industries; that is, cattle, sheep and wheat- we have been put beyond the scope of competing with overseas trading partners. It has been mentioned time and time again in this chamber that it costs $13 a head to put sheep on the hook in Australia, whereas in America it can be done for $5 a head. That is why one cannot give sheep away. It is all very well to say, `Shoot the sheep and give them to the poor', but someone has to find that $13 to put the sheep onto the hook. Of course, from the hook the sheep have to be moved down the line to where the poor people can get them. We cannot do anything other than find that money or carry on with the situation as it is.

There has been talk of putting these sheep into cans and shipping them to Third World countries. Another great idea! Even if one gave them away, it would cost about $19 to put a sheep in a can-one would not put one sheep in one can; one would put pieces of it in one can. In Australia that is beyond us. It costs nearly $120 to put cattle on the hook, whereas in America it can be done for about $40. We have to get the cost down if the industries here are to survive.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure you spoke on the cattle transaction levy Bill when it went through this chamber a few months ago. I certainly spoke quite strongly on that legislation. Honourable senators may remember that the Bill removed the onus for paying a slaughter levy from the processors at an abattoir back to the owner and spread it around so that a certain amount stayed with the processor but the bulk went back to the producer of the animals, and so forth. It was also extended to every cattle transaction, whether to the processor or from farm to farm or station to station.

With the processor having been relieved of at least $8, or thereabouts, on one head of cattle in the processing, one would have expected, when the time came to change over from the old to the new system-which I understood was two weeks ago-that that would be reflected in the market at auctions. I have made some contacts with the selling centre in Goulburn in New South Wales-I think another one is at Dubbo; certainly I have contacted Midland Junction in Western Australia-and I have found that there was not an ounce of movement upwards; there is certainly an ounce of movement downwards but there was no movement upwards. I expected that on cattle one would get at least $8 extra because it was removed from the processor to the producer, but that money was not there. We can put this legislation through Parliament on that basis; one can say, `Okay, we are moving the onus of paying for a certain transaction from the processors to the producers but they should be recompensed'. The producer will get the heavier load; the processor has not done his job by paying the extra which he reckoned he was saddled with in the first place and which should therefore belong to the producer. I just use that as an example of how all the imposts in primary industry finish up with the producer.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do. It is a weight on our backs that we can't take any longer.

—I acknowledge that interjection. Primary producers can no longer keep taking more and more imposts. I believe that most people know what the situation in the bush is, but in case all members of the Senate have not finally realised it, I will give them a brief rundown. I have been right around the southern half of Western Australia since 1 January to see how primary producers are faring. I also attended all the rural crisis meetings in Western Australia in November and December.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1 January it has got through to the people exactly what the price of wheat will be in the bank to the primary producer. It is about $50 a tonne less than last year. In Western Australia the average going into the farmer's bank would be around the $70 mark, depending on the freight component. Added to this, we have the total collapse of the wool market, and even the suspension of that market that we have had for three weeks to enable us to iron out a system that was allowed to go wrong-caused to go wrong to a great extent-by the Wool Corporation of Australia, assisted by the Australian Wool Council and aided and abetted by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin).

I did not criticise the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on that matter at least, virtually until the last couple of weeks. Just prior to Christmas he gave a guarantee to wool buyers around the world, including Japan and Italy, that the price of 700c per kilo was ironclad for the next two years. I do not quite know why he went on such a mission telling them that. It was probably to get the wool moving, but it has certainly backfired. I hope that he did not know that it would backfire as badly as it has since then.

The woolgrowing industry having been led into such a position by the Corporation, aided and abetted by the Minister, I would have thought that the Government would have come up with some scheme to isolate the stockpile under certain conditions. That has not quite been forthcoming. A Bill relating to that matter will come before the Senate later this week, so I will reserve my further remarks along that line until then.

In conclusion, the Opposition supports this legislation for the better workings of the collection of these levies. However, I hope that any benefits that result from the more efficient collection of the levies will be passed back to the grower, as has not been the case with the transaction levy, so that producers receive a benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating three rural Bills which consolidate the collection charges levied by the Federal Government and the consequential amendments to other Acts that flow from the consolidation of these Bills. The Opposition will support them because, in a sense, they are purely a housekeeping measure; they do not change anything. However, one is driven to comment on how these Bills illustrate the huge cost impost on rural producers.

SPEECH.PARA: People tend to think that rural producers somehow or other live idyllic lives free from the stresses of the urban environment and once or twice a year bring their products into town, having had no costs in producing those products. But the reality of the situation today is that there are now enormous costs on the rural producer. The very sobering impact of the Bills before us is the great swag of charges that the Federal Government now imposes on rural producers.

But that is not the end of it. The Government imposes many indirect charges on rural producers and, of course, the State governments-particularly the Labor State governments-are in there, boots and all, socking it to the poor old rural producer, who in most cases is simply not in a position to pass on charges. A restaurant can charge a good unionist a little more for a steak sandwich when he is working a 32- or 33-hour week; that is fine. He just applies for a wage rise, but there are no wage rises possible for rural producers, who have to sell their products, in the main, on the international markets in competition with the other nations of this world. There is a very good discipline that could be imposed on the economy to control costs within the country to keep rural products competitive. That is important to Australia, because about 40 per cent of our export earnings, meagre though they are, come from the activities of our rural producers.

The Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Bill consolidates the collection charges that previous speakers have referred to-the cattle slaughter levy and such things. The Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Consequential Provisions) Bill deals with the consequential amendments to 30 different pieces of legislation. As I said, it is sobering to reflect now on the range of charges that the Federal Government imposes on the rural industry and to look back a decade ago, when most of those charges did not exist. If they did exist, they were very nominal. The final Bill is the National Cattle Disease Eradication Trust Account Bill.

The Bills impose no new taxes. The Government puffs itself up and says, `That is good; they are revenue neutral', but the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech cannot deny the fact that these Bills are before us as a result of the outcry of the industry at the charges. As he says in the second reading speech, they are a housekeeping measure to try to bring some order to the system that exists at present.

I said before that 40 per cent of Australia's export earnings come from rural industry. It is still a very large industry in Australia. It ranks with the mining industry, which has a slightly higher figure, as the principal export earning sector in the Australian economy. In 1988-89 the rural industry was valued at $22 billion. There are 165,000 farms in Australia. Most of those are family farms, only about 5 per cent being owned by public or private companies. The industry directly employs nearly 400,000 Australians, and those 400,000 Australians contributed nearly $15.5 billion in export earnings last year.

One of the basic facts of life that are not appreciated by the Australian Labor Party, being a Party composed of union officials and the odd minor solicitor and minor schoolteacher, is the fact that when rural Australia is doing well the whole of Australia is doing well, and when rural Australia is in depression the whole of Australia is in depression. That has been an inviolate rule of Australia for the whole of our history. It therefore follows that all the nonsense that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) might talk when he dissembles over the latest figures for the unemployment rate, the inflation rate, the balance of payments and all the rest of it, and all the mickey mouse schemes such as the J-curve, going back to the start of the present Hawke Labor disaster, do not really matter if rural Australia is in depression.

The fact of the matter is that now, through a conjunction of events-a surplus on overseas markets, subsidies for overproduction in the European Community and to some degree in the United States of America, and, most importantly, the cost pressures we have now loaded on the Australian producer-the Australian rural economy is in depression.

TALK.START.PARA: —If this Government would only realise it, it would be a start.

—It does not realise; it has no knowledge. As I said before, it is a party of minor union officials and school teachers-only marginally better than the Australian Democrats-with no concept at all of the economic reality in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: At present the rural sector is in a very big depression. The three big export earners-wool, wheat and beef-are in trouble. The wool market and the wheat market are in crisis and the beef market is not looking too good, and we have quite a lot of problems on the horizon. There are three broad areas which contribute to our high costs. There is the fact that world commodity prices are down. We have had a number of climatic instances, particularly in my State of Queensland, where about half the State is under water at the moment. That has had a devastating effect on stock, particularly in the cattle industry, as well as on the sugar industry, which is another significant export earner.

The final problem is the cost pressures imposed on the industry, many of which relate to the Government. There are the high interest rates, the high cost of fuel and the high cost of inflation. I will deal with them briefly. The Government has been spending more money that it earns. In all the years since 1983, since it came in to power, its policy has been to have a high interest rate regime to attract money into the country. But this is utterly devastating for small business and rural producers in many ways. Although they might have assets or nominal assets that run up into the many hundreds of thousands, and sometimes into the millions, they are small businesses and they need overdrafts to survive. In the past they have paid figures in excess of 20 per cent and 25 per cent. This adds enormously to their operating costs. To go off on a tangent, clause 15(3) (c) of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Bill states that, if someone defaults in paying these accounts to the Commonwealth, the rate of interest levied by the Commonwealth is 2 per cent per month. In simple English, that represents 24 per cent a year. It is now enshrined in the legislation that anyone who defaults on payment of his or her account to the Commonwealth will pay 24 per cent.

The first time that I bought a house-Senator Tate can smile, but it is a real bloodsucking operation-I had to pay 7 per cent, and I thought 7 per cent was blatant usury. But now enshrined in Commonwealth legislation is the fact that, if the poor old rural producer who probably has to wait six to 12 months before he can sell his cattle or get his sugar, wheat or some other crop in, cannot meet his bill, he is in for 24 per cent.

That this has been done says a great deal about the Government's lack of knowledge of the industry. It also says a great deal about the Government's expectations. That small figure of 2 per cent per month shows that, first, it does not have the courage to write it up as 24 per cent per annum and that, secondly, it expects that, for the rest of its tenure on the treasury bench, inflation and interest rates will be running at a level that makes its charge of 24 per cent look compatible. I do not need to say any more on that point when it is spelled out in those terms.

One of the other great costs for the rural industry is fuel, which is enormously dear. It is true that rural producers qualify for the diesel rebate scheme and they are grateful for that, but that is only part of the equation. Fuel is a factor in pretty well everything that happens in Australia. We are a huge country with a low density population. Our manufacturing centres are well removed, by and large, from the rural producing areas. The cost of fuel and transport is factored into everything we buy. Everything a rural producer buys has a very significant fuel component.

Before the Gulf crisis started the cost of fuel in Australia was twice what it was in the United States. As the United States is getting its fuel from the Gulf and it is paying the same price per barrel as we are, there is no reason for Australia's fuel to be so expensive other than the rapacious taxes being put on it through fuel excise by this Government. But it has got a lot worse than that. Since the Gulf crisis, we have been paying pump prices about 60 per cent to 70 per cent higher-depending on where the fuel is bought-than they were before the Gulf crisis. Yet the price of fuel-the cost per barrel on the international market-is lower today than it was six months ago when the Gulf crisis started.

What is going on here? Why has the Government not moved in and done something to control those prices? We have not seen any significant erosion from the peak prices of fuel at the pump since the Gulf crisis. There might have been a 6c or 8c reduction in the cost per litre, but there is no way at all that the price of fuel today is what it was before the Gulf crisis started.

The only justification that anyone can advance for that is the fact that there has been a marginal increase in exchange rates, which makes the fuel slightly dearer for us to buy, but that does not mathematically go anywhere near explaining what is going on. The Government should certainly look at its Trades Practices Act. It should stop the monopoly that the oil companies, the refiners, have in tying houses. It should generate a free market so that any retailer can sell fuel bought from any producer within Australia or even overseas, so that we get a bit of real competition in the marketplace. If that happens, we will see a degree of moderation in the charges being applied to rural producers.

It is not only fuel that is the problem; it is everything that flows from the petrochemical industries. Plastics have an important place in rural production with polythene piping and all the rest of it. Petroleum feed stock for that matter is now very expensive. Again, it has gone up in price. We will not see the cost of polythene piping come down. We will not see the cost of paint come down. Again, this works off petroleum feed stock. These things have a major impact on rural producers.

One of the other great economic problems for the rural producer has of course been the effect of inflation-one of the living legacies of the mismanagement during the Whitlam years. Now, nearly 20 years after those fools were on the treasury bench we are still ingrained with very high inflation. The expectation in all branches of industry-whether rural, manufacturing or anything else-is that each year, each month and each week one has to add factor something into one's prices to cope with inflation. We are in a self-perpetuating mode there. Of course, the Government is again right at the heart of this. It loves bracket creep. It loves to see inflation increase so that people's salaries go up as a consequence and it gets more and more taxation each year in a very dishonest way. One of the great disciplines the Government could impose would be to index its taxation take from the community so that it is not a beneficiary of inflation.

One of the other great cost imposts comes from the Government's labour practices-its absolute reluctance, inability and obdurate approach to cleaning out the labour practices; its inability to take on the trade unions and get some productivity out of the work force. There are hundreds of thousands of Australians who are prepared to do a good day's work for a good day's pay. I was pleased to hear Mr Howard yesterday call for a return to the 40-hour week and for the removal of all those fringe benefits. I hope that becomes a reality. We simply cannot go on drifting and dreaming our way through the world, paying ourselves more to do less than other countries.

The example that Senator Brownhill gave the other day was very salutary. He stated that these work practices affect just one part of the industry-the cattle industry. He quoted the labour costs of just slaughtering and packing a beast-in Australia, $111; in the United States, $36 and, in Uruguay, $56.

When one adds in all the other costs, one finds that it costs $193 to slaughter and get a beast right through the abattoir, from the moment it turns up at the gate to when it goes out in a cardboard carton-$193 in Australia, $88 in the United States and $82 in Uruguay. I am a beef producer myself, and when we sell beef on the export market we do not get any compensation from the purchasers-whether they are in Taiwan, Singapore, South Korea or Japan-because it costs us $193 to process that beast as against $82 in Uruguay.

It would be remiss of me not to refer to the way the State governments are also in on the act regarding rural producers. In my own State of Queensland we have the misfortune to have a Labor Government. Only last week the Queensland Government again hiked up the electricity charges very savagely. Again, rural producers have very high power costs. The only glimmer of joy in the whole business, I suppose, is the fact that we do not have the Democrats in government. Such a situation would be even bleaker still for the rural producers because there would be the reintroduction of death duties on properties over $300,000, a Federal land tax scheme would be introduced and we would see capital gains tax ratchetted to higher levels. Of course, we would go back to the Stone Age with respect to controlling weed and pest infestation because we would find that all chemicals used on a farm would be totally taxed out of existence. There would be the abolition of the live sheep export trade and, of course, the lives of anyone in the pastoral industry would be utter misery because the most extreme claims of the animal liberation lobby would be written into the Democrats' policies. I was very heartened over the weekend to read a commentator in one of the Sunday papers who said that he thought Robert Menzies was the greatest Prime Minister we have ever had, which is a feeling I have always shared with millions of other Australians. Let us get the Government, with its huge raft of taxes, off our backs-taxes which, by and large, do very little in a positive or constructive way; taxes and levies which, by and large, only provide income for people who simply do not want to do an honest day's work.
