DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 December, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill. However, we have a number of concerns about the Bill and believe that in many respects it is unnecessary and introduces a number of highly regulatory procedures which could be done without the necessity of legislation. This Bill gives legislative force to what we see as a monolithic structure. Also, it is a long piece of legislation which in many aspects only gives effect to the common law liabilities which employers have to employees. There is also the question of the additional cost to the Government in putting in place legislation of this kind. Furthermore, the duplication between Commonwealth and State administration will be given greater emphasis by this legislation. Those are our principal criticisms of this Bill, which I shall deal with in more detail in the course of my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, despite those criticisms the Opposition will not be opposing the legislation. However, the Opposition is opposed to one of the three pillars of the Government's policy on occupational health and safety. Indeed, this is the third pillar which has been erected by the Commonwealth on this subject. The first Bill brought in by the Government introduced Worksafe, which set up the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. The second piece of legislation introduced by this Government established Comcare, which was an updated version of Commonwealth employees' compensation and with which I shall not deal now. The third piece of legislation puts in place a structure for Commonwealth employees and relates to liabilities placed on the Commonwealth as an employer. However, the Opposition believes that there is no necessity for the first of these pieces of legislation or for the new structures to which the Commonwealth has given effect.

On return to government we propose to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. We see it as unnecessarily duplicating the legislative and administrative arrangements between the Commonwealth and States in this area. We also see it as involving unnecessary expenditures and as duplicating in many ways the roles of Commonwealth and State. Therefore, although we shall not vote against the Bill itself, I move:
At end of motion, add:

``,but the Senate notes that the need for uniform national occupational health and safety standards has not been demonstrated; that the States and the Commonwealth are in the best place to determine their own needs; and that a future Liberal/National Government would abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and resume its functions within the Department''.

I now turn to some of the aspects of the legislation which, in the Opposition's view, offend much of the approach that we would favour on legislation and administration by the Commonwealth. There has been a growing tendency for many years, which seems to be accelerating under this Government, to churn out more and more legislation which adds virtually nothing to the requirements of good government or to the protection of people's rights and duties. It simply gives statutory form to and creates structures which only duplicate rights, procedures and institutions that already exist.
Part 2 of the Bill, in division 1, deals with the general duties relating to occupational health and safety and is a very good example of what I have been saying. The provision begins by stating:
An employer must take all reasonably practicable steps to protect the health and safety at work of the employer's employees.

Senator Cooney, who I understand will follow me in this debate-he is sitting patiently listening to me-will know that that has been the law of Australia for over 100 years. That law has been developed in a very sophisticated way over a long time. Yet here in this Bill we have pages restating not only the provisions as to that duty, but the duties of employers in relation to third parties, the duties of manufacturers in relation to plant and substances, the duties of suppliers, the duties of people erecting or installing plant in a workplace and so on. All these concepts come within the same category; namely, obligations which are being imposed on employers or on the various people concerned with occupational health and safety, as it is now called, and which is a modern buzz phrase. In fact, these matters have been working perfectly satisfactorily because these obligations have been developed over some years and relate to numerous instances as they have arisen.

All these obligations are well and truly established. As I said, they are working, subject to development and application in new situations, but all this part of the legislation, pages of it, adds nothing whatsoever to the benefit of people who may be affected by having to use plant on their work premises which is supplied by the manufacturers. It is a well-known and fundamental principle of the common law that one has to take reasonable care in a general way in relation to one's neighbour, and there is also the clearly established obligation as part of the contractual relationship that applies between employer and employee that reasonable care should be taken. As I have said, a great deal of this legislation is unnecessary.

However, if we turn from that general criticism to look at the specific reason for this legislation, we see that that arises in part 3 of the Bill, which puts in place what are called workplace arrangements; that is, it sets up a system providing for the appointment of people who have responsibility for watching out, I guess, for possible dangers to health and safety. It provides for the setting up of designated work groups and the appointment of a health and safety representative for each of these designated work groups.

That is a laudable idea. Indeed, there is nothing that the Opposition is concerned about in relation to that. The Opposition only wonders why legislation is needed to do it. We are talking about the obligations of the Commonwealth Government as the employer. This is not imposing any obligation on employers generally; the Commonwealth is imposing these obligations on itself. One must ask why the Government needs legislation to do it. When all is said and done, the Commonwealth, as part of this new dawn of cooperative occupational and safety arrangements in which it has been seeking to give leadership through the Occupational Health and Safety Commission, presumably has been observing these principles, codes of practice, and so forth.

Although this is a perfectly laudable objective that the Opposition has no criticism of, one wonders why it needs legislation. When we ask ourselves that, we soon get the answer as to why this legislation is brought in. It is brought in because it gives unions a highly preferred position in this whole subject. When we study this legislation fully, we see that that is about the only reason for it. The Government has brought this legislation in to further enhance the power, the authority and the general busibodiness of unions in as many affairs of the nation as it thinks it can. That is where the Opposition's major criticism of this legislation resides.

Of course, we are very much in favour of arrangements being entered into at the workplace. Enterprise agreements are matters that we want to encourage. Clearly, in matters of health and safety, we see very great merit in the employer and employees getting together and setting up, by agreement, a health and safety representative if one of the employees would take on this task. If more than one person was interested in that task, an election could be held which could be arranged by a suitable enterprise or workplace agreement.

But no, here the Government has erected a structure where, although it does not exclude that occurring, if there is a union involved the union has a preferred position under this legislation. An employee can be a candidate for this position where a union is involved only if he is nominated for the job by an involved union. When we have an election at the workplace for the position of health and safety representative, if a union is involved it is not open to any employee to put himself forward and say, `Look, I am the best person for this job'. He has to suck up to the union and get himself nominated by the union.

I do not suppose that we should be surprised by this sort of legislation. With its accord, this Government, from day one when it came into power nearly eight years ago, has agreed with the union movement of Australia that the peak councils of that union movement will virtually have a seat at the Cabinet table and has placed the union movement in a highly preferred position as far as the government of this country is concerned. In many ways, this is a very minor extension of the powers that have been accorded to unions over the years during which this Government has been in power.

The Bill gives a lot of powers to these health and safety representatives. If one of these people perceives that there is a health and safety problem and an immediate threat to health and safety, that representative, first of all, must inform a supervisor but, if he cannot find a supervisor immediately, he can direct an employee to cease working. This position is a very powerful one and that power is given to the representative by this legislation. The representative can do all sorts of other things, but nothing as effective as simply being able to stop work by any employee who he believes is in danger or is endangering health and safety. It is not a position which is there just to keep an eye on things to bring them to the attention of management; this legislation gives a very powerful position to that representative.

Another matter of concern to the Opposition about this whole question is that if this kind of structure is put in place, one would expect, and certainly one would hope, that it will put an end to industrial disputation on health and safety matters. As I have said, if this elaborate structure is created, if these very considerable powers are given and if this legislation is going to work, as presumably the Government thinks it is going to work-the Opposition may have some reservations about how effective it is going to be, but, obviously, the Government is not going to all this trouble unless it believes it is going to work-then we call upon the Government to make it very clear that it is not going to tolerate the use that has been made of such legislation by union representatives, particularly in the building industry, for so long whereby they create so-called health and safety issues to further their industrial policies. That has notoriously been the case in the building industry where lightning strikes have been pulled on on spurious health or safety grounds to achieve other purposes.

The value of this sort of legislation may be put in question because a similar type of legislation in Victoria certainly did not prevent the major industrial dispute and confrontation which occurred at the Hoechst factory last year. The Victorian Premier herself seemed to be encouraging what was clearly an abuse of legislation-the Victorian legislation in relation to this matter is very similar to the proposed legislation-and yet this was still pulled on. I believe that the Government ought to make clear that in its view this Bill should put an end to, and the Government itself will strongly support an ending of, this misuse of safety issues for industrial purposes by militant unions.

I have dealt at some length with the criticisms and concerns that the Opposition has about the Bill. It is going to add to direct government costs. One has to wonder whether that is money well spent despite the fact that it is a relatively small sum. Nevertheless, it is an issue that has to be noted.

Our third concern is the extent of Commonwealth involvement in health and safety matters which this Bill adds to. As I said, it is the third pillar in what has been a developing policy by the Commonwealth Government to get itself more involved in these issues. The Commonwealth now seems to be showing concern about the extent to which duplication of Commonwealth and State functions has been created-not only by this Government, I freely admit, but by successive governments in Australia-which, as I said earlier, certainly has been accelerated a great deal by this Government in the eight years in which it has been in office.

We believe that there is no need, if we are still going to do something about that, to maintain the existence of a National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. There has been enough consultation and experience in this area now at the State level and at the Commonwealth level for there to be no need to continue another bureaucratic structure of that sort. It received in the latest Budget $15 million, of which half was spent on salaries for people to go around the countryside having conferences, programs, study groups, seminars and whatever. The Opposition believes that this is only adding to the costs of government in Australia and we believe that the time has come for that to be abolished. That is the basis on which the Opposition has moved this amendment, to add those views on this occasion when we are supporting, or at least not opposing, the second reading of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Durack has pointed out, there has been much law made in looking to the welfare of people in the workplace. Much of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill 1990 is the proper and natural outcome of much that has gone before. The nineteenth century workplace that people like Charles Dickens described in Hard Times has, hopefully, by and large gone. But there is much yet to do to ensure that people are able to work in a place that is safe and proper; safe not only in terms of the trauma that might be inflicted on them by unguarded machines or slippery floors, but also in terms of their psychological health, the health of their organs and their ability generally to go about their functions in a way that leaves their bodily and mental integrity sound. This is good legislation and it takes practical steps to ensure that the workplace is run in a proper and safe fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three things that a good employer should provide for his, her or its employees; that is, safety in the workplace so that accidents are prevented; rehabilitation, if, unfortunately, an accident takes place; and income maintenance while a person is recovering. A significant clause of this Bill is clause 12 which refers to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. It imposes certain obligations and entitlements on that Commission. The title of that Act indicates that it is concerned with two of the issues that I was talking about before; that is, rehabilitation and income maintenance. But the primary consideration of any employer should be the safety of the employee in the workplace, and that is what this legislation addresses. It does some very useful things besides. It obliges the Commission to collect, interpret and report information relating to occupational health and safety in Commonwealth employment and to formulate policies and strategies relating to the occupational health and safety of employees, amongst other things.

The emphasis that this Act gives to safety-this point cannot be repeated enough-is crucial. I say to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who has finally brought this forth where other Ministers have not, that it is not before time that he and the Parliament have brought forward legislation such as this. I am glad to see it is here.

Senator Durack has said that this legislation simply repeats what other law already contains. It does more than that. Clause 16, which Senator Durack properly referred to, takes tortious matters and attaches to them a criminal penalty. I have no doubt that the courts will apply these penalties properly and fairly, but it introduces the concept of the criminality of employers in failing to take proper care of the people who operate in their workplaces.

I think that is an important step. It does several things. First of all, it ensures that employers will look to the safety of their employees, and the more people that are protected from a violation of their bodily, mental and psychological health, the happier the community. The social cost that comes about through injuries is horrific, the emotional cost is horrific and the cost to the family is horrific and, in my view, those costs are more important than the financial costs which, because of the nature of the parliamentary process, we tend to concentrate on in areas like this. True enough, the financial cost of accidents is a very important one to consider, but the others I have mentioned are perhaps more important. When this Bill becomes an Act and goes into operation, I think what we will find is that the social, emotional and family costs that I have talked about will be much reduced and the financial costs will be, too. This Bill perhaps has done more for the saving of expenditure in the workplace than many other ones that come before this Parliament.

The next thing I want to turn to is the question of the unions that Senator Durack has raised. He said that this gives the unions an unfair prominence in the running of health and safety in the workplace. Can I just say this: if there is one area in which the unions have an obligation to act, it is in the area of health and safety. Unions came into operation to get a fair return for their members and then had to work against the combination Acts and so on, but one of the earlier issues that they had to face was this issue of safety. Safety was a long time coming to the workplace, and indeed the law was a long time coming in giving answers to that. It was only perhaps halfway through this century that the effects of common employment, of volenti, and of contributory negligence were modified by the courts. Indeed, courts were quite slow in responding to the needs of people who suffered grievously in the workplace.

It is one of the great glories of the Parliaments, both here and in England, that they introduced legislation such as the fencing Act and those other Acts which imposed proper conduct upon employers by providing safety-in terms of physical safety-in the workplace. In that context, the unions are essential to give strength to employees who might face a grievous situation. For example, if somebody is working a word processing machine, there is danger of repetitive strain injury occurring because the seat is not at the proper level or the machine is not far enough away. I am just looking at Hansard here but there is no machine there at the moment that I can use as an illustration. But if that is the situation with a young lady of 18 or 19, it is expecting a lot of her to get up and complain to her employer that the seat is not appropriate. However, it is a different matter if she has got a union and a representative of the union can make that complaint on her behalf. I repeat that if there is any area in which a union should be and should be working effectively, it is in this area of health and safety.

Senator Durack properly raised the issue that if a health and safety representative goes beyond his or her power, then problems can occur. This Bill under the close scrutiny of the Minister has seen to that and it is for that reason that clause 32 is inserted. It says:

32. (1) An application for the disqualification of a health and safety representative for a designated work group may be made to the Commission by the employer of all the employees including in the designated work group, or by an involved union in relation to the designated work group, on one of both of the following grounds:
(a) that action taken by the representative in the exercise of purported exercise of a power under subsection 28 (1) or any other provision of this Act was taken:
(i) with the intention of causing harm to the employer or to an undertaking of the employer; or
(ii) unreasonably, capriciously or otherwise than for the purpose for which the power was conferred on the representative.

That seems to meet the objection that was properly raised by Senator Durack. If there is no union some other person, who is not a member of the union, is elected. My view is that such a person is in a very weakened state because he or she has not got the backup that is so essential when meeting a body, such as the Commonwealth or its instrumentalities.

Telecom Australia has some power in the land. It has economic power of considerable proportions and, particularly now when people are looking for work, unless a particular employee had an ability to call on an institution such as a union to back up his or her position regarding a health issue, he or she is going to be in terrible trouble indeed.

The situation would be the same with Australia Post. If a person is not given proper clothing or not given proper protection against the weather, it is almost an impossibility for that person to stand up for himself or herself. The same with the Commonwealth. I do not know whether the Department of the Senate would be so oppressive as to come down on the Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch, but I am sure that if they did she would be more than happy to have somebody back her up. So I think to criticise the unions in this particular concept is misconceiving the function of unions. One might talk about whether they operate appropriately in other areas but in this area of health and safety their need is essential.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should somebody have to be nominated by a union to even stand for election?

—I suppose it is a matter of mechanism. As long as the union is there to back up the position that is taken by the representative, I do not suppose it matters whether it nominates him or not. But it seems to me that the mechanism that is set out in this Act is a useful one, as long as one has got a group willing to back up the position.

SPEECH.PARA: We politicians, in a way, every now and then go into this union tendency, particularly when we are looking to raise our salaries-not so much to get what we do not deserve, of course, but to give a common answer to the objection that we get anything at all. We all, in various aspects of our lives, look for a backup and I suppose that is why we are members of a particular party. It is good to have people around when one is making points in this chamber. I oftentimes feel sorry for Senator Vallentine who sits there on her own. I am sure that she would more than welcome a few companions to back her up in what she does and that is essentially the function that a union performs.

I have perhaps spoken for longer than I had intended. But as we look at it, and I keep repeating, this is a piece of legislation which is essential in the development of the law which regulates the workplace. This is a big step.

I refer to clause 23 because it gives government-the people concerned-the right to make regulations. I think that is important. In my view it is better to bring forward safety provisions by way of regulations rather than in the Act. The nature of the workplace and the dangers that occur in the workplace tend to change quite rapidly and it is proper that a fairly rapid means of answering those changes be provided. That is provided by clause 23 which gives power to make regulations.

Finally, I congratulate the Minister and the Government for bringing forward this legislation. I think it will work, as similar legislation in Victoria has worked. The purpose of the scheme is really to give both employers and employees an opportunity for commenting upon the workplace, to prevent injuries that might otherwise have arisen, to give advice as to how hazards can be removed, and generally to save many people in the future from costs, whether those costs be social, financial, emotional or otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill 1990. The purpose of the Bill in broad terms is to provide for the protection of the health and safety of Commonwealth employees at work. Senator Cooney has very adequately drawn attention to the historical significance of health and safety as a preoccupation of workers. I think he rightfully has acknowledged the role of unions in relation to this key issue and has cited it as being an area of specific, very precise focus of unions for decades.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will impose on both employers and employees of the Commonwealth a duty of care and specific obligations which are similar to the obligations currently imposed on employers and employees by legislation which has been enacted by most of the Australian States. Commonwealth Government employees will now have similar protection to that which is presently enjoyed by both public and private sector employees in most States.

In other words, it is a Bill of uniformity; it is a Bill which draws together fragmented patterns of legislation throughout the Commonwealth. In that respect, it is a Bill which is overdue. I join with Senator Cooney in congratulating the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and the Government for finally drawing together this fragmented pattern of legislative cover.

The Bill not only addresses obligations of employers and employees in relation to health and safety matters at work but it also addresses the consequences of injury at work in terms of compensation, rehabilitation and the other important human dimensions which flow from breaches of safety and health in the workplace. It does not pretend that it is possible to make all workplaces in every way healthy and safe. I think it would be folly for us to imagine that that is achievable, but we can address ourselves to reducing the incidence and severity of such things.

The Occupational Health and Safety Commission was established in 1985 and was formed to rectify previous difficulties caused by the fragmented approach to occupational health and safety and to provide a national focus for the development and application of uniform standards and strategies. In my speech to the amendment Bill in 1988, I said that the Australian Democrats supported the establishment of the Commission but we believed that its output and effect had been disappointing. I think one has to monitor constantly the effectiveness of commissions of this type. I am interested to note that Senator Durack has flagged the intention of the coalition-should it become government-to abolish this Commission.

This Bill addresses some of the criticisms of the McKay report, particularly the lack of coordination between State and Commonwealth legislation. So, in general terms, the Australian Democrats support the Bill. My colleague, Senator Coulter, who will pass brief comments, will flag certain reservations and concerns that we have, and which we will be seeking the Minister and the Government to address through regulations.

Fairly predicably, Senator Durack ran the coalition's usual States rights arguments-that is understandable; it is its position in principle. The coalition essentially has a philosophical position to minimise the imposition of Commonwealth legislation over and above State legislation. But I think in running that argument-which, as I say, was predictable-he has rather confused the issue and the intention of uniformity. Indeed, the very role of the Commission, as it was intended when it was established in 1985, was to address the inherent difficulties associated with States on their own pursuing issues of occupational health and safety without some coordinated umbrella legislation at the Federal level.

It was also predictable that Senator Durack would focus on the unions' roles in this matter. To use his terms, he described them as pursuing with their usual busybodiness as many affairs of the nation as they can. I think, frankly, that that was a fairly empty criticism and observation concerning the very genuine and legitimate concern of unions in relation to occupational health and safety.

As Senator Cooney quite rightly points out, there are few areas of concern that historically have drawn such intense attention as has the issue of occupational health and safety. To argue that unions are just simply being busybodies in pursuit of this interest I think fails to acknowledge the legitimate role of unions in industrial relations and issues that flow from it. To suggest they have no place is to fly in the face of the realities of life. I am afraid that to suggest that their pursuit of these issues is nothing more than busybodiness is very superficial indeed.

Senator Durack suggested that of course occupational health and safety is an important issue and it can be adequately addressed in enterprise agreements. But with the increasing focus on productivity-which is one of the thrusts and focuses of the coalition's industrial relations policy-I would suggest there is a grave temptation in the pursuit of productivity for profit to fall back to where we were in terms of giving adequate attention to occupational health and safety.

Our record in Australia has not been good. There have been a number of serious reports which have been very critical of our record in occupational health and safety. I think this has probably been partly because it is very tempting for employers-particularly in the pursuit of productivity-to downgrade the significance of this aspect of the workplace. It is costly; it is expensive; and it does require special attention and special commitment of the employer. Of all of the commitments of the employer, I think this would be the one that is most threatened by a thrust and an emphasis on productivity for profit.

The Australian Democrats in general terms support this legislation. We congratulate the Government for finally addressing it adequately. However, we do have some rights, which Senator Coulter will now turn the Government's attention to. In the committee stage we hope to seek assurances from the Minister as to aspects of this legislation which we hope will be addressed through regulations. I think that Senator Cooney has correctly made the point that in this type of legislation, regulations are probably the best way to go in some respects. But there are assurances which we would require of the Government in relation to regulations flowing from this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some pleasure that I rise to support this legislation, because it is an area in which I was involved for some years in my former work. I had occasion to investigate a number of situations involving government employees in South Australia where quite serious health hazards were involved. The government departments concerned were uncaring of the health of their employees. In my experience I think it is fair to say that government departments have not been any better than private employers when it comes to the occupational health of their employees.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to mention a couple of situations in which I was involved personally with the investigations. Contrary to the assertions of Senator Durack, who indulged in a bit of his usual union bashing, I found that the unions behaved very responsibly in these particular cases and had very legitimate concerns over the agents to which their workers were exposed.

In opening, I think that it is fair to comment on the occupational risks related to the exposure of workers to mutagens and carcinogens. This is the area in which I work. It is fair to observe that some 25 per cent of the population in any Western country, including Australia, will get cancer at some stage and about 20 per cent of the population will die of cancer. Epidemiological studies indicate that perhaps as much as 90 per cent of that cancer is related to environmental factors. These studies look at the incidence of cancer in one area relative to another area. Through these comparative epidemiological studies, it is possible to find an incidence of cancer which is a background incidence and then to ascribe all cancers beyond that background level as related to some environmental factor in that particular region.

It is certainly true that most of those cancer-causative factors are still unrecognised. Of those that have been recognised, many relate to naturally occurring factors in the environment or factors which are easily under the control of the individual. We all know that the most common environmental factor causing cancer is tobacco smoke. We know of a number of other factors in the environment which relate to cancer. But there is still a significant residue of factors which almost certainly relates to occupational exposure.

I will mention a couple of investigations in which I was involved in the late 1970s which indicate the extent to which workers quite recently have been exposed and the response of the government departments to those exposures. In one instance I was called upon by a health nurse in one of the largest government departments in South Australia to see whether I could aid in the investigation of what the workers perceived as a possible health risk. The workers were involved in covering very large metal pipes with pitch-soaked bandages to prevent the pipes from rusting. Through general reading I was aware that pitch contains a number of carcinogenic substances. The health nurse concerned had contacted members of the Health Commission and they said that they had great difficultly in properly estimating the risk to which workers were exposed.

Through the tests that I was doing in my laboratory, I indicated that it was quite possible to get quite an accurate fix on the risks involved. I asked for a sample of the pitch before and after it was heated, from which I was able to calculate the amount of carcinogenic agent being released into the atmosphere to which these workers were exposed. Roughly, the workers were melting the pitch in 44-gallon drums in a relatively closed environment, bucketing this material out and then painting it onto these large pipes. It turned out that in the course of heating up a 44-gallon drum of this pitch, the equivalent of 4 million cigarettes worth of carcinogens were being released into the environment in which these workers were working. They were inhaling this material and, quite clearly, were being exposed to a very significant health risk.

As a consequence of the report which I made to the department, and which of course I made available to the workers, that practice was stopped. What happened then was very interesting. The Government department then decided to contract this work out to a private contractor. That is relevant when it comes to the obsession which the Opposition has for contracting government work out with the claim that that will somehow produce more efficient and less costly material being produced.

In this case, the work was contracted out, the work continued to be done and the workers in the private concern were not informed of the hazards to which they were exposed. Further studies were carried out by the Health Commission, a government instrumentality, without my laboratory being involved and without the workers being notified. This actually is contrary to the law in South Australia, where any investigation should be followed by notification both to the employer and to the union.

So in this situation we had the collusion of several government departments to get work done which had been demonstrated to be extremely hazardous to the health of workers so that the work could continue in a private capacity and the particular department could still continue to have its pipes covered in pitch.

The second example involves the laboratory in which I actually worked. As a member of the safety committee, I was asked to investigate a situation which had been identified as potentially hazardous. This involved the preparation of what were called specific pathogen-free animals. These animals were kept in a sealed laboratory. The workers went into the laboratory through a shower trap. They shed all their clothes, went in through a shower, donned sterile garb, worked in there all day and then came out through the same shower trap in the evening. The air that went into the laboratory was filtered and rendered bacteria-free. Everything went in through a steriliser. The food to feed these animals went in through an autoclave-type arrangement which used ethylene oxide as a sterilising agent. Ethylene oxide had been recognised for some years as a mutagen, a potential carcinogen. The question then arose: were the workers not exposed to the ethylene oxide degassing from the food before it was actually fed to the animals?

Indeed, the four workers-one male and three young females-were all expecting to enter their productive years shortly and therefore were very concerned about exposure to mutagens. They had already discovered that if this food were fed to animals in less than a fortnight the animals died. So clearly there was something in the food which was highly toxic. Investigations revealed that indeed there was a material being formed in the food from exposure to the ethylene oxide. That material was about 50 times more mutagenic and carcinogenic than the ethylene oxide itself and in fact was being released particularly while the animals were actually eating the food, because the highest levels of this agent in the atmosphere were actually in the area where the workers spent most of their day cleaning the cages and providing fresh food to the animals.

I mention this situation because on that occasion as a member of the safety committee I was asked to do this by the institute where I worked, but I was also asked by the person in charge of the laboratory whether I would provide information to the workers as it became available so that they could form some assessment as to the hazards to which they were exposed. Believing that workers should have that knowledge, I made that information available to them and that occasioned a great deal of consternation on the part of the management of this government run and financed laboratory.

The attitude of management on that occasion was that it was inappropriate to provide information to the workers as to the agents to which they were exposed and the degree of risk to which they were exposed. In neither case were strikes involved and in neither case were there spurious reasons. In both cases, significant health hazards were raised by the workers themselves. These were investigated and indeed there were serious hazards involved which could be addressed, but in both cases government employers were involved and took action to suppress the information from the workers and to cover up the degree of risk involved. In that context, I think it is highly desirable that this uniform national legislation be put in place because I cannot believe that those two instances-and a number of others in which I was involved in South Australia-are in any way unique. I think those sorts of things probably have gone on and have involved other government departments in other States and have unnecessarily exposed workers to considerable risks.

However, the significant part of this legislation to which I would like to turn now and which I would like, in the committee stage, to draw to the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is the clauses which deal with the extent to which this Act binds the Crown. I note that clause 11(2) says:
Nothing in this Act renders:
(a) the Commonwealth; or
(b) a Commonwealth authority other than a Government business enterprise; or
(c) a person who is employed by:
(i) the Commonwealth; or
(ii) a Commonwealth authority other than a Government business enterprise;
liable to be prosecuted for an offence.

To my mind, this raises the question of exactly what power this legislation has to force the Commonwealth to observe its own legislation. After all, we are talking about the occupational health and safety of Commonwealth employees, and I would have thought that it was necessary in this legislation to make the Commonwealth or Commonwealth authorities liable under their own legislation. I would like some clarification of that from the Minister when we get to the committee stage.

I wish also to draw attention to clauses 6, 7 and 8, which deal with both national security and internal security. Clause 8 deals with acts which should not prejudice certain police operations. I notice that all those clauses essentially absolve the particular departments covering either national security or certain police operations from responsibility in relation to occupational health and safety if the recognition of an occupational health and safety problem would prejudice national security or police operations. I can fully understand that in the case of soldiers and sailors at the present time in the Middle East. They are exposed to the risk of being shot at, which clearly is a health hazard. There is no question that the hazard in that case could not be covered by this sort of legislation.

However, let us suppose for argument's sake that it was deemed desirable that unexposed asbestos still be used in ships for insulation purposes, even in peacetime but in preparation for possible conflict, and that it was thought that the non-use of asbestos under those circumstances might prejudice national security because in some way the ship might be more likely to catch fire, be sunk or something. That is a hazard to which the sailors may be exposed. We have seen a celebrated case recently with the death of the Governor of New South Wales from an asbestos-related illness which I believe it was claimed he had acquired during time in the navy. Following from that, there have been a number of other claims that sailors have been exposed to asbestos. Could the responsibility for exposing people to those sorts of risks be avoided in any way under these particular clauses of this legislation? I notice that in both clauses 6 and 7, which relate to the defence forces, there is a subclause (4) that refers to subclause (2), and in each case the subclause (2) says:

. . . the Director-General of Security may, after consulting with the Minister, by notice in writing, declare that specified provisions of this Act do not apply, or apply subject to such modifications and adaptions as are set out in the declaration, in relation to . . .
Various things are then specified; subclause (4) says:
A notice in writing under subsection (2) is a disallowable instrument for the purpose of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act . . .

There is a provision in this legislation for parliamentary scrutiny of these exclusions from the provisions of this legislation, but it seems to me that it requires very close scrutiny and a fair bit of knowledge of the potential risks associated with some potential exclusions. As I said, Parliament will need to scrutinise this matter closely to ensure that the risks-other than the risks of direct conflict, such as being shot at and so on-are brought under this legislation, as I believe they should be, and that workers are adequately protected. However, when we turn to clause 8, which deals with the acts which may prejudice certain police operations, we find that it contains no protective provision at all. It says:

Nothing in this Act requires or permits a person to take any action, or to refrain from taking any action, that would be, or could reasonably be expected to be, prejudicial to an existing or future covert operation or dangerous operation of the Australian Federal Police.
It goes on to define `covert operation' and `dangerous operation' and concludes with the words:

. . . exposure of a member to the danger of serious physical harm or death, other than a danger arising from a cause within the control of the Australian Federal Police, is reasonably necessary for the effective performance of the function or the provision of the service;

That clause provides for no parliamentary protection, no oversight at all. I can foresee situations in which for the purposes of carrying out covert or dangerous operations it may be deemed `necessary' to expose workers to risks which do not relate directly to the danger to which they were exposed as a consequence of the covert or dangerous operation, such as the risk of being shot at. When we get to the committee stage I would like some clarification from the Minister as to the protective devices available under clause 8 in relation to police operations.

With those questions to be taken up in the committee stage, I return to the earlier theme. Along with my colleague Senator McLean I support this legislation. We believe that it is highly desirable to have uniform national legislation in this area. We believe that it is necessary to make it explicit, and we will look very closely at regulations which clearly will need to be passed under this legislation and, more particularly, at the codes of practice which will come in under this legislation in relation to exposure to particular agents, particular circumstances and particular hazards. Clearly, they are the things that will set the standards determining the level to which Commonwealth employees will be exposed to hazard in coming years.

We will not support the Opposition's second reading amendment, as my colleague Senator McLean has already indicated. I give notice that, if in future there is a Liberal-National Party government, we will oppose the abolition of the uniform national legislation which we are debating today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been four speakers, apart from me, in this debate, and I congratulate Senator Durack as the Opposition spokesman and Senator McLean as the Australian Democrats spokesman for their contributions. However, without in any sense diminishing the thanks that I have just offered, I congratulate in particular Senator Cooney for my own Party and Senator Coulter, who has just finished speaking. Senator Cooney is a distinguished lawyer in workers compensation and brought to this debate a wealth of insight that would otherwise not have been available. Like Rumpole for the defence, Senator Cooney has always advocated the role of the underdog and thus it is not surprising that he sees the value of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill through the lens of workers who might be in a situation requiring the protection of their occupational health and safety.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter, who is a professional scientist in his non-senatorial role, has had particular exposure to matters of occupational health and safety and has brought a scientist's mind of analysis and concern to the debate. I thank and congratulate both speakers.

The Senate now has before it the Bill itself and a second reading amendment moved by Senator Durack, which the Government opposes, and which I understand from the remarks of both Senator McLean and Senator Coulter the Australian Democrats also oppose. As for the Bill itself, the Government is the proposer, the Democrats are supporting it and the Opposition is not opposing it. I think that is a direct summary of each party's position on this legislation. Given all of that, this Bill has the numbers for unanimous passage. However, in recognition of the arguments that have been raised as considerations, question marks or misgivings with which people have qualified their support for this legislation, I will briefly answer each of those.

The Government does not support the amendment moved by Senator Durack for the reason that it makes a nonsense, in the pure sense of that word, of the Bill. This is a Bill to cover Commonwealth government employees occupational health and safety provisions. To support a Bill that does that and then to carry a motion that says it is not needed because the States have legislation in this area is to attack the very premise of the Bill, and on that logical ground the amendment ought to fail.

The significant second point why the amendment should fail is that this is a Bill for Commonwealth employees. It is in this sense aimed at cutting down the red tape involved in having six State statutes applying to Commonwealth employees and having provisions applying to Commonwealth employees that differ between the States so that a worker employed by the Commonwealth in one locale may be subject to different standards from a worker in another State. It seems to me that in those circumstances, while it is true that the Commonwealth can make its own regulations, if you like, or impose its own standards in terms of a statutory requirement, this amendment should fail. It is better that there be one comprehensive set of Commonwealth laws applying to employees of the Commonwealth. It is for those reasons in brief that I oppose the legislation.

The legislation arises out of an excessively long period of consultation between the Government and unions representing Commonwealth employees and others with an interest in occupational health and safety-indeed, our own Worksafe Australia. The consultation started in 1983. We are giving effect, therefore, to something that has been talked over considerably and refined in discussion to suit the needs of the Commonwealth and people employed by the Commonwealth. What I said in my second reading speech perhaps bears brief repetition now. On average, the incidence of occupational death, injury or disease in Australia is unacceptably high. Each week an average of 3,000 Australian workers have a compensable injury requiring them to be off work for one week or more. The work force has a lost time element-time lost because of occupational health and safety absenteeism-that is about 10 times greater than the time lost through industrial disputation. According to the national account figures which the Australian Bureau of Statistics has estimated, in 1989-90 the total bill in occupational health and safety lost time alone was $4.8 billion in terms of the national accounts or 1.3 per cent of Australia's non-farm gross domestic product. That is just the direct costs. If the indirect costs were added the figure would be much higher.

It is with that background that the Commonwealth approaches this legislation. The Opposition has stated in the debate that it regards some of the provisions as unnecessary in part because the States should apply their own legislation. I think I have basically answered that. The uniformity cuts the red tape, and it is possible to foresee that if the Commonwealth did not have this legislation the unions with coverage of Commonwealth employees could apply to the Industrial Relations Commission for an award covering occupational health and safety.

It is far better that the conditions to apply for Commonwealth employees be legislated for arising from agreement than be arbitrated on arising from contention between the parties as to what should apply. Whether or not there was State legislation, the option open to the employees of the Commonwealth would still be through their unions to apply for an award. Of course we will consult on the standards that we propose by regulation later to describe. They will reflect the needs of modern day Australian workers. I think that is appropriate. It is not appropriate that the State legislation apply in these circumstances.

The other argument is that the Commonwealth could simply do it. So we could, but to do it with legislative force is to signal to the work force that we are dinkum about the encoding of standards in law that protect their basic rights. That is an obligation of good government.

One of the other objections raised was that the safety committees and the elected representatives have excessive power. From the debate it seems that this is objected to because they may in origin spring from unions. That is an ideological debate between the Opposition and the Government about the role of unions. I welcome the support of the Democrats on this. Unions are a legitimate part of the social fabric in Australia and they have a key role in this. That was said amply and eloquently by Senator Cooney.

Some reference was made to occupational health and safety being used artificially and wrongly as a means of industrial disputation with employers to visit pain upon an employer while the union got off scot-free. There is some evidence that this occurs in the building industry. The Government does not support that; we deplore it. I do not think that anything in this legislation can reasonably give rise to that.

This Bill imposes upon the Commonwealth a duty of care to its employees. By doing this we accept our responsibilities. As well, it imposes rights for employees to select representatives to represent them on occupational health and safety, with the range of responsibilities that those representatives will have being a reasonable range of responsibilities to carry out the job properly once they have been appointed. It will prescribe standards on specific hazards. The operational elements of this Bill will be overseen by Comcare.

It is a necessary piece of legislation. It is not simply cluttering the legislative statute books. It provides real rights. It answers a real need. It sets for Australia an important standard in seeing that the rights of individual workers to enjoy a safe, hazard and disease free environment are upheld properly in an appropriate form. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

``dangerous operation'' means the performance of a function or service under section 8 of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 in circumstances where exposure of a member to the danger of serious physical harm or death,-
and these are the relevant words-
other than a danger arising from a cause within the control of the Australian Federal Police, is reasonably necessary for the effective performance of the function or the provision of the service;

There are several questions arising out of that. The first question is: who makes the determination that the danger, other than a danger arising from a cause within the control of the Federal Police, is reasonably necessary? Who makes that determination that this exposure, which is now excluded from the provisions of this legislation, is reasonably necessary? What safeguards are in the Bill for the people exposed? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to pick up as completely as I can the nuances and all the variations that apply in each of those questions. Let me take the first question concerning the extent to which the Act binds the Crown, which is set out in clause 11.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I would say is that this Bill prescribes, of course, as we know, occupational, health and safety mechanisms to protect Commonwealth employees. If, under one of those regulations, a Commonwealth employee suffers injury or disease, that Commonwealth employee, given the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act, is entitled to compensation and, should rehabilitation be appropriate, to rehabilitation. If there is then a loss of function and physical or mental impairment to some extent, as assessed medically, that employee is entitled to compensation in the normal way.

This is not, therefore, a province of law in which there are actions for recovery of damages as such. This is an area in which there is no fault. Whoever's fault it was-whether it be the employee who negligently conducted himself or herself, or the employer who negligently supervised-the injury is covered by paid time off, compensation for loss of function and entitlement to proper rehabilitation. If the question is whether there are suable offences for damages, this is not an appropriate area of law where that applies.

The next reasonable question Senator Coulter asked was how somebody who is dissatisfied with the conduct of the Crown and who is an employee of the Crown might be protected if the right to sue or to take action at law, as might happen in a vehicle negligence case, applies. Let me refer to the reason why this Bill provides for the selection of safety representatives with powers of inspection and safety committees with powers of investigation and report. I note that one of the powers of safety representatives is, where necessary, to engage outside consultants to advise them on the conduct of their responsibilities. In that way there is an independent person in the workplace, other than the employer, elected by the people in that workplace to speak up for them. The reason why this involves Comcare, an authority of the Government that is not directable by the Minister, which has the carriage of the matter, is that there is an external agency outside the Public Service Commission which is also able to express a view or to take action.

The sorts of things that would apply were there to be a department or officers of a department who condoned negligence or acted negligently or matters that required disciplinary action involve a range of measures, including the naming of such people in Parliament. Therefore, there is a range of ways in which the interests of individuals can be protected, although there is no sense of fine upon the Commonwealth; the Commonwealth has some privilege. I think that answers as fully as I can, and as fully as I understand the questions put to me, Senator Coulter's points in that area.

I turn to the Australian Federal Police (AFP). The area in which this legislation would not apply is where an officer of the AFP, who for the purposes of this legislation would be the worker, is on covert operations. I suppose it is hypothetical but one could imagine the circumstances where some officer of the Federal Police successfully infiltrated a covert operation as directed by his or her superior. The officer concerned may be involved in risk taking activities that exposed them to danger. In those circumstances this legislation would not apply. Who would make the necessary decision? The superior officer directing the worker, in this case the police officer, in the covert work would make the decision that this was operational work of that nature. If there were a conflict, the Australian Federal Police enjoy the protection of a strong, articulate union and I am sure that union would speak up. I am not sure whether I have thrown some light on Senator Coulter's questions; I hope that I have answered them. Certainly in the circumstances of the Federal Police, when somebody is on active duty of a covert nature, obviously he is exposed to various dangers which in the normal course of Commonwealth employment would not be the case. When he is in the category of active service on covert duty, he is not covered by these provisions.

Debate resumed from 13 February, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has come to the view, with some considerable reluctance, that it cannot support the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990, the purpose of which is to enable Australia to ratify protocol I to the Geneva Conventions. The Bill has a history in this Parliament in that we will remember that some little time ago the Labor Government introduced it and sought bipartisan support. At the time we indicated, after considerable consideration and consultation, that we were not in a position to support it and the then Attorney-General withdrew the Bill, recognising the importance of bipartisan support for international treaties and other similar obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: Since then, the Opposition has given much more consideration to the legislation and has raised the possibility of the Government entering reservations in the hope that a position could be agreed between the major parties. The Government has not been prepared to accept our suggestion of reservations and, therefore, regrettably we are unable to support the legislation.

Protocol I was concluded in 1977 after many years of negotiation and is, of course, about protection of victims of international armed conflicts. I guess that our good faith in this matter is demonstrated by the fact that my colleague Senator Durack, at the time of early negotiations, was the Australian Attorney-General involved and my colleague in the other place Mr Andrew Peacock was at that time the Foreign Minister for Australia and was also involved in those negotiations. We support the spirit of looking at further ways in which we can protect the victims of international armed conflict; it is the detail of the ultimate documentation that came out of the long negotiation process that causes us concern.

This is protocol I. There is another protocol, protocol II, relating to non-international armed conflicts; but that, as I understand it, does not require domestic legislation prior to ratification. The protocols contain particular protections for categories of persons, such as the wounded, the sick, the shipwrecked, and civilian medical and religious personnel.

As was made clear by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General during debate on the Bill in the other place, the coalition supports and encourages the expansion of international humanitarian law. We regard the aims of the protocols as laudable. As I said, for reasons of detail and, in particular, our concern that this protocol, if ratified, would place too many impediments in the way of our armed forces and, in fact, may endanger them, we are not prepared to give our support to the legislation. We acknowledge the many arguments that can be put in favour of ratification and, in particular, those which were very cogently put by the International Committee of the Red Cross visiting this country. We have had long and considered discussions with its members. But, as I said, the arguments in favour are, in our view, outweighed by the arguments against ratification.

Those which can be described as the senior or otherwise major countries in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation have also had this concern and have not been prepared to ratify-neither has our principal alliance partner, the United States of America. It has similar reasons for concerns that we have, which I will detail in a moment. It is interesting that within our own immediate South Pacific region, the only countries that have signed have been New Zealand, Vanuatu and Western Samoa. Real problems will be created, in our opinion, by Australian ratification when it comes to the joint operation of our military forces with those of our allies.

We are immediately conscious of the arrangements for the allied forces in the Gulf at the moment. If two contributing forces, say Australia and the United States of America, are participating, basically under a different set of rules, one can imagine the practical difficulties that will occur which could put one party to that alliance under obligations that it would regard as intolerable. The interoperability of our forces with those of our allies has to be considered and that is why, if Australia is to ratify this protocol, we believe that it is important that we do so with our principal allies. Certainly, they are unlikely to do so without the sort of reservations that we put to the Government and that I will mention in a moment.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) acknowledged the difficulties in the protocol when he wrote to President Reagan, when he was in office a little time ago, and referred to the number of ambiguities and operational complexities that come out of the protocol. I think that is something that is accepted by all. It is a question as to whether we are prepared to overlook those difficulties in a desire to meet the spirit of the protocol. We think that is something that is too dangerous when we are talking about the lives and capability of our armed forces.

I do not think anyone would argue that the protocol is not extremely legalistic in parts and also vague in other parts. When we look at the very serious consequences of breaching the protocol, then we recognise the major difficulties that are being put before our armed forces. In many ways we are also concerned as to whether the nature of our defence equipment, particularly the strike assets such as the F111s and the submarines and their capacity, is incompatible with aspects of the protocol. If we were inhibited in using such assets or in having the potential to use such assets with a capability of attacking the bases and infrastructure of aggressors, then we would regard that restriction as intolerable and we are not prepared to place that upon our armed forces.

Apart from those general concerns, there are a number of specific provisions of the protocol that cause us difficulty. Article 1.4 is one such example which provides that the protocol shall apply to certain types of wars of liberation. It states:

Under this article, the provisions of the Protocol apply to ``armed conflicts in which peoples are fighting against colonial domination and alien occupation and against racist regimes in the exercise of their right of self-determination''.

We are concerned with this term `alien occupation' because it has no settled meaning in international law. We are also concerned that, by including so-called wars of liberation within the obligations of this protocol, we are in some ways lifting the status of such conflicts and blurring the traditional distinction between international and civil wars. That is something that causes us concern in the longer term because in some ways it can be interpreted as giving a legitimacy to such conflicts. I know there is always great difficulty in distinguishing between a terrorist and a freedom fighter. It is one area in which we are happy to err on the side of conservatism. We look to ways of resolving particularly internal disputes but also, of course, all disputes if at all possible by peaceful means. To raise the status of such wars and in some way to accept their legitimacy by incorporating them within such a document, we think, sets an undesirable precedent.

Articles 20, 51.6, 52.1, 54.4, 55.2 and 56.4 contain a blanket prohibition against the right of reprisal. That causes us concern. In our opinion the prohibition conflicts fundamentally with the right of self-defence which is recognised in Article 51 of the United Nations Charter. There is, of course, a settled right of collective self-defence in an effort to answer aggression. It is a right that is widely accepted as well as contained within the Charter. Often the mere threat of reprisal can be an effective way of bringing an end to breaches of international law and of influencing a potential aggressor not to carry out such aggression. We very much regret any inclusion within domestic law that would inhibit that capacity to threaten retaliation and arguably these provisions would do so. Therefore, they arguably could be more likely to contribute to aggression and violence rather than to dissuade such unsatisfactory conduct.

Article 35.2 forbids the use of weaponry which might cause superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering. Obviously, superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering is not something a government of a country such as ours with the basic values that we have, or our armed forces, would wish to inflict. But when one thinks about it, it places an incredibly difficult burden upon our armed forces to decide whether a particular action they are going to take in the interests of protecting our interests might have that effect. This element of subjectivity, inherent in the article, causes us great concern. Just in passing, it is a matter of interest that it is not present in the French translation of the protocol. I presume that it is a matter of language rather than any intended position.

Article 56.1 prohibits attacks against dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations. Again, generally, those sorts of resources are not such which we would readily attack in a war situation. It is commendable that the alliance forces in the Gulf have not attacked dams. I think one dam, if breached, has the capacity to do enormous damage to Baghdad. It is understandable, in some circumstances, that these objects will have a military facilitation and it might be in the best interests in the longer term of bringing the war to an earlier end and thus alleviating unnecessary suffering to attack such targets.

What concerns us is that that flexibility is lost and we have faith that our armed forces, again consistent with the values that they are seeking to uphold, would be able to adequately weigh the military utility of attacking such targets against the cost and loss to the public. But the draftsmen of this protocol obviously do not feel that they can rely on that. I guess that, in many ways, our concern with the document as a whole is that it is those upon whom we would like to see this document imposed who are probably going to least take note of it when it comes to a moment of decision.

I do acknowledge that article 56.1 is qualified in some ways by the introduction of the words `normal function'-in other words, the protection is to be removed where the normal function of the installation is to provide regular, significant and direct support for military operations. But I do not think that resolves the dilemma that is faced by the decision makers at the head of our armed forces at these moments of great difficulty.

Article 44.3 deals with the way in which certain combatants should distinguish themselves from the civilian population. We are concerned with that because they are given protections under this protocol and treated as combatants, not if they wear uniforms or are otherwise clearly defined but, as I read it, simply by adequately displaying their arms. One could understand that, in a guerilla situation, that would impose great difficulties upon our forces and we are not prepared to be parties to implementation of laws that have that effect.

Articles 48, 49.1 and 49.2 prescribe the distinction between civilian and military objectives with a view to extending the protection afforded to the civilian population in times of armed conflict. Whilst we laud the spirit of those provisions again we draw to attention the fact that it will, in practical circumstances, often be very difficult to draw the distinctions that are so easy to write on paper and to incorporate in a document of this kind. Again, we are not prepared to place that unreasonable burden upon the decision makers at the head of our armed forces.

Under article 48, nations are obliged at all times to distinguish between the civilian population and combatants and between civilian objects and military objects, and to direct military operations only against military objects. As I said, it is fine in the reading of it but there will be times when it places an impossible dilemma upon those who have to make that judgment in the heat of battle.

Articles 52 and 57 prohibit attacks which may cause `incidental loss of civilian life'. Again, no-one wishes to see the loss of civilians in times of armed conflict, least of all those who share our basic human values and have respect for human life and the dignity of each and every human life. But there will always be civilian casualties in any conflict and there will always be incidental loss of human lives, but we hope that they will not be deliberate. We would abhor the deliberate targeting of civilians, but that is not the question in point. It is very difficult to impose the obligation upon our military forces that they will be prohibited from causing incidental loss of human life.

Article 51.4 prohibits indiscriminate attacks which, under article 52, include those which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians and damage to civilian objects which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated. Similar language is included in article 57.2. If one contemplates trying to make that decision in terms of the precision of that language, it can easily be seen how impossible the task is that we are setting those who have to interpret these provisions in a moment of great trauma. We believe that the language goes beyond the intended simple codification of the principle of proportionality by which nations are obliged to conduct military operations so as not to cause unwarranted damage to civilian objects.

Article 82, which obliges nations to ensure that legal advisers are available at all times to advise military commanders of their obligations under the protocol, is in our opinion simply unreal. It just seems to have been written out of all context with reality.

The Government has proposed that a declaration of understanding be lodged on ratification with reference to aspects of articles 5, 44, 51, 52 and 57. But a declaration of understanding is an interpretive measure and does not alter Australia's obligations under the protocol. Unlike the lodging of a reservation, which is the form that we have suggested, it would have no influence on the judgment of Australia's actions in international law. Such a declaration of understanding would not address the protocol's fundamental problems of lack of realism and ambiguity, and we therefore reject it.

It is disappointing that the Government has taken the view that any reservations to the protocol would be incompatible with its objects and would therefore not be permissible under article 19(c) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties. It does seem to us to be simply a convenient argument because of the nations that have ratified the protocol. Many have, in fact, lodged reservations in order to address their concerns about the ambiguities within the protocol.

The Opposition has therefore come to the view, as I said at the outset, that it cannot support this legislation. We regret that our efforts to persuade the Government to express reservations have not been fruitful and we regret that we are not able to give the bipartisan support that we would otherwise have wished to give when an Australian government enters into such an obligation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990 attempts-and I think with the support of the Australian Democrats it is going to be a successful attempt-to bring into operation protocol I, which is additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 and relating to the protection of victims of international armed conflicts. It seems to me that, no matter what else is said, the objectives of this Convention are the most laudable that we have discussed in this chamber for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand what Senator Hill has said, he is in sympathy with the general thrust of what is attempted here to give protection to civilians who are slaughtered-and that is not too strong a word-in wars. It is an attempt by the United Nations-to which we recently said that we give such adherence as to be more than admirable; in whose name we are now at war in the Gulf; of which we have been a member since the Second World War; and which is to be the foundation of the new world order-to try to spare, as much as is practicable, victims of any particular war.

3 The protocol has been ratified by 88 states, including members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO)-countries such as Denmark, Norway, Italy, Iceland, Canada, Greece and Spain. The Opposition finds that, because of some niceties of language, it is not able to pass legislation relating to that sort of convention.

The argument put by Senator Hill in his usual forceful manner would mean really that we would not pass the Ten Commandments if they came before this chamber because they had not been precisely identified. One of the Ten Commandments says: Thou shalt not kill. On Senator Hill's argument, we would say, `We really cannot pass that lot. We certainly have the most sympathetic approach to what you are trying to do, Moses. But, really, you have not put into proper language what you mean by not killing, because we may have to defend ourselves'. And properly so. If somebody rushed into the chamber with a gun, and I had a gun, I am sure I would shoot back.

I see in the chamber a member of our military forces, a proud instrument of this land. But we would have to say to Moses, `We cannot pass this because you have not made enough exceptions; you have not been precise about it. We cannot pass this, unfortunately'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to read the fine print.

—Yes, we would have to read the fine print and there is a bit of that. But even if we look at the fine print, it could be said that it is not taken far enough. Then we could say to Moses, `Look, you have got a thing here which says that you cannot steal'. I see that Senator MacGibbon is in the chamber. He would say that imposing taxes would be some form of larceny, so we would have to make some exception for that. We would go on and say, `Do not covet your neighbour's goods'. One could say that we have all sorts of problems about that because at times we have to confiscate goods for the country. Unfortunately, on the argument put by Senator Hill, the Ten Commandments would not get through this chamber. The same could be said about the Magna Carta, which again is a statement of general principles, and the Bill of Rights. None of them would get through-not even the Constitution of this country would get through. Of course, the Constitution is most unclear because it is a general statement of principles to be read in the light of what everybody knows is the general thrust and details which need to be obtained can be fleshed out later. It would be absolutely impossible to produce a document that satisfies what Senator Hill was trying to put.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody knows what we are talking about. It is a general statement of the sorts of things that we as a nation, and the United Nations representing the general world community, want to see if the disaster of war occurs. Senator Hill says, `Well, look, what about the poor military commander? What about the poor government?'. Well, what about the poor people who are largely powerless to do anything about war, whether they are in a democracy such as ours or a dictatorship such as that of Saddam Hussein's?

The fact of the matter is that constitutionally, under the Westminster system, we go to war not on the vote on the Parliament but on the say so of the Prime Minister of the day. That is how we went to war in 1939 and that is how we went to war on this occasion.
