To my mind, simply to say, `Look, we as a leadership can impose upon the people a war, do nothing to somehow protect them'-whether they are in the armed service or whether they are the civilians who accept, because they have to, the raining down of bombs-`and give them absolutely no protection except some sort of vague analogous to common law approach that after the war we might do something about people who have perpetrated these evils' is just out of all proportion to the sorts of terrors we expect them to face.

This protocol, with all its faults-and Senator Hill has gone through them-does that. What we are saying if we do not pass this protocol is this: it is more important to protect the anxiety which military chiefs might suffer in deciding whether or not to make an attack than it is to protect the citizens of the country against whom war is being waged.

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously do not agree with it. Why on earth are you trying?
—Senator Walters says that I do not agree with this protocol. Of course I agree with this protocol. I agree because I am in good company with 88 nations around the world.
—I hope you are not going to Baghdad with Bill.

—I will take this up. This is the argument that is put: Senator Alston is saying that an honourable senator who gets up in this chamber and supports the Geneva Conventions is somehow giving solace to Baghdad. This is what is being put by the Opposition, through the words of Senator Alston: it is somehow traitorous if an honourable senator supports this Convention; that somehow comfort is being given to people like Saddam Hussein. The fact of the matter is that this Convention will be passed through this House with the agreement and consent of Australia's own military forces. It seems to me to be absurd that the Opposition would come into this chamber tonight and say, as it has now said through Senator Alston, that our own military forces-the Navy, Army and Air Force-are traitors because, in agreeing to this Convention, they are giving comfort to Saddam Hussein.

SPEECH.PARA: What other interpretation could we take from the remark, `Go to Baghdad with Baghdad Bill', that was made by way of interjection to my support of the Convention? The only inference that could come from that statement is that all these people who have supported this Convention are somehow traitors-that includes the United Nations itself and NATO. The statement made here, by inference, by the Opposition through one of its senior shadow Ministers is this: NATO, the countries of Denmark, Norway, Italy, Iceland, Canada, Greece and Spain are traitors; that our armed forces are traitors. What a statement to make that these people are traitors--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are the legal advisers on the Australian ships?

—Senator Walters then says, `Well look, there is some difficulty because it is said that there ought to be legal advisers'. Of course there should be legal advisers. It does not mean to say that legal advisers have to be next to the gun saying, `Look, you can shoot this round'. I will read article 82 which deals with legal advisers in armed forces, because it is another indication of how the Opposition has twisted the logic. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The High Contracting Parties at all times, and the Parties to the conflict in time of armed conflict, shall ensure that legal advisers are available, when necessary-
which Senator Hill seems to have left out-
to advise military commanders at the appropriate level on the application of the Conventions and this Protocol and on the appropriate instruction to be given to the armed forces on this subject.

`Appropriate' is the word used; `when necessary' is the phrase used. It means that it should not be simply up to the military command or even to the Prime Minister-if that is the person involved-the president or the dictator, simply to decide how these conventions should work. The article says that it should be given a proper legal interpretation so that the meaning of this Convention should be clear.

When the Convention is properly read, there is no suggestion that there should be interference by legal people in the actual theatre of conflict. The question of the general thrust and the way the armed forces are being used in terms of their compliance or otherwise with this Convention should be answered with legal advice. Article 57 was attacked because it states:
In the conduct of military operations, constant care shall be taken to spare the civilian population, civilians and civilian objects.

That is exactly what President Bush has been saying-I accept his views on this matter-in reference to the bombing of the shelter, which has brought headlines such as `Backlash on civilian deaths' in the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 February 1991. Of course there was a backlash, and there should have been. The President of the United States came out and said, `Of course we did not mean to kill the civilian population, civilians and civilian objects', yet the Opposition is opposing the proposition to which President Bush agreed.
In opposing article 57, the Opposition is clearly opposing the very concepts that President Bush has proclaimed. Article 57 (2) reads:
With respect to attacks, the following precautions shall be taken:
(a) those who plan or decide upon an attack shall:
(i) do everything feasible
I stress the word `feasible'-
to verify that the objectives to be attacked are neither civilians nor civilian objects . . .

Why would anyone oppose that proposition? Why is that so objectionable? Why in all humanity would anyone oppose that proposition? President Bush said, `We do everything feasible'. He complied with this, but not the Opposition. Article 57(2) (a) (ii) reads as follows:
take all feasible precautions in the choice of means and methods of attack . . .

Again, that subparagraph is opposed because article 57 is opposed. What is wrong with that? Why would anyone oppose that? Let us look at some of the other things that Senator Hill opposed. He said, `Article 20 talks about reprisals and we want to take reprisals'. Reprisals mean that people should not, as a matter of revenge, go and slaughter civilians. Why oppose that? It means that, if we did go to war and we won, we would not go around crucifying and abusing the citizens. That sort of thing has always been part of the process of war. We only have to look at the speech of King Henry V before Harfleur in Shakespeare. He comes out with that concept. He says:
What rein can hold licentious wickedness
When down the hill he holds his fierce career?
We may as bootless spend our vain command
Upon the enraged soldiers in their spoil . . .

He talks about the rape, the plunder and the spoil. In his day he objected to this. Article 20 talks about not taking reprisals on citizens in that sense, yet the Opposition opposes it. Members of the Opposition disagree with the President of the United States and would not pass the Ten Commandments. Shakespeare was well ahead of him in his day.
Article 56(1) reads:

Works or installations containing dangerous forces, namely dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations, shall not be made the object of attack, even where these objects are military objectives, if such attack may cause the release of dangerous forces and consequent severe losses among the civilian population. Other military objectives located at or in the vicinity of these works or installations shall not be made the object of attack if such attack may cause the release of dangerous forces from the works or installations and consequent severe losses among the civilian population.

Again, it is an admonition to balance. It says that we are not to go knocking these things down, blowing them up and releasing them upon the civilian population so as to cause not loss but severe loss. We are not to do that if the consequences of doing so are disproportionate to the consequences that follow. Article 56 (2) says:
The special protection against attack provided by paragraph 1 shall cease:

(a) for a dam or a dyke only if it is used for other than its normal function and in regular, significant and direct support of military operations and if such attack is the only feasible way to terminate such support;

I do not know why Senator Hill did not read subparagraph 2. It is easy enough to knock over straw men, but if the Opposition is going to object to this, for heaven's sake-and I say this advisedly; this is a matter of life and death and destruction to policy-look at the text and what it means and then oppose it, but do not oppose article 56(1) without looking at article 56(2) as well. Article 49(1) reads:
`Attacks' means acts of violence against the adversary, whether in offence or in defence.

The provisions of this Protocol with respect to attacks apply to all attacks in whatever territory conducted, including the national territory belonging to a Party to the conflict but under the control of an adverse Party.

Article 49 then talks about humanitarian protection contained in the Fourth Convention. Why oppose that when all it wants to do, in so far as it is possible, is bring some rules into the waging of war. If we have this instrument of doing business around the world, and given the history of the human race, it seems to me that we have always had wars and it looks as if we are going to have them in the future.

The world community says, `As a group of people, through the proper organisation, the United Nations, let us see if we can do something about this horrific instrument of policy, this terrible instrument of war, to modify the horrible, ghastly destruction that comes about'. What is wrong with that proposition? All of us in this chamber, without exception, agreed that after the Second World War there should be some sort of retribution on those who brought war upon the world. We must have come to that conclusion because we thought that the nazi regime acted in such an horrific way that the nations of the world ought to get together and do something about it.

In a certain sense we applied retrospective laws. We simply said that even though there was no world order at that time and no specific war set out, nevertheless a concept of common law was such as to provide a basis for doing something about it. It seems to me that we are in a much stronger position if the world community, through the United Nations, sets out the ground rules. That is what this article does. People are going to say, `We do not think article X is quite what we want, article Y is as precise as it might be, or article Z suits our particular side'. The world community has come together and, with all its faults, said, `We think the document in schedule 1 to the Bill sets out fair and reasonable rules to be guided by'. Because of some literal errors, because we feel this has been awkwardly expressed or because it might not cover everything we want, why should we reject the great good this could do to gain some sort of leverage and improve what we want in future legislation?

Clearly, we ought to pass this legislation and, if we think something should be changed, we will change it, as we do through this Parliament. The United Nations meets regularly. Oftentimes we pass Acts that we intend to amend. Indeed, an example of this chamber passing legislation which it is not happy with is the legislation on occupational health and safety. The Opposition did not oppose that legislation, but its members said, `In the give and take of this place, and the give and take of legislation, we will put that through and fix it up later'. That is an important Bill, but for heaven's sake how much more important is this, which sets out rules and regulations which may save thousands-indeed millions-of lives in the way in which wars are conducted? It may save property and great and glorious buildings which symbolise the greatness of the human race-buildings such as the Taj Mahal, St Peters in Rome, St Pauls in London or the Louvre in Paris.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Melbourne Cricket Ground.

—Yes, the Melbourne Cricket Ground-or the Angkor Wat. It is just a matter of balancing what is to be gained against what is to be lost. I do not for one minute doubt that members of the Opposition hate and detest war and the death and destruction it causes as much as anybody else in this chamber, but because of overcaution and an overly legalistic approach-perhaps even too great a fear that everything has not been covered-they have lost a great opportunity to take advancement. I used the Ten Commandments in a serious way because they set out precepts which have reverberated throughout the ages to now. The Magna Carta, the Bill of Rights and the American Declaration of Independence were flawed documents in the sense that they were not perfectly expressed, but they have all added magnificently to the culture we enjoy. They have added to the great inspirations and aspirations of humankind.

SPEECH.PARA: This document is of lesser quality than some of those, but it gives us something to go forward with. It is terribly disappointing that, because of overcaution and a lack of vision on this occasion, the Opposition opposes the legislation. This is an historic document and to be recorded on the books as having opposed it will not go well when the history of the good people on the other side is written.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise, I am sure, to those who know the history of the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill to discover that the Australian Democrats give it our unequivocal support. The Bill is identical to the one the Government introduced in the House of Representatives in March 1989 but, because of the Opposition's criticism at the time, the Government decided to withdraw it. It should be said that the present AttorneyGeneral (Mr Duffy) really has tried to get total parliamentary support for this legislation but, given continuing opposition from the coalition, it is understandable that he has decided to introduce it regardless.

SPEECH.PARA: In fairness to Senator Hill and to the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock, I believe they have tried to reach a position of compromise with the Government on the matter, but unfortunately they felt it was not possible in the end. This is a pity, since we understand that the convention which eventually led to the finalisation of these protocols was in existence during the period Mr Peacock himself was the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Fraser Government.

As a result of the delays in bringing on this Bill, however, former Australian Democrats Senator Michael Macklin introduced his own private senator's Bill in August 1989 in an effort to get the Government to ratify the protocols updating these laws of war. I know that former Senator Macklin was very committed to the ratification of these protocols and it was a source of disappointment to him that debate on this Bill did not come on while he was still in the Senate. He is, I am sure, very pleased that we are finally debating the Bill tonight. This Bill seeks to give legislative effect to progress made in international forums in humanitarian law. The Democrats recognise that essentially these two protocols aim to restrict, as far as humanly possible, the horrors caused by warfare. This need has been accentuated in recent weeks by what we have seen taking place in the Middle East. International humanitarian law should be concerned with the lives and welfare of individual human beings in peace as well as in war.

The written law which deals with the fate of human beings during armed conflict has been developed over the past 120 years and the Bill before us is really only the latest addition to those laws. The most important of these laws was the Geneva conference of 1949, which resulted in four conventions being adopted. These have since been ratified by 145 nations. In 1977 the two protocols before us today were adopted and signed, following the diplomatic conferences of 1974 to 1977, by some 97 nations in the case of protocol I, and by some 87 nations in the case of protocol II. To date we understand that 88 countries have ratified these protocols.

These protocols were developed after much hard work by many organisations, especially the International Committee of the Red Cross, which we believe deserves some recognition for the results of its efforts in helping to bring about the legislation before us. Our understanding is that the Australian delegation was very active throughout the conference from 1974 to 1977, and that Australian representatives, both military and civilian, made important contributions to the compromise process and to the overall and eventual success of the conference.

The Geneva protocols, as opposed to the Geneva Convention, deal in greater detail with matters such as civil defence, protection of medical, religious and media personnel, protection of children in particular and other civilians, and use of distinctive emblems such as the Red Cross. Most notably the Bill before us seeks to extend the provisions of the four Geneva Conventions and to introduce new principles. For instance, these protocols incorporate the new and important concept that the principles of law governing armed conflicts between nations should apply also to conflicts between the armed forces of a state and organised dissident forces within state boundaries. Understandably, this expansion of the Geneva protocol to include conflicts within a state's boundaries has met resistance from some nations and indeed has not been ratified for precisely this reason. Protocol I applies international humanitarian law to armed conflicts:
. . . in which peoples are fighting against colonial domination and alien occupation and against racial regimes in the exercise of their right to self determination.

Given the nature of some of the regimes that both the superpowers have supported in the past, it is not difficult to work out why both the United States (US) and the Soviet Union have opposed ratification. The irony is that, during the conferences in 1977, the United States played a very active role in ensuring that the protocols were adopted by consensus. At the time of the conference both the United States and Australia signed the protocols. Since then the United States seems to have withdrawn its support and we can only assume, given the pronouncements of the US military, that the Pentagon feels that the first protocol would restrict defence forces too severely in conducting their operations.

Despite the opposition of some nations, however, these conventions may be seen as almost a complete consolidation of written international humanitarian law applying to armed conflicts. Like the 1949 Geneva Conventions, the protocols before us today strike a balance between military necessity and humanitarian considerations. Rules of humanitarian law are always the result of a most complex process of compromise between demands for an effective national defence on the one hand and the common will to uphold certain human values even in war on the other. The international conferences held in the 1970s to develop these protocols were no different. It was a long and arduous process of negotiation and, yes, there was some compromise to reach an outcome that was acceptable to as many nations as possible.

Despite this, we find it difficult to accept that the first protocol is a controversial document. The provisions for the protection of medical services in times of warfare, for instance, or relating to the search for missing persons, or relief action for civilians, are all important additions to the Geneva Conventions. The underlying principles of this law are that the human dignity of all individuals must be respected at all times and that everything possible should be done to reduce the suffering of those who take direct part in the conflict or have been put out of action because of wounds or captivity.

Unfortunately, as we have seen in recent weeks in the Gulf war, there will always be some regimes, such as the Iraqi one, which have little or no respect for such principles. The treatment of captured military personnel by the Iraqi regime blatantly contravenes the provisions of the Geneva Convention. The behaviour and attitude of Iraq in relation to those prisoners of war and Iraq's indiscriminate bombing of civilian populations in both Israel and Saudi Arabia cannot be condemned too strongly.

We respect the reasons the Opposition has given for opposing this Bill, but we remain unconvinced by its arguments. The Opposition's claim that ratification would hamper the armed forces conflicts with the view held by most in Australia's military that Australia could be involved in a war without any difficulty in meeting our obligations under these protocols. Again, we must emphasise that these provisions have all been drafted with the active participation of military experts from all major countries, including Australia and the United States of America.

It would be hard to accept that Australian military personnel were involved in the development of a protocol with which they always disagreed. In fact, virtually the opposite is the case, with Australian military personnel not only actively involved in developing these protocols but also giving their positive endorsement to Australia being one of the first signatories. We also have the encouraging situation where more than half the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries, including Denmark, Italy, Canada, Spain, Norway and Greece, have already ratified the protocols. Given this background, it is hard to understand why opposition from some sections of this Parliament still continues. Indeed, I would have thought that the use of terms such as `feasible' and `as far as possible' in the attached articles and protocols give military commanders the necessary latitude to take into account virtually any specific circumstance.

Under these circumstances, we find it difficult to accept that a Bill which aims to give additional protection for the victims of warfare should be met with opposition. Since the Menzies Government ratified the original 1949 Geneva Convention, Australia has had a very good record in showing concern for the fate of the civilian population in times of war. Indeed, one of the reasons for our good reputation overseas is that we have been such ardent supporters of improved international humanitarian law. The Democrats believe that we should now ratify both the protocols and thereby show the electorate and our neighbours that this country is willing to accept binding obligations of a strictly humanitarian nature. Australia's ratification of these protocols will cement our commitment to limiting the scope of war to military objectives only, while at the same time strengthening the provisions which give protection to civilians and to prisoners of war.

Despite the fact that the United States, the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union have to date not signed these protocols, global support overall has been strong. If Australia failed to approve this Bill, it would be setting a deplorable precedent. It would in fact be the first time in history that a Red Cross humanitarian treaty was rejected by this Parliament. We look forward to the passage of this Bill and to the signing of these protocols by Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill. It is quite disturbing to hear the arguments that have been put forward by Senator Cooney and Senator Bourne. It is very worrying to think that a vote will be taken on this amendment and that the Australian Democrats in particular do not understand what they are voting on and the implications of that vote.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition does not oppose this Bill lightly. We would, however, be failing in our responsibility to Australia's armed forces and security if we agreed to certain articles of a protocol that could weaken our alliances and make the job of our service personnel that much harder. These protocols are additional to the 1949 Geneva Convention, already enshrined in Australian law, and seek to elaborate on the protection given to civilian populations in times of conflict. In this proper objective they have created ambiguities that can only cause problems for our armed forces. It distresses me that both the Government and the Democrats are not aware of those ambiguities and do not want to try to resolve that before rushing into agreeing to this amendment.

There are 102 articles and 63 pages of the protocols, and most of these are fully supported by the coalition. These include medical care of the wounded and bans on experiments on internees. All honourable senators would support the proposition that the medical needs of an occupied civilian population should be provided and that the deliberate bombing of civilian targets is wrong. While we may regard certain articles as impractical and by extension dangerous, the coalition firmly upholds accepted humanitarian restraints on the conduct of war on the hopefully rare occasions when this becomes necessary.

By the nature of our society and national character, Australia already stands committed to the decent treatment of defenceless and innocent people, and ratifying the protocols will make no difference. Essential humanitarian provisions are already part of Australian law through the Fourth Geneva Convention and this will remain regardless of the fate of this Bill.

What disturbs me, however, are the ramifications of article 48, headed, `Basic Rules'. This directs parties to a conflict to distinguish at all times between civilian and military objectives so that they `accordingly shall direct their operations only against military objectives'. That is all very desirable, but it is all very impractical. We know that that in real life is an impossibility. The word `only' will cause severe practical difficulties for military commanders when a ruthless and cynical enemy of the stamp of Saddam Hussein deliberately surrounds a military installation with civilian facilities. Therein lies one grave concern that we cannot simply brush under the carpet. I am sorry that Senator Bourne has already left the chamber. Maybe she would understand that what has happened in recent weeks is a problem that will only be exacerbated by this Bill.

Article 51 of protocol I has a similar uncertainty in prohibiting attacks on military objectives which may cause incidental civilian casualties `excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated'. This can only hamper the efforts of our armed services in conjunction with our allies to destroy the military capacity of an enemy as swiftly as possible and avoid the horrors of a prolonged conflict. It is an open invitation to ensure, in light of the events of recent weeks, that a baby milk plant is placed beside every chemical weapons establishment. That is what we are looking at. It will make the situation absolutely and utterly absurd and unworkable.

It is a sad if unpalatable truth that if a liberal democracy is forced to wage war for its own survival or, as in the present circumstances, for collective security, the most humane war policy is to destroy the capacity of the enemy to wage war, and as quickly as possible. For this reason, I have to query the impact of article 56, which decrees that dams, for example, should not be attacked, `even when these objects are military objectives', should civilian losses eventuate. It is an impossibility. It is illogical. Where would this have placed the World War II dambusters? Service personnel must not be exposed to allegations of war crimes when simply carrying out the necessary destruction of enemy infrastructure.

When the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) states correctly and properly that some Iraqi civilian casualties are inevitable in the task of freeing Kuwait, it behoves this Government to think carefully before committing Australia to a convention that could tie the hands of Australian servicemen in such a situation. It is one of the grim facts of history that in 1944 President Roosevelt, in the planning of the Normandy landings, insisted on the bombing of Nazi communications in occupied France even at the cost of thousands of civilian casualties. The bombing was an immense strategic success, but 10,000 French civilians died and as many as 40,000 deaths were feared. This was a terrible decision that had to be made but who are we to argue that it was mistaken or immoral when it saved the lives of allied servicemen, shortened the war and liberated France from a very real tyranny? We are more fortunate in 1991 that western military technology can greatly limit civilian casualties. But there will inevitably be losses when Hitler's adoring disciple, Saddam Hussein, holds the lives of his own people in absolute and utter contempt. In the face of this tragic reality it is not only impractical but also immoral to tie the hands of the military.

When we have a situation where article 82 insists that commanders be provided with legal advice while planning operations, it becomes apparent to many of us that we are denigrating our service professionals. That is what has happened in this exercise. It is the legal servicemen and not the commanders and the people out in the field who have given the Government advice. With all due respect to the legal officers in this situation, the commanders and the people out in the field are the people we should be listening to. Surely there are already enough career openings for lawyers in modern society. It might be thought more appropriate for a commander in a genuine moral dilemma to seek advice from a chaplain, not a legal officer. Legal advice will become necessary only when commanders are hampered by more than the usual constraints of commonsense and common humanity.

Although the Government may be told by the legal section of the Department of Defence that it can live with the protocols, the Australian Defence Force Journal of January and February 1991 draws a discreet distinction between the provision of advice and full support for a proposition. Can the Government deny that Australia's front-line service people do not have serious concerns as to the impact of the protocols? I would be very interested to hear the Minister's response to that very question. I do not believe that it can say that it has no concerns. It is in the nature of servicemen and women in a democracy that they do not speak out against government policy, but it should not be abused. It becomes all the more necessary for a responsible government not to proceed until such fears are resolved and those people who are literally prepared to die for Australia do not in any way believe that their danger faced in combat will be increased.

Those honourable senators who support this Bill fall into two categories. In the first category are most government members, who would not wish to see our armed services rendered less effective, but consider that the protocols pose no practical difficulties. Therein lies the distinction between us and them because we do see the practical difficulties. We are not for one moment suggesting that the Government is intentionally trying to put more pressure on the service personnel, but there are practical working difficulties. The Government had better be right because we, in the coalition, would prefer not to take any risk whatsoever.

In the second category are those on the far Left, including of course the Australian Democrats, who are hellbent on hampering our armed services in the task of defending freedom for Australians, Kuwaitis or anyone else. They are more than happy to see those who resist international outlaws fight with one hand tied behind their backs. The sooner the Democrats get out of this type of argument, the better off the country will be.

Before we ratify the protocols, we should look closely at which nations have taken this step as distinct from merely signing them. That is the issue I take on with Senator Cooney. He said that all eight nations had signed them. Very few nations within our region have ratified the protocols; neither have the leading western military nations with whom we must realistically expect to cooperate. Clearly, the United States of America and Britain have not ratified the protocols-Senator Cooney said that President Bush had ratified them-because they foresee the same practical difficulties outlined earlier. A government that, to its credit, has aligned Australia beside these nations in the cause of justice ought to be more alive to the possibility of such cooperation being impaired. What might happen if Australian naval units under overall United States command are ordered to fire on enemy shore installations where there may be some risk of civilian casualties? I stress that the problem will arise not because we adhere to a higher standard of moral conduct but because of the stupid ambiguities of those articles that I mentioned earlier.

Of those nations that have actually ratified the protocols, some in Europe and the West Indies are in areas safe from external military threat and thus removed from the dreadful practicalities of war. Others are nations whose records show that they have no intention whatsoever of adhering to the protocols or indeed the original and basic decencies of the Geneva Convention. The classic example is Iraq, which is blatantly violating the rights of prisoners of war and murdering Israeli and Kuwaiti civilians. Yet the Democrats and the Government support this. I simply urge a rethink.

The most practical means of protecting civilians, apart from the values of common decency that do not need to be gleaned from the protocols, is the advance of military technology that can minimise injury to civilians because targeting is so precise. Those who scream at the cost of military hardware should bear this lesson in mind.

I conclude by stating that it will be a shame upon this Parliament if any Australian serviceman or woman is killed through the effect of legalistic constraints placed on commanders in combat. We cannot afford that luxury and I, as an Australian and as a member of this Parliament, do not want to see that as the net result. Ratifying these protocols will not give any practical additional protection to the civilian victims of war but it may just jeopardise the safety of our armed forces, the quality of our defence cooperation and the duty to bring hostilities to a swift and just conclusion.

I find it interesting to hear the sanctimonious claptrap, particularly of the Australian Democrats, about bringing our servicemen and women home. The Democrats, by their support of this Bill, quite clearly do not give a continental about what happens to our servicemen and women because they are placing them in a very unenviable position. I therefore urge the Government to think again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill. I support it very strongly. It is a credit to the Government that it has brought forth this Bill. I trust it will be passed by the Parliament. It will go on the international record as a further achievement of this Parliament and the Australian Government in the issue of human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly interested to hear some of the remarks of Senator Knowles. I did not have the opportunity of hearing Senator Hill's remarks because I was at a meeting. But I am astonished that anybody in the Australian Parliament could oppose this Bill. I thought this would have gone through unanimously.

I find it particularly interesting that Senator Hill is opposing this Bill. I have not known Senator Hill long, but over the years I have known him he has been a hard and tireless worker on human rights issues around the world. I find it strange that he has to stand up in this Parliament to oppose this Bill. I suspect, looking at the list of the other speakers from the Opposition, that Senator Hill was rolled inside the coalition party room. When one sees that Senator Knowles, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Bishop are the ones leading the charge to oppose this Bill, one gets a fair idea that the extreme right of the Liberal Party of Australia has again triumphed over the moderate leadership of the Liberal Party. I do not think Senator Hill would want too many examples of this sort of decision of the coalition which is against the image that it is trying to create.

I did not hear Senator Hill's remarks to justify his position. I will read Hansard tomorrow with interest. After hearing Senator Knowles's remarks, I am even more astonished at the paucity of the Opposition's arguments in opposing this Bill.

First of all, I want to point out to the Opposition that, as I understand it, in March 1988 Senator Durack wrote to the Red Cross in Australia saying that the Opposition gave a strong commitment to the ideals of the Geneva Convention and supported this proposal. I cannot recollect whether Senator Durack was then a shadow Minister or not, but he certainly is and always has been a very senior member of the coalition. He was a former Attorney-General of Australia. He was willing to write in March 1988 to the Red Cross of Australia saying that the Opposition supported this proposal.

Obviously even Senator Durack-who, I do not think by any description, could be called a wet within the Liberal Party-was willing to support it but he has been rolled by the conservatives of the Liberal Party. I find it very strange indeed. In the years to come, the coalition will be haunted by the decision to oppose this Bill.

I listened with interest to Senator Knowles's remarks. She tried to pick some articles out of the Bill to support her argument that this Convention puts at risk Australian service people in carrying out their duties in the defence of Australia or in military action. She particularly quoted article 56 and said that it was prohibited to attack certain installations because they could be considered civilian targets and so on. She quoted article 56-and this is what she was referring to, I would imagine-which states:
Protection of works and installations containing dangerous forces

. . . Works or installations containing dangerous forces, namely dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations, shall not be made the object of attack, even where these objects are military objectives-
She did not quote the next phrase-the qualifying phrase-which says:
if such attack may cause the release of dangerous forces and consequent severe losses amongst the civilian population.

Clearly, it is qualified. Clearly, it is left as a matter of judgment for the military forces about whether such an attack can take place. Senator Knowles should not quote selectively from the article, because when she does, she forgets the qualification.

It has taken years of discussion and debate in the international forums of the world to draw up articles to cover the points that Senator Knowles was trying to make. She may have a point if some of the clauses that she failed to quote were removed. But I ask her please not to quote selectively from a particular clause and leave out a subordinate explanation.

One of the things that Senator Knowles and the Liberal Party have failed to mention is the importance of this protocol in an area that has not been dealt with before-the question of a civil war. Protocol II for the first time attempts-and, I think, quite successfully-to say that where there is a civil war within a country, the people affected have some rights to protection. I quote from the second reading speech of the Minister as follows:

Protocol II applies to situations of non-international armed conflicts between the armed forces of a Party and organised armed groups exercising some territorial control over territory of that Party. It does not apply to internal tensions, or disturbances such as riots or sporadic acts of violence.

Since the end of the Second World War most of the wars in this world would be called internal-civil wars. Unfortunately, there have been scores of them, probably close to 50 or 60, around the world over the last 40-odd years. In every case civilian populations have suffered disastrously in those wars because either side has chosen to attack the civilian population on the grounds that it believes the civilian population is a resource which the other side can use to help in that civil war.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ethiopia.

—Yes, I will mention Ethiopia and I will mention Eritrea. I must say to Senator Walters that if this protocol that is now being adopted had been agreed to by the Ethiopian regime of, first of all, Emperor Haile Selassie followed by Colonel Mengistu, hundreds of thousands of people would now not be dead in that country. It has been a practice of the Mengistu regime, and of the Haile Selassie regime before that, to terror bomb civilian populations that have no connection with the Eritrean Peoples Liberation Front armed forces. They bomb at will; they bomb as part of their campaigns.
—They will not let the Red Cross in. They have thrown the Red Cross out.
—Order on my left, please.
—Senator Michael Baume says that they will not let the Red Cross in.
—Or the Red Crescent.

—It does not matter which one-neither will let either in. But if they were let in, what they would see is an effort made by the Mengistu regime to use terror tactics against its own civilian population. There is nothing in the international code to prevent that from happening, other than a moral force of someone like me standing up in this Parliament, far away, saying how terrible it is. Well, it is terrible. But I would say that if one asked the Eritreans, who have been the sufferers in this war for 30 years-of terror bombing, first of all by Haile Selassie and now by the Mengistu regime-they would say that they want these protocols signed because they say they do everything possible to follow them through.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite may laugh. They may well be right to laugh and say that I have got all this wrong. But I would point out to them that I did not see any of them volunteering to visit Eritrea.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't touch them for a ticket to get there.

—I made my own arrangements to get to Eritrea. It would be instructive for Senator MacGibbon as he is always interested in military matters. I would have thought that he might have been the first one to go there and see military weapons in operation. It may appeal to his blood lust to go to Ethiopia and Eritrea and see the use of weapons in a major conventional war that has been going on for 30 years. But if Senator MacGibbon did go--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Schacht is speaking to the Senate. Opposition senators were heard in silence.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. What I want to say about the situation, as I tried to say before despite the interjections, is that if we ask the Eritreans we find that they do try to carry out their obligations, even though they are not formal signatories to the Geneva accords. They are a rebel force that controls a substantial amount of territory and a substantial amount of the population. As a result, they have close to 20,000 Ethiopian prisoners of war.

SPEECH.PARA: But when one asks the Ethiopians how many prisoners of war from Eritrea they have, the answer is none. Why? Because the Eritreans, when they are captured, are executed. That is because, under international law, Mengistu is not obliged to give any recognition to the legitimacy of the fact that in this civil war the Eritreans are entitled to some protection.

I would say that in this example-and I have seen this first hand-protocol No. 2 would be a very useful development. I do not expect someone like Mengistu to take much notice of it, but at least it is a start to try to improve international order in this world.

Another area which some people may say is not relevant in this context but which is mentioned in the schedule is the situation in South Africa. Apartheid is specifically mentioned in the protocols as an inhumane system. When I was recently in South Africa I spoke to a number of African National Congress people who had spent long periods on Robbin Island. I asked them how they were treated. They said that when they were first arrested, sentenced and sent to prison in the 1960s because of their opposition to apartheid they were treated as criminals. For example, they were not given shoes or socks, they were given no proper bedding and were forced to carry out a number of activities which were harsh and in- humane; they often suffered beatings. But they said that during the 1970s and 1980s under international pressure the South African Government, without actually conceding the point, started to treat them as prisoners of war. They said that when that started occurring their treatment improved considerably.

By the 1980s, although they were still imprisoned on Robbin Island or elsewhere in South Africa, their treatment improved because unofficially the South African Government conceded that they were prisoners of war and not criminals. Therefore, where internal disturbances occur and lead to civil war and where people because of oppression do not consent to be governed, if we can lay down as part of the international order that the ability to protect such people will be enhanced, I think that will be all for the better.

I am astonished that the Opposition would seek to oppose this Bill covering this Convention. I think that it will enhance Australia's reputation no end in the world. It will add a further instrument to our foreign policy in favour of human rights. Naturally, I expect some members of the Opposition, who have not overly covered themselves with glory on human rights issues, to oppose this legislation. They will use the furphy that this means we shall restrict the way in which our armed forces can defend this country in a state of war.

I have read the protocols and see nothing in them which provides that when we are legitimately defending our sovereignty, legitimately participating in such actions as the Gulf war sanctioned by United Nations resolution, we would be prohibited from carrying out the actions on which we are now embarked. If by some mischance a rogue member of the Australian defence forces carries out criminal acts of murder, we should be quite willing to ensure that that person is brought to book, charged and dealt with accordingly under the law. The definitions that have now been included enhance our reputation.

What distresses me somewhat is that Opposition members imply that our armed forces will be restricted. Indeed, they almost imply that those forces need these loose definitions to carry out war in a barbaric way against civilians and so on. I find that a slur on the professionalism of the Australian armed forces. In several wars at international level the Australian armed forces have covered themselves with glory in that they have not resorted generally or as a policy to the abuse of human rights, to attacking civilians deliberately. There have occasionally been instances where an individual has transgressed, but those instances have been dealt with. I think that it is a slur on the armed forces by the Opposition who believe that those forces cannot carry out their professional duties in accordance with the protocols outlined here, the amendment to protocol I and the adoption of protocol II. This Bill should be supported unanimously by the Parliament as it will bring greater recognition to this country for the honourable record that we already have of protecting human and civil rights in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of glaring errors of fact in Senator Schacht's pretence at a review of the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill that demand comment. I am afraid that it all stems from the fact that Senator Schacht's knowledge of military law, the rules of international armed combat and of the Geneva protocols is minuscule. It is not surprising because I imagine that a quarter of an hour ago he had not devoted any time to them. Certainly he has never had any involvement in this field before in his life. The closest that he has ever come to armed combat, I imagine, would be the grand final of an Australian rules match in Adelaide. To misrepresent the situation by saying that members of the Australian armed forces--
—I didn't see you tramping around Eritrea.

—If Senator Schacht puts me on the gratuitous travel list that the embassies of this town have him on and he gets tickets for me, I will go anywhere in the world, even with Senator Schacht as company. Until I see the colour of Senator Schacht's money, until he gets me those return first-class air tickets that he gets from embassies around town, he should withdraw his offer. He rarely goes anywhere where he pays for himself.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the point about which Senator Schacht is sensitive and quite ignorant; that is, anyone who has worn a uniform of the Australian armed services has always been covered by military law. Australian service personnel have never had a licence to operate without respect to military law any time they have worn that uniform. It is a gross distortion of the facts for Senator Schacht to claim that that is not the case. The Opposition with very great reluctance opposes this Bill to amend the Geneva protocols.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did Senator Durack support it two years ago?

—We are not alone in that. The Prime Minister of this country, Robert James Lee Hawke, opposed the protocols and said as much in a letter to President Reagan when the protocols first came out. The Prime Minister has since been got at by the lefties in his Party, and it is not surprising when one looks at the speaking list for this debate. We see on it Senator Cooney, Senator Schacht and Senator Faulkner, all the far Left, all in here assuaging the fact that they have sold their principles out over the Gulf involvement. They have all been given a place on the speakers list so that somehow or other, as Senator Schacht describes himself, they can be a great moral force. They can get up in this place and talk about the iniquities of the Opposition bringing a bit of commonsense into this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We oppose this Bill quite simply because it hamstrings our own troops. If implemented, it will lead to unnecessary loss of Australian lives. I make no apology for the preservation of Australian lives, whether they are in civilian circles or whether they wear the uniform of this country. There could be bigger losses than the loss of a few lives.

We support the intention behind the Geneva protocols. We would support the protocols if they were subject to reservations. Most of the countries that have been paraded by the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and by the Australian Democrats as supporting this legislation have agreed to these protocols only under the imposition of various reservations to the protocols.

In my reading for this debate I came across a quotation by Clauswitz. I thought that it would be very appropriate for the Democrats but, having listened to Senator Schacht, I think that it applies to him to some degree also-perhaps not to the same degree because it starts by talking about kindhearted people not black-hearted ones. Clauzwitz said:

Kindhearted people might, of course, think that there was some ingenious way to disarm or defeat an enemy without too much bloodshed, and might imagine this is the true goal of the art of war. Pleasant as it sounds, it is a fallacy that must be exposed: war is such a dangerous business that the mistakes which come from kindness are the very worst.
The best interpretation that can be put on the Government in supporting this is that it is making the mistake of kindness.

Australia's record in the conduct of war and in armed conflict is second to that of no other country. We have nothing to apologise for at all for the actions of our men and women who have worn the uniform of the Australian defence forces. The way in which we have conducted war, the way in which we have used our weapons systems, and the way in which we have treated our prisoners of war do not need explanation, qualification or defence in any way whatsoever. Australia has respected not only the Geneva Conventions as they exist but the whole body of international law which, as the ALP and the Australian Democrats do not understand, goes back not 50 years or 100 years, but hundreds, if not thousands, of years. There is a whole body of international law in relation to armed conflict. Australia has always respected and supported the principles of it.

This particular protocol that we have before us was drawn up by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC). Few people realise that the only people who can be members of that Committee are Swiss nationals, Swiss civilians. The ICRC held a series of conferences over the years to which international representatives were invited. Presumably this is the body that Senator Bourne talks about as being full of Australian military personnel, actively involved in the formulation of the record. Nothing can be further from the truth.

The overwhelming majority of members at the Committee meetings over the years that led to this recommendation being formulated by the ICRC was made up of those from Third World countries, out of Africa and other parts of the world-people who actively pushed their own concerns. It might have been quite legitimate for them to push their own concerns, but the Western democratic nations were not the principal formulators of this policy. They were Third World countries and they were openly pushing what they saw as necessary in their own narrow interests. The interesting thing is that the Swiss Army or the Swiss defence forces, even though the Swiss have not fought for 200 years, rejected the protocol without major changes and reservations. Those reservations and rejections have been echoed around the other Western democratic nations.

The United States rejects it out of hand, will not have a bar of it; Britain will not have a bar of it; France will not have a bar of it; none of the Warsaw Pact countries will have a bar of it; none of our neighbours, not one of the Association of South East Asian Nations, will sign the protocol. The only region in the area that signed it was poor old New Zealand under Lange, or his successor. That is some recommendation! As I said, most of the Western powers, the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries, that the Left wants to trot out as paragons of virtue and that signed the protocol did so with reservations; and they were the minor, inconsequential members of NATO.

How did we get into this position? The Department of Defence set up a review committee some years ago. It was composed of operational officers, that is, those who actually have to do the fighting, and a number of legal officers. The recommendation of the first Australian Department of Defence committee was so heavily qualified, so full of reservations, that it rejected the signing of the protocol. That committee's view, in true Department of Defence and government styles under Labor, was rejected, ignored. Another committee was set up to look at the matter which was comprised only of legal officers-I am advised that they were as few as two in number-and they accepted that we should be a signatory to the Geneva Conventions protocol. This Bill is the consequence of that. It is on that advice that the Chief of the Defence Force Staff makes his advice to the Government which is paraded by the Left as being the acceptance of the Australian defence forces. I have to say that I do not know one officer in the Army, the Royal Australian Navy or the Royal Australian Air Force who is involved in operations, that is, in a fighting role, and who supports the signing of this protocol-not one. If we had a secret ballot, we would find the proof of that statement.

The Bill that is before us, for an Act to amend the Geneva Conventions Act of 1957, runs to 73 pages. It is a very legalistic document. I propose to follow the precedent that has been set by the other distinguished speakers who have spoken on this side of the chamber against it. A very excellent and brilliant speech was made by Mr Peacock in another place, where the legal implications of the Bill, clause by clause, were dealt with. Senator Hill has done the same here tonight. I wish to follow the example set by Mr N.A. Brown, Mr Nugent, Mr Atkinson, Mr Bradford and Senator Knowles, who have all preceded me either here or in the other place, and cite a few examples so that those who have not had the opportunity to wade through the 73 pages of the Bill can see why the Opposition has reservations about signing the protocol without amending it in some way or other.

We believe that the Bill is restrictive and dangerous to a degree in its application to the Australian Defence Force. We believe that our history proves that we can honour, have honoured and are prepared to honour into the future all the humanitarian aspects in relation to the rules of law in the conduct of armed conflict. It is interesting that Iraq, which has had such a terrible history in the past 12 months, not to say the past eight to nine years, is a signatory to all the conventions. That is how binding and effective these conventions have and what great moral force they have. This is why the Third World countries love it. They can get a veneer of respectability by being a signatory but, when they get into armed conflict, it does not matter a darn to them; they still go ahead and do the things that Iraq has done.

Since the outbreak of hostilities by the United Nations forces against Iraq to clear it from Kuwait, we have seen Iraq, in breach of the Geneva Conventions, use prisoners of war (POWs) in public on television screenings. There has not been a word of protest about it from that side. We have seen televised forced confessions from POWs. Worse still, we have seen human shields formed out of these POWs and we have had Iraq boasting that some airmen have died because they have been human shields around military targets. All of these things are flagrant breaches of the existing Geneva Conventions by a country which is a signatory to them.

We have seen not only the premeditated attack by Iraq on civilians of countries with which they are nominally at war, such as Saudi Arabia in the missile attacks on Riyadh, but we have also seen the release of many a Scud missile attack indiscriminately targeted intentionally and in a premeditated way against civilians in Israel. It is hard to imagine a more flagrant breach of any convention of war than that which we have seen from Iraq; yet Iraq has the moral stature of being a signatory to these conventions.

One of our problems comes from the fact that our principal ally is the United States. Our major treaty agreement is with the United States, and the United States will not have a bar of this convention. It makes it very difficult for us to ally ourselves with the United States.

I said that Mr Peacock made the definitive speech on this in the House of Representatives and it is interesting that when we read the House of Representatives Hansard, we see that none of the points that Mr Peacock made was ever refuted by the Labor Party speakers after him. They glissaded and skated around the points, but they never countered the legal points that he raised. Mr Bilney, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, made the claim that the matter of inter- operability, which is a very real concern to us, is not relevant because the Australian Navy is engaged in joint operations with the United States Navy in the Midway carrier battle group at the present time in the Persian Gulf. This overlooks the fact that this legislation has not yet passed through the Parliament and in that sense is inoperative.

There is very real need for interoperability here. Since we are the lesser power, the operational command is always in the hands of the major power. That means we take orders from the Americans. In the case of the Gulf-because it is a nice, simple, very clear example-we have got ships there as part of a carrier task force. If this Bill had been passed and was now an Act of the Australian Parliament, it would be quite impossible for any captain of an Australian ship to accept a fire plan to bombard the shore installations of Iraq or Kuwait because, under the terms of this Convention as it is written, the Australian captain could not say beyond reasonable doubt that he could not be sure there were no civilians in the target area. Therefore, as the Convention is written, he has no option but to decline to be part of that operation. That is an enormous limitation on us in relation to our allies.

Another concern is the legitimisation of terrorists and irregulars. Senator Schacht made a great thing about that in relation to the South Africans. The fact of life is that, through history, there has been an enormously strict division between civilians and members of the armed forces. That has been done not to protect the soldiers, but to protect the civilians. Governments do not want civilians involved in combatant situations. For that reason, the international law of armed combat makes it very clear that certain conditions have to be met by any armed force. There has to be a system of command, there has to be someone in command giving orders and a chain of command set up. There has to be a uniform, which is clearly visible at a distance, worn by the combatants. Arms, rifles and weapons have to be carried openly, not concealed. The conduct of operations always has to be done with respect to the international laws of combat. This is all done so that civilians are not involved accidentally in the fighting between the combatant troops.

This protocol before us today raises to prisoner of war status, the equivalent of a uniformed member of an armed service, any member of a terrorist organisation. It does not matter how unlawful, how irregular, how literally without form or structure the organisation is that that person represents. There are very big advantages in that to the irregulars. Let us imagine that an Irish Republican Army terrorist had blown up the British Prime Minister and the British Cabinet a couple of weeks ago and had been caught. If this protocol had been in place that person would be a prisoner of war. He would have been locked up immediately with three good meals a day, no duress, nothing done to him at all. He would just sit there and watch television until such time as hostilities were over and then he would go home. As an irregular, as a guerilla, as a terrorist, a person is subjected to the civil criminal laws of the country. He is brought before the courts, tried and, if found guilty, he is convicted. There is an enormous difference between the two.

This Bill aids the unscrupulous people, the unscrupulous countries, and penalises the scrupulous ones because it provides, for the first time, a positive incentive for military forces to merge with and to hide with the civilian community. It also inverts the traditional law of combat because the pattern has been to put the onus on the defender, not the attacker. This again reinforces the hiding of a country's military assets in the civilian community.

If we think back to the Second World War, the very first thing the Australian Government did was to withdraw Australian civilians from danger areas in the north and in the islands because that was its obligation, and the correct action. It is for the defender to protect the civilian component of his population from attack in whatever ways are open to him. Yet this protocol inverts that traditional system.

There is a large section on the use of weapons and weapon systems. This is very ambiguously written, but the protocol expressly limits the right of the parties-that is of nations-in an armed conflict to choose their own method or means of warfare by prohibiting the employment of weapons, projectiles, material and methods of warfare of a nature as to cause superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering. The definition that is there, `causing superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering', is so wide that most of the weapons that we want to use in warfare could well be deemed to be illegal. There is no argument that we would want to see nuclear, chemical and biological weapons banned. We want to see weapons that produce gross suffering to people in combat banned. But enshrining it in this legislation makes any commander guilty. It is conceivable that things like land mines, flame throwers and all the other things that, horrible though they might be, have a legitimate place in limiting the casualties of the side using them, could well be banned.

We should never forget that we are not in a debating society here. We are talking about a protocol which provides very stringent penalties. Anyone who breaches the conditions of the protocol can be tried as a war criminal and sentenced to 14 years. There is an obligation on military commanders to prevent, suppress and report breaches of the protocol. That is very simple to write, but in the heat of battle it is largely unenforceable. There are three great commands in the Army, the platoon, battalion and division, and I would not want to be any one of those three commanders if this protocol were in place. Commanders simply cannot defend themselves against the charge that they failed to prevent, suppress or report breaches of the protocol. Commanders are operating under orders from above and they have subordinates below them. In the heat of a battle they simply cannot control the situation to that sort of degree, so that they can stand up in a court of law some months or years later and be completely covered against all eventualities.

This protocol binds individually and collectively all the members of the Australian Defence Force. It is not only the Chief of the Defence Force who is going to go to court, it can be any person from the four star general at the top, down to the newest recruit, a private at the bottom. It is too ambiguous, it is far too complicated for any combat situation.

In conclusion, I would like to comment on the Government's action with this. When the Government first moved to introduce these protocols, it came to the Opposition and the Opposition said it was not prepared to go ahead with the Government in this form. The Government, quite correctly, withdrew the Bill from the Parliament at that time. Lionel Bowen had enough sense to know that unless it was bilaterally supported it was so important an issue that it could not proceed.

Then what happened? I presume the Left got at the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and had the Bill brought in and reintroduced. It has come through with the support of the Australian Democrats, the rent-a-mob crowd for getting difficult legislation through this Parliament. But that is not good enough. This is a major issue for Australia and this Opposition will not put either the lives of individual servicemen or the country at risk through defective legislation.

It has been one of the traditions of the Parliament that succeeding governments do not revise, let alone rescind, treaties of previous governments. But this matter is so important that I think there is a high probability in government that in a year, 18 months time or whenever it is, we are going to have to come back to this and have a look at it. We are also probably going to have to look at a few other treaties that the Labor Party has put through, where it has tried to outflank the Constitution by using the external affairs powers to get past something that it could not get through the Parliament. There is a real need, I think, to review treaties that are on the book.

We support the spirit behind this. We are totally opposed to any unnecessary brutality or loss of life in armed operations. However, we do not believe that this very muddled, ambiguous and extraordinarily complex piece of legislation is at all effective. Not only is it ineffective but we believe that it is also highly dangerous for the operations of the Australian Defence Force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose one should never really be surprised by decisions that are made by the Federal Opposition but, frankly, its decision not to support the Government on this legislation is really quite extraordinary. The Government introduced an identical Bill to this-the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1989-in March 1989 but adjourned debate on it after the Liberal Party of Australia indicated its opposition to the legislation. The Government was, of course, very anxious to have bipartisan support on such an important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is now being reintroduced in the midst of circumstances which, one would think, would make it of particular relevance. One would have thought that the Opposition would have recognised its relevance and importance and supported the current Bill. But no, it is opposing it once again. I am surprised, firstly, because the present shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock, is, to the best of my knowledge anyway, the same Mr Andrew Peacock who was Minister for Foreign Affairs in 1978 when Australia signed the protocols. I think he is the same Mr Andrew Peacock who presided over at least the last couple of years of Australia's role in the delicate and difficult negotiations in drawing up the protocols. I suppose this is an object lesson to all of us in politics. Mr Peacock's political star is certainly on the wane-rooster one day, feather duster the next.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that clever! The same tired old epithet!

—He obviously got rolled, as did Senator Hill, by people like Senator Bishop in the Liberal Party room. I was also surprised at the Opposition's stance, because protocol I is such straightforward stuff. It aims simply to provide protection for the victims of international armed conflicts and to include breaches of the new protections in the range of offences under the Geneva Conventions Act; surely a priority for anyone wishing to display civilised and humanitarian attitudes. I am surprised that there has even been a need to have a debate on this issue. But my surprise increased even more when I looked at the pathetic case that has been mounted against ratification of this protocol.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the case? Boiled down it is this: the United States (US) will not ratify the protocols. The Opposition sees Australia as creatures of the US. Therefore, the Opposition must reverse its previous stance on this issue. Australia must not place impediments in the way of the US or any manner in which it chooses to wage war. The late Mr Peter Hastings, writing in the Sydney Morning Herald on 20 March 1989, said:

The US opposes ratification on familiar great-power grounds. It would oblige the US in various armed conflict situations to fight with `one hand tied behind its back'. Washington has also warned if Australia ratifies the document the `interoperability' of US and Australian forces (their capacity to conduct joint operations) would be at stake.

In other words, when the US says jump the Opposition jumps. Even if we grant-which I certainly do not-that we must accept creature status in relation to the United States, or any other country for that matter, the Opposition is very sadly off beam in this argument.

The provisions of protocol I, which the Opposition claims will make warfare less efficient, which is an amazing concept in itself in the context of a humanitarian debate, are contained in articles 35 to 58. They do indeed impose obligations on those engaged in warfare. These obligations are that they must ensure that their objectives in warfare are military rather than civilian. Article 57, precaution in attack, is of especial note to use in the past few days. This article reads in part:
1. In the conduct of military operations, constant care shall be taken to spare the civilian population, civilians and civilian objects.
2. With respect to attacks, the following precautions shall be taken:
(a) those who plan or decide upon an attack shall:

(i) do everything feasible to verify that the objectives to be attacked are neither civilians nor civilian objects and are not subject to special protection but are military objectives within the meaning of paragraph 2 of Article 52 and that it is not prohibited by the provisions of this protocol to attack them.
Paragraph 2 of article 52 reads:

Attacks shall be limited strictly to military objectives. In so far as objectives are concerned, military objectives are limited to those objects which by their nature, location, purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and whose total or partial destruction, capture or neutralisation, in the circumstances ruling at the time, offers a definite military advantage.

I would like to take a look at last week's bombing of an air raid shelter in Baghdad-in light of these provisions of protocol I. Would this protocol have prevented the US legally taking the action it did in bombing such a target? I quote from the front page of today's Australian:
Despite publicly defending last Wednesday's attack as a strike on a legitimate military target, senior Pentagon officials privately acknowledged to the Sunday Times-
I interpolate here that that is where this story was obtained from-
they were wrong not to check whether the building was being used by civilians before jets struck it with two bombs on Wednesday night.
`The satellite reconnaissance said this was a deep, multi-faceted bunker, like other command and control bunkers,' a Pentagon source said.
`But there was very little on-the-ground assessment and we had no idea civilians were there.'

A case could certainly be made that the intelligence undertaken by the United States before the bombing operation did not conform with the obligations outlined in articles 57 and 52 of protocol I. Perhaps they do not wish to ratify the protocol because of situations such as this. However, it is not, I believe, acting in its own best interests in failing to ratify these protocols. I do not believe that anyone would accuse the US of having deliberately bombed an air raid shelter. I do not believe it. The same article from the Australian went on to say:
`Clearly it was a propaganda victory for Saddam Hussein because we did not realise the civilians were there,' the source said.
In relation to this, in the House of Representatives the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) showed a degree of clairvoyance when he said in last week's debate in the House:

It is the opinion of the Government that observance of these principles is necessary not only for the humanitarian conduct of armed conflict, but also for the success of military operations, paradoxical though that may seem. Enormous destruction of lives and civilian infrastructure can harden resolve in war and can undermine peace or the possibility of peace once hostilities cease.

There is no doubt that the United States', and hence the coalition's, cause has suffered from this incident, and the United States would certainly admit that. If it had ratified this protocol and had observed its strictures on intelligence operations before this bombing raid, not only may 300 Iraqi civilians, mainly women and children, still be alive but the United States would have avoided the dismay and the grief that this incident has caused amongst its own supporters.

At any rate, the requirements on military commanders to take all care with the lives and property of civilians and innocent parties are not new requirements. No reasonable humanitarian and, I stress, intelligent commander would object to the codifying of these rules in this way for the purpose of bringing breaches of these protections within the range of offences under the Geneva Conventions Act.

The Chief of the Defence Force, General Peter Gration, who is the Australian Government's senior military adviser, has advised the Government that it should ratify the protocols, that it will not affect the way we conduct warfare and that ratification is in the national interest. Of course, General Gration is looking at Australia's perspective and Australia's interests in coming to that conclusion. I would urge the Opposition to do the same rather than trying to second guess any of our great and powerful friends.

Australia is a sovereign nation and, I hope, a maturing nation. We must make decisions such as this based on our own interests, our own perspective and, I might say, our own morality. However, if we are going to look at what our friends have done-which seems to be very important to people like Senator MacGibbon-what about Canada? Canada has more forces committed to the Gulf than Australia has, yet Canada has ratified the protocols and, further, has made the subsequent declaration under article 90.

Another point for those opposite to note is that this has not affected Canada's relationship with the United States at all. The United States has managed to accommodate its stance on this issue; it has also managed to accommodate those of its other Gulf allies who have ratified the protocols. So I ask: why is Australia different?

I just mentioned that Canada has made the declaration under article 90. I would like to stress that I consider it most important that Australia quickly complete all processes and consultation necessary also to do this without further delay. I find it totally bemusing that it has taken 13 years for these protocols to be ratified and I think it is fair enough that we see no further delays.

The International Committee of the Red Cross and the Australian Red Cross Society have urged all in this Parliament to support the adoption of the protocols that are before us. The Red Cross, time after time in warfare, has to mop up the mess and destruction of lives and property caused by war. It has prepared a document setting out its views. In part, this document says:

Australia has shown its concern for the fate of the civilian population in times of war. Australia should now ratify both Protocols and thereby show to its own people, to its neighbours and to the world at large that this country is willing to accept binding obligations of a strictly humanitarian character . . .

I strongly endorse these views and urge the Opposition to take note of them; they are words of reason and humanity. I might point out, too, that they are words of reason and humanity that have been heeded by many others.

As of late last year, 97 countries have ratified protocol I and 87 countries have ratified protocol II. This number includes our near neighbour, New Zealand, as well as other countries such as Denmark, Austria, Sweden, Finland, Norway and Switzerland.

It has been pointed out ad nauseam in this debate by the Opposition that in the list of those countries that have ratified the protocols the names of Britain, France and the United States are not present; that they are conspicuous by their absence. The point that I am making is that that need not concern us. We should look at our own perspective. We should look at humanitarian and international interests and make our own decision.
