On this issue we should not let our agenda be set by other countries. I strongly support this most important legislation before the Senate.

The thing which springs to mind first and foremost is this: what is it that compelled the Labor Party to reintroduce this legislation at this crucial time during the Gulf War? What is it that persuaded the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who has held a constant line, to be rolled in his party room by the far Left and to bring on this particular piece of legislation?

SPEECH.PARA: We listened to Senator Coates's question to Senator Evans at Question Time today. He asked: could we please beg for a cease-fire? We note that Senator Childs has been a strong supporter of the appeasers of Saddam Hussein. The sort of rhetoric that we got from Senator Schacht and Senator Faulkner is the only justification they have. Senator Schacht, who purports to come from the Centre Left, had to hide his own embarrassment at being rolled by the Left by attacking the Opposition for refuting this legislation. To put it into context, I think it is important to know that the Opposition considered this particular legislation during 1989 on two separate occasions and gave it very serious consideration. The Party accepted the recommendation that was made by the shadow Minister concerned. Very simply, it is that advantages of this legislation are outweighed by the disadvantages. Accordingly, we are opposing the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990 this evening. Paragraph 3 of the explanatory memorandum, which accompanies the legislation, states:

The most significant change to the law is to be found in Clause 5 of the Bill, which, in effect, incorporates the obligation to punish `grave breaches', as defined in Protocol 1, into our domestic law.

That is the requirement that other countries who have become parties to the protocol-such as Saddam Hussein, a signatory-have agreed to do. Yet we have seen Saddam Hussein fire indiscriminate Scud missiles into suburban areas of Jeru- salem aimed specifically at civilian casualties. The reason that the missiles have not been as successful as he would like is that the Iraqis are forced to fire those missiles from mobile platforms which they then have to re-hide so that they are not bombed. Accordingly, their aim is not quite as accurate as they might have liked. Also, because those missiles have to travel some considerable distance, they have had to sacrifice the power of the missile for fuel to get it there; but the aim is to kill civilian populations. Yet we have heard no protest about that aspect from our friends on the left tonight.

I think it is quite poignant that we are debating this piece of legislation at exactly the moment that the whole dilemma of how to apportion blame in a war is being given as a very good example. I refer to the question of the bombing of the bunker in Baghdad over which so much controversy has lain in the last several days. On 16 February in Launceston, the Prime Minister said:
. . . he had been briefed by Australian intelligence officers on Thursday on the bombing raid and understood that the US had no evidence to suggest the shelter was being used by civilians.
Obviously I and all Australians are horrified at the loss of any innocent civilians, but I think they understand the accuracy of what I have said.
Mr Hawke told an impromptu press conference:
Allies in their targeting have been extremely careful to ensure they target military and strategic installations.

On the same day, General Kelly said that, indeed, the bunker was a military target. Today from the Australian we had a partial quote from Senator Faulkner, who is very good at partial quotes and the inaccuracies of the Left of the Labor Party. He quoted unknown sources from the Pentagon as saying that there had been an error. What he did not quote was the United States officials in Saudi Arabia who denied the admissions made in Washington and said that in particular the intelligence identifying the bunker as only a military command post was out of date.

So we have one group of officials saying that there was an error, another group of officials who are closer to the action saying it was not, the Prime Minister of this country saying that it was a military installation, and Saddam Hussein perhaps using the whole episode as a justification for the use of chemical warfare, which is of course also outlawed by international law.

This is the classic case of United States bomber pilots; Australian servicemen under a joint command; and the death of civilians, which may or may not be considered in terms of the protocol to be a grave breach of the convention. If this is to be brought into our civil law, as indeed this legislation would do, then there would be an obligation to prosecute anyone who came within our jurisdiction as a war criminal and to make that person subject to up to 14 years in gaol. That is what this protocol is all about.

A man of straw was erected by Senator Schacht. He wanted honourable senators to believe that at present if an Australian serviceman committed murder, he would somehow get off scot-free. That is simply not the case. There is ample law already in place to deal with that situation. We are dealing with a whole new scope of the conventions which have been in existence for some time but have become extended because there is an attempt to codify the law.

I think it is important that we realise what those other controversial aspects of the protocol are. Firstly, it would apply to wars of liberation and guerilla warfare by reason of article 1 (4); secondly, the difficulty in making distinctions between combatants and the civil population, especially in the context of guerilla warfare under articles 43, 44 and 48; thirdly, restrictions that are imposed on military operations under articles 50 to 58, which seek to protect civilians and the civilian population from the effects of armed hostilities; and, fourthly, the blanket prohibition on the right of reprisal provided by article 20.

In dealing with something such as the difficulty in distinguishing between what is an acceptable target and what is not an acceptable target, things such as nuclear power stations would be specifically outlawed. Does that mean that those nuclear power installations which were bombed in Iraq would make the people who bombed them war criminals within the context of someone against whom we would want to bring the force of law and moral opprobrium? I suggest not.

Who will forget the gruesome sight of allied pilots shot down, maltreated and humiliated by the televising of falsified statements against their homelands? `The butchers are torturing our boys' read the tabloids. This treatment was in direct contravention of the provisions of the Third Geneva Convention on the treatment of prisoners of war. This is the collective view of President Bush, Prime Minister Major and our own Prime Minister.

We have all heard the reports from Kuwait of the maltreatment of Kuwaiti citizens-the raping of women, the torturing of their men and the pillaging of their goods. These actions surely would be a blatant disregard of the provisions of the Fourth Geneva Convention dealing with the protection of civilian persons in the time of war. We should always remember that Iraq is a signatory to the protocol, yet we see nothing but contempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Weekend Australian of 16 February an article written by Greg Sheridan about my Senate speech on 12 February appears. In that speech I urged the normalisation of Australia-China relations. This article is presented in a sensationalist style and seriously misrepresents what I said. I have never met this journalist, but he telephoned me briefly last Thursday. He asked me some general questions about my travel arrangements, but he did not question me about the topics he addressed in his article.

SPEECH.PARA: The article grossly misrepresents the whole thrust of my speech and it misrepresents my own assessment of the issues that currently bear upon where Australia-China relations should be heading. The first misrepresentation is the article's headline. I am not sure whether this was the responsibility of Mr Sheridan or the work of a subeditor. The headline reads, `Lib rejects Chinese massacre ``trauma''.' This assertion is wrong. On the contrary, I condemned the massacre and I carefully described in my speech how its trauma is still felt by the people of Beijing. In my speech I described how I had recently observed that this trauma is still unresolved. In my speech of 12 February I actually said that this massacre is unparalleled in Beijing's entire history. There has never been so traumatic a massacre. I do not reject the massacre and I do not reject its immense trauma.

How it is possible for anyone to hear or read my Senate speech of 12 February and then write a headline like that defies comprehension. In contrast to Mr Sheridan, I am heartened that two of the many people who did read and listen to my speech carefully and understand it were Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Senator Robert Hill, the shadow Minister for that portfolio. They have not made any assertions such as those made by Mr Sheridan. I respect their constructive responses, which were entirely opposite to the sensationalist Sheridan approach.

The second misrepresentation is found in the opening paragraph of the article, where Mr Sheridan makes the accusation that I have `opposed Opposition policy towards China'. This is not correct. Such a policy detail is not always declared specifically, but is a movable feast in response to developments. It is correct to say that in expressing my personal views, which are entirely in the same direction as all Opposition statements made since last August, I am addressing the next step in that direction, which is the timing for Australia's decision to normalise our relations with China and end the sanctions policy. My colleague Senator Hill is more cautious than me in taking this next step. Although we have both criticised the Government for remaining too aloof from China in recent months and we have both urged the Government to adopt more direct dialogue with China, Senator Hill believes the time has not yet come to remove all sanctions.

Senator Evans's response on this point was indicated in his remarks in the Senate at the end of the same adjournment debate last Tuesday. He said that he was giving very close consideration to taking this next step; the question at issue was the question of timing. I quote:

In considering all these matters, it is very difficult to apply absolute considerations. To deal in any absolute way with the situations we confront is always a matter of drawing an appropriate balance between competing demands, competing objectives. It is always a matter of judgment as to how these responses should be applied, taking into account the nature of our relationship, the nature of the great issues of principle that are involved and, among other things, the nature of the reaction of other like-minded countries, and I can assure Senator Teague that all these things are being very closely considered at the moment.

One of the matters that is always relevant in considering these kinds of issues is the question of timing. It is the case, as Senator Teague himself acknowledged in his speech, that that is a particularly sensitive matter at the moment with a number of remaining trials either taking place or just concluded in Beijing. That is something that the Government, again, will need to bring into account in its deliberations on these matters.

Thirdly, I am misrepresented in Mr Sheridan's article by the second headline, `Excellent propaganda'. This is mischievous and sensationalist, and is presumably intended to catch the reader's eye. However, it actually directs ridicule at my drawing attention to the deaths of some Chinese soldiers killed by civilian violence. It is my view that these soldiers' deaths greatly added to the urgency and ruthlessness of the army columns advancing towards Tiananmen. The misrepresentation is that this headline, `Excellent propaganda', is placed in the article at a point quite distant from the related text in such a way that it appears to denigrate my personal assessments as merely the acceptance of a foreign government's propaganda. This is not true, nor is it fair to leave open such a prejudiced interpretation.

My own remarks about the detailed events of 3 and 4 June in Beijing appear to have raised Mr Sheridan's ire. Ironically, my remarks are not derived from statements from the Chinese Government, whether `propaganda' or otherwise. In fact, the few published statements made by the Chinese Government about the Beijing massacre are very limited in their detail and that is why in my speech I criticised the Chinese Government's failure to give all the facts and an adequate explanation. Some Chinese officials have put the number of soldiers' deaths as low as about 36 during the first week of June. However, I believe the figure may have been as high as 100.

Finally, there is one point I should clarify and it concerns my phrase `in the few days preceding 4 June', which was quoted in the article. The point I wanted to emphasise was the new and increasing violence organised by students and non-students in the crowds occupying the roadblocks and Tiananmen Square at this time. This violence increased in the few days preceding 4 June. However, it is true that the deaths on both sides of the conflict mainly occurred on one day, and that was 4 June. Dr Jonathan Unger and Mr Hong Li Zhien were understandably cited in the article as calling for this correction. I suggest that this man has been delivered a most potent interference in his entitlement to appear before a committee of the Parliament. In fact, I am advised that this process is in contempt of a committee of the Parliament. I would further advocate and suggest for the deliberation of the Senate that the court orders themselves in support of this process may indeed be in contempt of the Parliament.

It is a reality that any person who appears or seeks to appear before a parliamentary committee has absolute parliamentary privilege and must not and cannot be in any way constrained. The effect of these orders is indeed to constrain this key witness before the parliamentary inquiry. If it does constrain him in fact, it will be in contempt of the Parliament. Whether it constrains him in fact or not, it has intimidated him and any other witness who may have been intending to appear before such a parliamentary committee. I believe that it is threatening to establish a precedent by which the raising of any writs and subsequent court orders could become a potent and frequently used instrument to contempt any subsequent committee of the Parliament.

I know for a fact that this man feels intimidated and feels constrained, and it is up to us to advise him otherwise. Whether we can insure that others who would have appeared before this Committee will not feel constrained or intimidated as a result of the process laid upon him I do not think we can be so sure. This process is more contemptuous because it is the fifth step along a line of interference in the processes of this Committee.

The first action that Westpac took to constrain was a series of injunctions taken out to constrain the publication of documents in Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. I sought to table those documents in this Parliament but it was ruled against.

The second step taken by Westpac to constrain those documents was when Mr Stuart Fowler, the Managing Director of Westpac, appeared before the parliamentary Committee and sought to get back from that Committee the copies of the documents that it had. I argue that that was an attempt to interfere with the processes of that Committee. The argument advanced was that the documents enjoyed legal privilege. I do not argue for one moment that legal privilege is not one of the cornerstones of our society. In essence, it says that any person in this country should be able to appear before his or her solicitor or legal adviser in private, to reveal all and to receive legal advice as to what his or her standing is before the law and that that process be privileged and totally confidential. Quite clearly, that is one of the most fundamental cornerstones of our society. But if the legal adviser goes to the next stage and says, `Certainly you have broken the law, and this is the way to subvert the course of justice as a result of having done that' and block the due processes of entitlement of others who take action as a result of what has been done, that is aiding and abetting and it attracts no privilege.

I argue that when Mr Fowler presented himself to that inquiry and advanced that argument he knew that those documents attracted no privilege but he advanced that argument in an attempt to get the documents back. I argue that Mr Stuart Fowler, the Managing Director of Australia's largest bank, attempted to interfere with the course of that inquiry.

The third thing that Westpac did along this path was to publish a series of advertisements in Australian newspapers calling back to itself copies of these documents. In publishing those advertisements, it attempted to raise in the minds of average Australians that these documents enjoyed privilege which they did not enjoy and that they could not be used before a parliamentary committee in ways in which they could in fact be used.

The fourth step along this path was when Westpac made submissions to the President of the Senate and to the Clerk of the Senate that I should not be entitled to table these documents in the Parliament. I respect the ruling of the President that it was in the preservation of the principle of sub judice over and above the public interest. That was the fourth step along a five step path.

The fifth step occurred yesterday when Westpac sought, through the Supreme Court, to restrain a witness from appearing before a parliamentary committee and presenting evidence in his possession. I argue that there is more than a coincidence in the conjunction of time. Mr McLennan tells me in this letter that at approximately 4 p.m. on Friday the Secretary of the Committee advised him that the Committee had released for publication his submission to the inquiry. At approximately 8.30 p.m. on Sunday he was served with summonses supported by a court order which sought to restrain him and which it is reasonable to argue are in contempt of the parliamentary process.

The manner in which these summonses were served is typical of the manner in which people have summonses served on them all over this country. I was told today by Mr McLennan in a telephone conversation that in the evening at 8.30 p.m., in the dark, he heard noises outside his home. His lady companion went out to investigate the noises. She called upon him to investigate the noises. He did so and people appeared from behind bushes and served him with summonses. This is not the first time that this technique has been used. I suppose it is a way of getting summonses in the hands of someone if the course of the parliamentary process is intended to be perverted.

I know John McLennan and his involvement in this process. For two years he has diligently assembled the evidence and vigorously pursued the course of justice on behalf of people who will take Westpac and other major banks to court on managed foreign loans. I have no doubt that the conjunction time here is more than a coincidence. I am simply saying that this process is a deliberate contempt of the Parliament and that it is simply one of a series of steps, some of which have previously been contemptuous, and which are designed to keep people out of inquiries and to perpetrate the non-disclosure of what is contained in these key documents which, in the words of the bank itself, are devastating. These are documents which I contend will certainly see the light of day because there is no way that the sub judice principle can prevent them from seeing the light of day when an appeal is heard in the first week of April, when I will table them in the Senate if they are not tabled elsewhere. They are documents which, in the words of senior legal advice to me, are potentially the most devastating documents that he has seen in 50 years in law.

I advise honourable senators that I will be writing to both the Speaker of the House and to the Chairman of the Committee advising them that I have received this letter of request from a constituent, Mr John McLennan, and advising them that it is my opinion, on legal advice, that these documents substantiate a contempt of the Parliament. I will ask the Speaker of the House to place the matter before the Privileges Committee of the other place and draw the attention of the Chairman of the Committee to what I am advised is a contempt of his Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I will make a few remarks about events in South Africa and how they relate to my recent visit there. On 21 December it was announced in the Parliament by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) that I would be visiting South Africa with the sanction of the Australian Government. Sources in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade say that it might be the first visit of a member of the Australian Parliament since the 1950s that has been sanctioned by the Government. We all know that not only this Government but also previous governments would not sanction official visits because of the policies of apartheid.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, I arrived in South Africa at a time of considerable international, as well as domestic, interest within that country because of the speech of F.W. de Klerk, State President, on 1 February. I spent a number of days in Johannesburg and a number of days in Cape Town. I also visited Namibia to lead the Government delegation to the Southern African Developing Coordination Conference annual meeting.

It has been reported in the press in Australia that I was described as an envoy of the Australian Government. I never was an envoy. I never claimed that for myself, and it was quite a misleading comment to make. Although I had extensive discussions with a full range of people within South Africa, I never at any stage claimed to those people that I was some sort of envoy or representative of the Australian Government in an official capacity, taking messages backwards and forwards.

During my visit to South Africa I met a wide range of people. I met representatives of the African National Congress (ANC), the Pan African Congress and Inkatha-three of the four main black organisations; and members of the black trade unions in South Africa. I met members of the National Party, the Conservative Party, the Indian party and the so-called coloured parliament; and members of human rights organisations and business groups. I met representatives of the rugby board of South Africa, the cricket organisation and the softball organisation. Included amongst members of the National Party I met was the Foreign Minister, Mr Pik Botha.

In my limited time there I had an opportunity to visit a number of white suburbs in areas of Johannesburg and Cape Town, as well as the black suburbs in the greater metropolitan areas of both those cities. My first comment and observation on visiting those areas was that I doubt that there is any country in the world that has a greater disparity over wealth or greater inequity between the living conditions of one considerable group of citizens compared with another. The poverty of the black townships is appalling. I said previously in media interviews that, although I have visited countries such as Burma, Cambodia and Ethiopia, the poverty of the black population-particularly the living conditions-in South Africa is as bad as any that I have seen.

What is most stark is the comparison with the affluence of the white suburbs. If ever there is an indication of the inequalities of apartheid, the living conditions of the white population and the living conditions of the black population clearly demonstrate it. Sometimes, the starkness and the disparity is a matter of only a few hundred metres. From Sandton in north Johannesburg, which is a very affluent white suburb, one travels a matter of a few hundred metres into the black township of Alexandria and sees appalling poverty.

In all my discussions and observations of South Africa-and I do not proclaim in any way to be an expert after such a short visit-one thing I think I can say confidently is that rapid change is coming to South Africa, and the change is irreversible. Why is this change occurring after such a long period during which the present Government has refused to make any changes at all to the apartheid system? I think there are two reasons. The first is the success of international sanctions. Many people claim that sanctions have not been effective. From all that I heard in South Africa, it is clear that sanctions have hurt the present regime, and hurt deeply.

We know about sporting sanctions. The importance of sporting sanctions was the psychological impact on the white minority Government and its supporters that they were unable to participate in international sporting events. White South Africans, like Australians and people in other Western countries, have a deep love of their sport, particularly rugby, cricket and other major sports. The fact that they have not been able to play internationally for the last decade or more has had a very big psychological impact on the white population in that country.

Trade sanctions, although effective, were not as effective as the financial sanctions. Some time ago Australia put forward a report written by the now recently appointed head of the Treasury, Tony Cole, on how financial sanctions could be effective in South Africa. By all accounts, those sanctions have been very effective over the past few years. I was told by many people that in the end it was the financial sanctions that had the greatest impact on the present Government. Those sanctions created the present economic circumstances. The high interest rates, the inability to borrow money from overseas and the disinvestment that took place all created grave difficulties. In the end, even the most recalcitrant supporters of apartheid realised that there was no future for South Africa while these financial sanctions were in place.

I know that the sanctions were effective because every white person I spoke to requested that sanctions be lifted. If sanctions had not been effective, I suspect that no members of the white population would have asked for them to be lifted. In all the discussions I had with the black population, who undoubtedly suffered greatly from the financial and economic sanctions, it was made quite clear that, despite their suffering, they were more than willing to continue to support the imposition of international sanctions on South Africa because they knew it was the only weapon internationally that would have an effect.

As effective as sanctions were, one should not forget that the real reason apartheid is now coming to an end in South Africa is that the black people themselves chose not to give in. Despite the intolerable circumstances, the awful repression that went on for 30 years, they never gave in in their fight against apartheid. In the end they made the country ungovernable; they withdrew their consent to be governed by a minority regime. They suffered enormous oppression. I met many people in the leadership of the various black organisations in South Africa who gave terrible accounts of the years they spent in gaol, sometimes detained without trial and held in solitary confinement. Not only black people suffered that penalty but also people of other races, including whites, who opposed apartheid.

The black people over recent years made it clear to the regime that to govern would be impossible and that the cycle of unrest would get worse and worse unless significant and major reforms were made to the way the country was governed. For those reasons, the State President of the National Party Government, F. W. de Klerk, in his major speech on 2 February last year and again on 1 February this year in opening the parliamentary session outlined the changes. The speech this year to parliament was significant in a number of ways. The speech last year could be considered very significant because of the release of Nelson Mandela and the unbanning of the African National Congress and other political parties. This year he announced the repeal of all the remaining legislation that maintains apartheid in that country.

One matter that has not been given due publicity in this country is that he tabled in the parliament a manifesto which he called `the manifesto for a new South Africa'. When one reads that manifesto, at long last one sees a commitment from the National Party, on behalf of the white community which it represents, to a multi-racial, democratic South Africa in which all South Africans will be treated equally; will be part of the one country; will have the right to be governed and be part of the government; and will have the right to universal suffrage and universal franchise. South Africa will have a democratic electoral process.

There is also a commitment to human rights-a commitment to have a bill of rights written into the new Constitution. In a way, it is ironic that after 40 years of the ANC and the black community asking for and being refused a bill of rights the white community now wants a bill of rights as a way of protecting the so-called minority views of the country. It means that in South Africa's new Constitution there will be a bill of rights that guarantees the individual liberties that we as a democratic society have taken for granted for so long.

It was fascinating for me as a politician to be in South Africa during the period around the State President's speech. Society at all levels is now developing in such a way that people argue, debate, discuss among themselves, across communities, between groups of people and organisations as to what sort of South Africa they want in future. In a sense one has a clean blackboard to be written upon about the new society. Publicity has been given in the West about the problems that South Africa faces because some groups in the community are publicly saying they refuse to participate. We have also seen stories here in the press about so-called extreme right wing people in the white community refusing to participate. But while those people maintain that public profile, privately they are also involved in the discussions with other groups in the community about the sort of South Africa that has to be created. We are seeing a society that is being remade and in which new institutions are being created. There are new discussions about the way in which a society with its great political, social and economic problems can be reorganised and governed in a civilised way for the future.

I do not want to be over-optimistic about the process, but I do not think that we should be unduly pessimistic. There seems to be an element of goodwill among all the levels of people I met in South Africa. The South African Government has conceded that the present apartheid system is finished and that a new democratic South Africa has to be created. Some people have suggested that there will be a lot of violence associated with this change. I do not think that that will necessarily be the case, although I accept that during the process of rapid and fundamental change in South African society there will be episodes of terrible violence of an indiscriminate nature. But some of it will not be political violence, but straight criminal violence. In a country with seven million homeless blacks and 35 per cent unemployment in the black population, one can understand why there is frustration.

Recently we have had discussions about what the Australian response should be to these changes that are taking place in South Africa. Although I accept that in a formal way we have not reached the stage legally where the abolition of apartheid is irreversible, I think that society in South Africa has reached the stage where it is irreversible. Whatever happens in the Parliament of South Africa, the majority of South Africans, no matter what their race or background, accept that the change is inevitable and that they have to get on with the job.

What is Australia's response? I believe that it was reasonable for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) following the State President's speech to suggest that the Commonwealth of Australia should consider putting to the Commonwealth of nations the proposal for a phased lifting of sanctions, subject to certain criteria being reached. The Commonwealth Foreign Ministers met last Friday in London and issued a statement saying that subject to certain matters being triggered, there should be preparations for sanctions to be lifted. What are those triggers? I think there are three very important triggers that cannot be ignored. Despite the announcement about removing the legislative pillars of apartheid, the remaining three areas, namely the group areas Act, the population registration Act and the land Act are not yet through Parliament, although I expect that they will be passed by about May of this year. That is a very important step.

I think the other important step that has to be taken is the release of the political prisoners in accordance with the Pretoria minute of August last year. By all accounts there are still at least 350 political prisoners in places such as Robin Island who are there for no other reason than their opposition to apartheid in the past. Some of them have already served long sentences. An unknown number of people are still being detained without trial throughout South Africa. I think it is mandatory that the South African Government, in accordance with the Pretoria minute of August last year, release all those political prisoners by 30 April.

In conjunction with that the South African Government has to reach agreement on the indemnity of the return of political exiles. It has been suggested there are as many as 40,000 political exiles. I do not believe all of them will want to return, but those who do have to be guaranteed indemnity that they will not be prosecuted for their activities against apartheid in the past. I understand that that agreement is close to being reached.

Although the existing security legislation is not specifically a pillar of apartheid, it is anti-democratic in many of its features. It enables the police to arrest and detain people without trial for long periods. It gives powers to police to search without a warrant. These are all features which we in a democratic society would abhor. They have to be removed.

In each of the above mentioned areas the Government has said publicly and privately that it will reach agreement in the next few weeks. I noticed last week that the State President F.W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela had a discussion and issued a statement that they had reached political agreement on these sorts of issues. I hope that is correct because it will mean that by about May of this year those matters which are obstacles to further negotiations will have been removed. The Commonwealth Ministers meeting in May can then seriously look at a program of beginning to lift some of those sanctions such as sporting sanctions.

I do not think we should lift trade or financial sanctions until we are further along in the process of reaching agreement about the creation of some sort of interim administration which has black representation. Above all else, I think financial sanctions should be lifted only after agreement has been reached on the substance of a democratic constitution and a date has been set for a general election on the basis of an adult franchise.

Some people, even in the ANC, say that they think it is not too imaginative or fanciful to suggest that by June of next year there can be a general free election in South Africa and a new constitution on adult franchise. Though that speed of change may take our breath away, even people in the ANC believe it is possible and I hope that that timetable can be achieved. I am sure that all members of this Parliament would agree with it.

In conclusion, I would like to put on record a personal aspect of my trip. My visit to South Africa had many exciting highlights. I met a range of people, from Nelson Mandela to the Foreign Minister, Pik Botha. The highlight for me at a personal level was being invited to attend an ANC funeral at Sebokeng. In mid-January, at a black township outside Johannesburg, 42 people were massacred in an act of indiscriminate violence. The ANC organised a major mass funeral for those 42 people which I was able to attend. It was held in a dilapidated soccer stadium. There were about 25,000 people present at the funeral. It was a very moving experience. Leaders of the ANC such as Albertina Sisulu and Thomas Nkobe were present. The major speaker was Archbishop Desmond Tutu. All these people made magnificent speeches. When I was given an invitation to speak at the rally it was with some trepidation that I spoke amongst speakers who had made such powerful contributions at such an emotional moment.

I do not think that I will ever have the opportunity in Australia, as I did in South Africa, to speak to an audience of about 25,000 people. When the speeches were finished, to be congratulated on my speech by people such as Desmond Tutu, Nobel Peace Prize winner, was an honour that I will not forget for a long time. I will also not forget being at a funeral which ended with 25,000 people singing the ANC national anthem, Sikelele Africa. It was a moment of considerable emotion. At a personal level, I was very honoured to be able to participate in that ceremony. Like everybody else, I only wish it was not necessary because of this indiscriminate violence.

In conclusion, my observation is that apartheid in South Africa is dead. It will be gone within a couple of years. There will be much agony yet. There will be more violence. There will be many disappointments in that process; but South African society has now reached a stage where it is impossible for the people to put the clock back. I am sure that is something we all welcome. In doing so, I think that we should pay tribute, above all else, to the many black people of that country-and also the many white people-who over 35 to 40 years have never given up the struggle to end what has been one of the worst and most iniquitous systems of racism in the history of the twentieth century.

It was an honour for me to be in South Africa at this particular time. I look forward to following developments there in the next few months. I also want to say that wherever I went in South Africa amongst the black population it was recognised that Australia has played a major role internationally in opposing apartheid. Australia was always recognised for that. I look forward, maybe sometime in the near future, to being able to visit South Africa when it has a constitution that is democratic and non-racial and all people in that country are free.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amount of revenue would be required annually from a general sales tax in order to finance both the abolition of the present wholesale sales tax and reductions in personal income tax.
(2) What amount of revenue collected from a general sales tax would produce a 1.0 per cent rise in the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

(3) How does this figure compare with the $500 million in collections from a broad-based consumption tax which the then Treasurer (Mr Howard) computed in the economy of 1981 would be associated with a 1.0 per cent rise in the CPI (Hansard 12 March 1981).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I refer the honourable Senator to the Treasurer's National Press Club speech on 9 May, 1990 entitled ``Consumption Tax (and other Myths)''. The Treasurer noted in that speech that, it is not possible to introduce today a fully compensated consumption tax which yields net revenue to further reduce income tax rates. Put another way, after replacing the wholesale sales tax, there would be insufficient revenue to provide income tax cuts and increases in welfare payments large enough to maintain real disposable incomes. In 1990-91, a consumption tax of 12.5 per cent would raise about $8.3 billion after abolition of the wholesale sales tax. The cost of compensating welfare beneficiaries for the higher costs associated with the introduction of a 12.5 per cent consumption tax would be in the order of $2.3 billion. But a further $8.5 billion in income tax cuts (after allowing for the reduction in the personal rates scale that will apply from 1 January 1991) would be needed to compensate income earners for their corresponding loss in real disposable incomes. This is $2.5 billion more than what is available from the proceeds of the consumption tax (general sales tax).

(2) The link between revenue collected and corresponding increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) flowing from any switch to a consumption tax will depend on the coverage of that tax system i.e to what extent presently untaxed goods and services become taxed and changes in rates of tax presently applicable to goods under the wholesale sales tax. The Treasurer noted in his Press Club speech that a 12.5 per cent consumption tax would raise some $8.3 billion after allowing for abolition of the wholesale sales tax and add some 5 percentage points to the level of prices. A consumption tax set at the rate of 7 per cent would increase the CPI by about 1 per cent if the wholesale sales tax were removed at the same time. However, this consumption tax would raise less revenue than what is presently being raised by the wholesale sales tax. That is, the CPI would increase by 1 per cent, but indirect tax revenue would actually fall by about $300 million.
(3) See answer to (2), above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Reserve Bank receive regular reports or statements from non-bank financial institutions; if so: (a) what information is required to be included; (b) who is responsible for the provision of these returns; and (c) is there a minimum size for institutions required to report.
(2) Is the Department of the Treasury notified of any changes in the liquidity or viability of non-bank financial institutions.

(3) Does the Reserve Bank report to the Department of the Treasury on matters relating to the viability of bank and non-bank operations and any other developments which could result in damage to public confidence or potentially affect the safety of depositors' funds.

(4) Does the Reserve Bank report to the Reserve-Bank Board on developments affecting the bank and non-bank sectors of the finance industry; if so, is information included which relates to the operations of: (a) industry sectors; (b) groups of organisations in a single group; or (c) individual entities.

(5) Did the Reserve Bank receive reports or financial statements from the: (a) Farrow Corporation; (b) Pyramid Building Society; (c) Geelong Building Society; (d) Country Wide Building Society; (e) Commercial Credit Union; or (f) Building Society Group either as individual entities or in any other combination.
(6) Did the Reserve Bank at any time express concern about the operations and financial viability of any or all of the Farrow Group of building societies.

(7) Does the Reserve Bank report to the Treasurer on the state of the finance industry on a regular basis; if so, do these reports include information or comment on problems of sections of, or individual elements of, the finance industry.
(8) Are regular discussions held between Reserve Bank officers and the Treasurer or his personal staff.
(9) Was the Reserve Bank aware of the possible failure of the Farrow Group of building societies; if so, when did it become aware.
(10) Was the Treasurer, or his office, informed that there was a risk of the Farrow Group of building societies failing; if so, when.

(11) Did the Treasurer have any discussion with, or communication from, the Victorian Government at any level about the imminent failure of the Farrow Group; if so, what was the date of the first communication or discussion.
(12) Was the Treasurer advised of rumours that the Farrow Group was in trouble; if so: (a) when; and (b) by whom.

(13) Were discussions held between Victorian Government officials and the Reserve Bank in January or February 1990 regarding the need for a line of credit for the Farrow Group; if so: (a) on what dates; (b) why were these discussions held; and (c) who initiated them.
(14) Was an agreement reached in February 1990 to provide a line of credit to the Farrow Group; if so, was this with Reserve Bank support.
(15) If the Reserve Bank supported the provision of a line of credit, did it subsequently withdraw its support; if so: (a) when; and (b) why.

(16) Was a meeting held between the Reserve Bank and the Victorian Government in late March or early April 1990; if so: (a) did the Treasurer participate; (b) who represented the Reserve Bank; (c) was the Victorian Treasurer present; (d) who represented the Victorian Government; and (e) did the Reserve Bank advise the Victorian Government representatives that the Farrow Group could not recover or return to being a viable financial institution and should be sold in the interests of the depositors.

(17) If the advice referred to in question 16 (e) was given: (a) what was the basis of the advice; (b) was the Reserve Bank Board aware of the advice and the Bank's concern; and (c) was the Treasurer told of the advice before it was conveyed to the Victorian Government; if so, when and to what level of detail.

(18) Did the Reserve Bank examine: (a) the audit report by the Farrow Group auditors, Day, Neilson, Jenkins and Johns, on which the Victorian Treasurer and Attorney-General made a statement of public support before becoming party to the February-March 1990 agreement on liquidity funds for the Farrow Corporation; and (b) the audit statement prepared for the Farrow Corporation by Price Waterhouse before the meeting with Victorian Ministers and officials in March-April 1990.
(19) Why did the Reserve Bank reject the findings of both the documents referred to in question 18 in its advice to the Victorian Government.

(20) Does the Reserve Bank have: (a) power to intervene in the operations or management of non-bank financial institutions; and (b) the ability to provide funds to non-bank State registered building societies to cover liquidity problems.

(21) Did the Farrow Corporation apply to the Reserve Bank to become a licensed bank or have discussions with the Reserve Bank on the matter; if so, was the Corporation advised that: (a) its equity level was too low; (b) its accounts did not properly reflect its financial position; and (c) its management arrangements were not appropriate.

(22) Has the Treasurer taken part in discussions about the state of Victorian building societies; if so: (a) on how many occasions; (b) who was involved; (c) who was responsible for briefing him; and (d) was he advised that: (i) the public perception of the Farrow Corporation created by its annual reports and its public relations firm, International Public Relations, was inaccurate, (ii) the Farrow Corporation was in serious danger of failure, and (iii) the only problems faced by the Farrow Corporation were rumours started by a bank.
(23) Did the Treasurer receive any requests for a meeting or any other communication from the Farrow Corporation during 1990; if so, what was the purpose of the communication or proposed meeting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Part III of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 gives the Reserve Bank the power to collect statistics from corporations subject to the Act.

(a) The information collected under the Financial Corporations (Statistics) Regulations dated 18 May 1984 varies for the different categories of corporations. For building societies it includes aggregated statistics on lending and borrowing, selected liabilities, assets, interest rates and selected maturity dissection of borrowings.
(b) The Act requires that statistics prepared by corporations under Part III be verified by a statutory declaration made by a senior officer of the corporations.

(c) The Act relates to financial corporations which engage in the borrowing and lending of money in a major way and whose assets exceed $1 million. Certain classes of corporations are exempt from the legislation, including public authorities, authorised banks, terminating building societies, friendly or benefit societies, medical benefits organisations, life and general insurance companies and trustee companies.

2 and 3. My Department is not informed about the liquidity or viability of financial corporations as a matter of course. There is, however, a close working relationship between the Treasury and the Reserve Bank and the Bank keeps it informed of developments relevant to the stability of the financial system. Moreover, the Secretary to the Treasury, as a member of the Reserve Bank Board, receives such information as is provided to other Board members arising from the Bank's surveillance of the financial system.

4. I am informed that the Reserve Board receives regular reports on developments affecting the bank and non-bank sectors of the finance industry, and that the information relates to the operations of industry sectors, groups of organisations in a single group and individual entities.
5. (a) Yes;
(b) (c) Yes;
(d) Yes, but from a corporation entitled Countrywide Building Society.
(e) Yes, but from a corporation entitled Commercial Credit Cooperative Limited.
(f) Yes, but predominantly building societies in the Group (there are other financial intermediaries).

6. I am informed that the Reserve Bank had some discussions about the operations of the Farrow Group with the responsible State authorities. (See responses to parts 9 and 10). These discussions arose from concerns evident in sections of the market.

7. The Governor of the Reserve Bank regularly discusses economic and financial developments with the Treasurer. These discussions may include problems in particular parts of the financial system if the Governor believes that to be appropriate.
8. The Governor and I discuss the state of the economy on a regular basis and we talk face to face or by telephone whenever particular matters warrant it.

9. The Bank has told me that it had been generally aware for some time that the Farrow Group of building societies was exposed to a higher-than-normal operating risk because of its high rate of growth, its exposures to the commercial property sector, and its interest rate policy. Such information as was available to the Reserve Bank, however, was not an adequate basis on which to make considered judgements about the societies' viability.

10, 11, 12. I did not know of the financial difficulties of the Farrow Group of building societies prior to the release of a statement by the Victorian Treasurer on 13 February 1990 concerning Pyramid Building Society.

The only advice received by my office prior to 13 February 1990 was a minute dated 12 February which referred to an article on Pyramid that had appeared in the Sunday Herald on 11 February which stated that there had been small net withdrawals from the Society.
That advice could not be considered knowledge of Pyramid's difficulties. In the event the minute was not drawn to my attention as it was not considered such a serious issue at the time.
13. The Reserve Bank has informed me that it had discussions with Victorian Government officials on a number of occasions:

* On 12 and 13 February 1990-talks initiated by Victorian Office of Management and Budget in relation to its concerns about the risk of a run on Pyramid Building Society and its inquiry about the RBA's policy on liquidity support for building societies.
* On 15 and 20 February 1990-talks with Victorian Registrar of Co-operative Financial Institutions, initiated by RBA, to inquire about Farrow's efforts to arrange additional lines of support.
* On 21 February 1990-talks initiated by Victorian Office of Management and Budget to mention Farrow's liquidity difficulties and problems of securing support from banks.

14. I understand the Farrow Group had discussions with various financial institutions about possible lines of credit. The Reserve Bank has told me it was not party to any such discussions but it made known to banks and to the Victorian Government its longstanding and on-going policy of willingness to provide necessary liquidity support to banks which choose to lend to well-managed and viable non-bank financial institutions.
15. Not applicable; as indicated in the response to part 14, the Reserve Bank did not give its support to the provision of a line of credit to the Farrow Group.

16. The Reserve Bank informs me it did not meet with the Victorian Government in late March or early April 1990. There, however, were numerous discussions between various representatives of the Bank and the Victorian Government during the period from February to June 1990. These were primarily to keep the Bank informed of events as they developed; the Bank did not offer the advice mentioned in the question. I did not participate in any of the Reserve Bank's discussions.
17. Not applicable (refer to the response to part 16).

18. The Reserve Bank has informed me it did not receive a copy of an audit report by Day, Neilson, Jenkins and Johns; it did receive a copy of Price Waterhouse's summary of its review of the Farrow Corporation Limited group.
19. The question is based on an incorrect premise. The Reserve Bank did not see the first document referred to. It neither accepted nor rejected the latter.

20. The Reserve Bank does not have the power to intervene in the operations or management of non-bank financial institutions. Its longstanding policy is not to provide financial support to financial institutions it does not supervise.

21. I am informed that Farrow Corporation did not make application to become a bank. However, in January 1990, Farrow Corporation indicated to the Reserve Bank an intention to seek a banking licence in the medium term (3-5 years) if certain State legislative restrictions on its activities were not removed. The Bank offered no advice on its equity level, accounts or management arrangements. On 11 May 1990, an officer of Farrow Corporation arranged for Mr Farrow to meet with the Chief of Financial System Division of the Bank on 24 May, purportedly to discuss the possibility of a banking authority. The appointment was cancelled by Mr Farrow on 23 May.

22. I have regular discussions about economic and financial developments with both the Reserve Bank Governor and the Secretary to the Treasury. There have however been no particular discussions concerning the state of Victorian building societies.
23. I receive many requests for meetings during the course of a year, but there is no record of any such contact with the Farrow Corporation in 1990.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Inquiry into the Needs of Australian Mariners, Commonwealth and Allied Veterans and Allied Mariners

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government at any time indicate that it intended to respond during the Budget Session 1990 to the Report of the Inquiry into the Needs of Australian Mariners, Commonwealth and Allied Veterans and Allied Mariners, which was commissioned by the Government on 26 January 1989 and was submitted to the Government on 16 October 1989; if so, why has it not done so.
(2) When does the Government intend to respond to the report.
(3) What has been the reason for the delay in excess of fourteen months in the Government's issuing of a response to the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While the Government did not, at any time, undertake to respond fully to the recommendations of the Inquiry into the Needs of Australian Mariners, Commonwealth and Allied Veterans and Allied Mariners during the 1990 Budget Session, two of the Report's recommendations were addressed and accepted.
They were:
* compensation for Australian mariners interned in Nazi concentration camps; and
* the adoption of a medals-based approach to determining Qualifying Service for service pension purposes.
(2) As stated in the answer to question (1), the Government has partially responded to the Report. The remaining recommendations will be addressed when Government business permits.

(3) The Government has responded, in part, to the Report. Outstanding recommendations are being carefully considered. For a just and equitable response, the Government has been consulting with ex-service organisations, Government departments and other interested groups. It is this necessary process which has taken fourteen months.
